<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Taiwan</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Country in East Asia</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"Republic of China" redirects here. For the People's Republic of China, see <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(disambiguation)" title="Republic of China (disambiguation)">Republic of China (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Taiwan_(disambiguation)" title="Taiwan (disambiguation)">Taiwan (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p>
<span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1073938472">.mw-parser-output .geo-default,.mw-parser-output .geo-dms,.mw-parser-output .geo-dec{display:inline}.mw-parser-output .geo-nondefault,.mw-parser-output .geo-multi-punct{display:none}.mw-parser-output .longitude,.mw-parser-output .latitude{white-space:nowrap}</style><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Taiwan&amp;params=24_N_121_E_type:country_region:TW"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">24°N</span> <span class="longitude">121°E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">24°N 121°E</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">24; 121</span></span></span></a></span></span></span>
</p>

high</span></span> · <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">23rd</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Currency</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/New_Taiwan_dollar" title="New Taiwan dollar">New Taiwan dollar</a> (NT$) (<a href="/wiki/ISO_4217" title="ISO 4217">TWD</a>)</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Time zone</th><td class="infobox-data"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">UTC</a>+8</span> (<a href="/wiki/Time_in_Taiwan" title="Time in Taiwan">National Standard Time</a>)</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Date format</th><td class="infobox-data"><div><ul><li>YYYY-MM-DD</li><li>YYY-MM-DD (<a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_calendar" title="Republic of China calendar">Minguo calendar</a>)</li></ul></div></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Left-_and_right-hand_traffic" title="Left- and right-hand traffic">Driving side</a></th><td class="infobox-data">right</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_Taiwan" title="Telephone numbers in Taiwan">Calling code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_Taiwan" title="Telephone numbers in Taiwan">+886</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166" title="ISO 3166">ISO 3166 code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-2:TW" title="ISO 3166-2:TW">TW</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><div class="plainlist"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/.tw" title=".tw">.tw</a></li><li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/.%E5%8F%B0%E7%81%A3" title=".台灣">.台灣</a></li><li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/.%E5%8F%B0%E6%B9%BE" title=".台湾">.台湾</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[22]</a></sup></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Taiwan</b>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-word2_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-word2-33">[II]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ROC_territory_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-ROC_territory-34">[j]</a></sup> officially the <b>Republic of China</b> (<b>ROC</b>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-word1_1-1"><a href="#cite_note-word1-1">[I]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[k]</a></sup> is a <a href="/wiki/Country" title="Country">country</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[23]</a></sup> in <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East Asia</a>, at the junction of the <a href="/wiki/East_China_Sea" title="East China Sea">East</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China Seas</a> in the northwestern <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a>, with the <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">People's Republic of China</a> (PRC) to the northwest, <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a> to the northeast, and the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a> to the south. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Free_Area_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Free Area of the Republic of China">territories controlled by the ROC</a> consist of <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Taiwan" title="List of islands of Taiwan">168 islands</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Taiwan_Islands_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-Taiwan_Islands-47">[l]</a></sup> with a combined area of 36,193 square kilometres (13,974 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-taiwansnapshot_26-1"><a href="#cite_note-taiwansnapshot-26">[16]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NDC2021_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-NDC2021-48">[34]</a></sup> The main <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Taiwan" title="Geography of Taiwan">island of Taiwan</a>, also known as <i>Formosa</i>, has an area of 35,808 square kilometres (13,826 sq mi), with mountain ranges dominating the eastern two-thirds and plains in the western third, where its <a href="/wiki/Urbanization_by_country" title="Urbanization by country">highly urbanised</a> <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Taiwan" title="Demographics of Taiwan">population</a> is concentrated. The capital, <a href="/wiki/Taipei" title="Taipei">Taipei</a>, forms along with <a href="/wiki/New_Taipei_City" title="New Taipei City">New Taipei City</a> and <a href="/wiki/Keelung" title="Keelung">Keelung</a> the <a href="/wiki/Taipei%E2%80%93Keelung_metropolitan_area" title="Taipei–Keelung metropolitan area">largest metropolitan area</a> of Taiwan. Other major cities include <a href="/wiki/Taoyuan,_Taiwan" title="Taoyuan, Taiwan">Taoyuan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taichung" title="Taichung">Taichung</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tainan" title="Tainan">Tainan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kaohsiung" title="Kaohsiung">Kaohsiung</a>. With around 23.9 million inhabitants, Taiwan is among the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Most_densely_populated_countries" title="Most densely populated countries">most densely populated</a> countries in the world.
</p><p>Taiwan has been settled for at least 25,000 years. Ancestors of <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_indigenous_peoples" title="Taiwanese indigenous peoples">Taiwanese indigenous peoples</a> settled the <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Taiwan" title="Geography of Taiwan">island</a> around 6,000 years ago. In the 17th century, large-scale <a href="/wiki/Han_Chinese" title="Han Chinese">Han Chinese</a> (specifically the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hakkas" title="Hakkas">Hakkas</a> and Hoklos) immigration to western Taiwan began under a <a href="/wiki/Dutch_Formosa" title="Dutch Formosa">Dutch colony</a> and annexed by the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Tungning" title="Kingdom of Tungning">Kingdom of Tungning</a> but was later <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_under_Qing_rule" title="Taiwan under Qing rule">taken control of by the Qing</a> of China, and <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Shimonoseki" title="Treaty of Shimonoseki">ceded</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Empire of Japan</a> in 1895. The <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)" title="Republic of China (1912–1949)">Republic of China</a>, which had <a href="/wiki/1911_Revolution" title="1911 Revolution">overthrown the Qing in 1911</a>, took control of Taiwan on behalf of the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allies of World War II</a> following the <a href="/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan" title="Surrender of Japan">surrender of Japan</a> in 1945. The <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Proclamation of the People's Republic of China">defeat of the ROC by Communist forces on the mainland</a> forced the consequent <a href="/wiki/Retreat_of_the_government_of_the_Republic_of_China_to_Taiwan" title="Retreat of the government of the Republic of China to Taiwan">retreat to Taiwan</a> in 1949. Its effective jurisdiction has since been limited to <a href="/wiki/Free_area_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Free area of the Republic of China">Taiwan and smaller islands</a>.
</p><p>In the early 1960s, Taiwan entered a period of rapid economic growth and industrialisation called the "<a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Miracle" title="Taiwan Miracle">Taiwan Miracle</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGold1985_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGold1985-49">[35]</a></sup> In the late 1980s and early 1990s, the ROC transitioned from a <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">one-party</a> military dictatorship to a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Multi-party_democracy" title="Multi-party democracy">multi-party democracy</a> with a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Semi-presidential_system" title="Semi-presidential system">semi-presidential system</a>. Taiwan's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Export-oriented_economy" title="Export-oriented economy">export-oriented industrial economy</a> is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">21st-largest</a> in the world by nominal GDP and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">19th-largest</a> by PPP measures, with a focus on steel, machinery, electronics and chemicals manufacturing. Taiwan is a <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed country</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wb_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-wb-50">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-qq_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-qq-51">[37]</a></sup> ranking 20th on <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">GDP per capita</a>. It is ranked highly in terms of <a href="/wiki/Civil_liberties" title="Civil liberties">civil liberties</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[38]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Taiwan" title="Healthcare in Taiwan">healthcare</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[39]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Human_development_(economics)" title="Human development (economics)">human development</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HDI-1_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-HDI-1-57">[m]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HDI_2019_31-1"><a href="#cite_note-HDI_2019-31">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Taiwan" title="Political status of Taiwan">political status of Taiwan</a> is contentious.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[43]</a></sup> The ROC no longer represents China as a member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, after UN members voted in 1971 to <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_2758" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution 2758">recognize the PRC</a> instead.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-woo21_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-woo21-59">[44]</a></sup> The ROC maintained its claim of being the sole <a href="/wiki/Two_Chinas" title="Two Chinas">legitimate representative of China</a> and its territory, although this has been downplayed since its <a href="/wiki/Democratization" title="Democratization">democratization</a> in the 1990s. Taiwan is claimed by the PRC, which refuses diplomatic relations with countries that recognise the ROC. Taiwan <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Taiwan" title="Foreign relations of Taiwan">maintains official diplomatic relations</a> with 13 out of 193 UN member states and the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-woo21_59-1"><a href="#cite_note-woo21-59">[44]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-60">[45]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[46]</a></sup> though many others maintain unofficial diplomatic ties through <a href="/wiki/Taipei_Economic_and_Cultural_Representative_Office" title="Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office">representative offices</a> and institutions that function as <a href="/wiki/De_facto_embassy#Taiwan" title="De facto embassy"><i>de facto</i> embassies and consulates</a>. International organisations in which the PRC participates either refuse to grant membership to Taiwan or allow it to participate only on a non-state basis under various names. Domestically, the major political contention is between parties favouring eventual <a href="/wiki/Chinese_unification" title="Chinese unification">Chinese unification</a> and promoting a pan-Chinese identity, contrasted with those <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_independence_movement" title="Taiwan independence movement">aspiring to formal international recognition</a> and promoting a <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_people#The_current_state_of_Taiwanese_identity" title="Taiwanese people">Taiwanese identity</a>; into the 21st century, both sides have moderated their positions to broaden their appeal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[47]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[48]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Taipei" title="Chinese Taipei">Chinese Taipei</a>, <a href="/wiki/Names_of_China" title="Names of China">Names of China</a>, and <a href="/wiki/China_and_the_United_Nations" title="China and the United Nations">China and the United Nations</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Name_of_the_island">Name of the island</span></h3>
<p>Various names for the island of Taiwan remain in use, each derived from explorers or rulers during a particular historical period. The name <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Formosa" title="Formosa">Formosa</a> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hant"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%A6%8F%E7%88%BE%E6%91%A9%E6%B2%99" title="wikt:福爾摩沙">福爾摩沙</a></span></span>) dates from 1542, when <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">Portuguese</a> sailors sighted an uncharted island and noted it on their maps as <i>Ilha Formosa</i> ("beautiful island").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yb:history_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-yb:history-64">[49]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[50]</a></sup> The name <i>Formosa</i> eventually "replaced all others in European literature"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDavidson190310_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDavidson190310-66">[51]</a></sup> and remained in common use among English speakers into the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the early 17th century, the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">Dutch East India Company</a> established a commercial post at <a href="/wiki/Fort_Zeelandia_(Taiwan)" title="Fort Zeelandia (Taiwan)">Fort Zeelandia</a> (modern-day <a href="/wiki/Anping_District" title="Anping District">Anping</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tainan" title="Tainan">Tainan</a>) on a coastal sandbar called "Tayouan",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEValentijn190352_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEValentijn190352-68">[53]</a></sup> after their <a href="/wiki/Ethnonym" title="Ethnonym">ethnonym</a> for a nearby <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_indigenous_peoples" title="Taiwanese indigenous peoples">Taiwanese aboriginal</a> tribe, possibly <a href="/wiki/Taivoan_people" title="Taivoan people">Taivoan people</a>, written by the Dutch and Portuguese variously as <i>Taiouwang</i>, <i>Tayowan</i>, <i>Teijoan</i>, etc.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mair_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mair-69">[54]</a></sup> This name was also adopted into the Chinese vernacular (in particular, <a href="/wiki/Hokkien" title="Hokkien">Hokkien</a>, as <a href="/wiki/Pe%CC%8Dh-%C5%8De-j%C4%AB" title="Pe̍h-ōe-jī">Pe̍h-ōe-jī</a>: <i><span lang="nan-Latn"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/T%C4%81i-o%C3%A2n" title="wikt:Tāi-oân">Tāi-oân</a>/<a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/T%C3%A2i-o%C3%A2n" title="wikt:Tâi-oân">Tâi-oân</a></span></i>) as the name of the sandbar and nearby area (Tainan). The modern word "Taiwan" is derived from this usage, which is written in different transliterations (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hant"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%A4%A7%E5%93%A1" title="wikt:大員">大員</a>, <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%A4%A7%E5%9C%93" title="wikt:大圓">大圓</a>, <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%A4%A7%E7%81%A3" title="wikt:大灣">大灣</a>, <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%87%BA%E5%93%A1" title="wikt:臺員">臺員</a>, <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%87%BA%E5%9C%93" title="wikt:臺圓">臺圓</a></span></span> and <span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hant"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%87%BA%E7%AA%A9%E7%81%A3" title="wikt:臺窩灣">臺窩灣</a></span></span>) in Chinese historical records. The area occupied by modern-day Tainan was the first permanent settlement by both European colonists and Chinese immigrants. The settlement grew to be the island's most important trading centre and served as its capital until 1887.
</p><p>Use of the current Chinese name (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hant"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%87%BA%E7%81%A3" title="wikt:臺灣">臺灣</a>/<a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%8F%B0%E7%81%A3" title="wikt:台灣">台灣</a></span></span>) became official as early as 1684 with the establishment of <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Prefecture" title="Taiwan Prefecture">Taiwan Prefecture</a> which centred in modern-day Tainan. Through its rapid development the entire Formosan mainland eventually became known as "Taiwan".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-蔡玉仙等編_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-蔡玉仙等編-70">[55]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-石守謙主編_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-石守謙主編-71">[56]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[57]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Oosterhoff_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-Oosterhoff-73">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>In his <i><a href="/wiki/Daoyi_Zhil%C3%BCe" title="Daoyi Zhilüe">Daoyi Zhilüe</a></i> (1349), <a href="/wiki/Wang_Dayuan" title="Wang Dayuan">Wang Dayuan</a> used "<a href="/wiki/Liuqiu_(medieval)" title="Liuqiu (medieval)">Liuqiu</a>" as a name for the island of Taiwan, or the part of it closest to <a href="/wiki/Penghu" title="Penghu">Penghu</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThompson1964166_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThompson1964166-74">[59]</a></sup>
Elsewhere, the name was used for the <a href="/wiki/Ryukyu_Islands" title="Ryukyu Islands">Ryukyu Islands</a> in general or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Okinawa" title="Okinawa">Okinawa</a>, the largest of them; indeed the name <i>Ryūkyū</i> is the Japanese form of <i>Liúqiú</i>. The name also appears in the <i><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Sui" title="Book of Sui">Book of Sui</a></i> (636) and other early works, but scholars cannot agree on whether these references are to the Ryukyus, Taiwan or even <a href="/wiki/Luzon" title="Luzon">Luzon</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThompson1964163_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThompson1964163-75">[60]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Name_of_the_country">Name of the country</span></h3>
<p>The official name of the country in English is the "Republic of China"; it has also been known under various names throughout its existence. Shortly after the ROC's establishment in 1912, while it was still located on the Chinese mainland, the government used the short form "China" (<i><span title="Chinese-language text"><i lang="zh-Latn-TW">Zhōngguó</i></span></i> (<span class="nowrap"><span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hant-TW"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%B8%AD%E5%9C%8B" title="wikt:中國">中國</a></span></span></span>)) to refer to itself, which derives from <i><span title="Chinese-language text"><i lang="zh-Latn-pinyin">zhōng</i></span></i> ("central" or "middle") and <i><span title="Chinese-language text"><i lang="zh-Latn-pinyin">guó</i></span></i> ("state, nation-state"),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[n]</a></sup> a term which also developed under the <a href="/wiki/Zhou_dynasty" title="Zhou dynasty">Zhou dynasty</a> in reference to its <a href="/wiki/Demesne" title="Demesne">royal demesne</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[o]</a></sup> and the name was then applied to the area around <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Luoyi" title="Luoyi">Luoyi</a> (present-day Luoyang) during the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Zhou" title="Eastern Zhou">Eastern Zhou</a> and then to China's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Plain_(China)" title="Central Plain (China)">Central Plain</a> before being used as an occasional synonym for the state during the <a href="/wiki/Qing_dynasty" title="Qing dynasty">Qing era</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wilx_77-1"><a href="#cite_note-wilx-77">[62]</a></sup> The name of the Republic had stemmed from the party manifesto of <a href="/wiki/Tongmenghui" title="Tongmenghui">Tongmenghui</a> in 1905, which says the four goals of the Chinese revolution was "to expel the <a href="/wiki/Manchu_people" title="Manchu people">Manchu</a> rulers, to revive <a href="/wiki/Names_of_China#Zhongguo_and_Zhonghua" title="Names of China"><i>Chunghwa</i></a>, to establish a Republic, and to distribute land equally among the people.(<a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">Chinese</a>: <span lang="zh-Hant">驅除韃虜, 恢復中華, 創立民國, 平均地權</span>; <a href="/wiki/Pinyin" title="Pinyin">pinyin</a>: <i><span lang="zh-Latn-pinyin">Qūchú dálǔ, huīfù Zhōnghuá, chuànglì mínguó, píngjūn dì quán</span></i>)." The convener of Tongmenghui and Chinese revolutionary leader <a href="/wiki/Sun_Yat-sen" title="Sun Yat-sen">Sun Yat-sen</a> proposed the name <i>Chunghwa Minkuo</i> as the assumed name of the new country when the revolution succeeded.
</p><p>During the 1950s and 1960s, after the ROC government had withdrawn to Taiwan upon losing the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a>, it was commonly referred to as "Nationalist China" (or "<a href="/wiki/Free_area_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Free area of the Republic of China">Free China</a>") to differentiate it from "Communist China" (or "<a href="/wiki/China" title="China">Red China</a>").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[64]</a></sup> It was a member of the United Nations representing China until 1971, when the ROC <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_2758" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution 2758">lost its seat</a> to the People's Republic of China. Over subsequent decades, the Republic of China has become commonly known as "Taiwan", after the main island. In some contexts, including ROC government publications, the name is written as "Republic of China (Taiwan)", "Republic of China/Taiwan", or sometimes "Taiwan (ROC)".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[65]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[66]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Republic of China participates in most international forums and organizations under the name "<a href="/wiki/Chinese_Taipei" title="Chinese Taipei">Chinese Taipei</a>" as a compromise with the People's Republic of China (PRC). For instance, it is the name under which it has participated in the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Taipei_at_the_1984_Summer_Olympics" title="Chinese Taipei at the 1984 Summer Olympics">Olympic Games</a> as well as the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>. In 2009, after reaching an agreement with Beijing, the ROC participated in the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> for the first time in 38 years, under the name "Chinese Taipei".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WHO2009_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-WHO2009-85">[68]</a></sup> "Taiwan authorities" is sometimes used by the PRC to refer to the current government in Taiwan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PRCNorway_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-PRCNorway-86">[69]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Taiwan" title="History of Taiwan">History of Taiwan</a></div>
<h3><span id="Early_settlement_.28to_1683.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_settlement_(to_1683)">Early settlement (to 1683)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_Taiwan" title="Prehistory of Taiwan">Prehistory of Taiwan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dutch_Formosa" title="Dutch Formosa">Dutch Formosa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Formosa" title="Spanish Formosa">Spanish Formosa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Middag" title="Kingdom of Middag">Kingdom of Middag</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Tungning" title="Kingdom of Tungning">Kingdom of Tungning</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%E4%BE%88%E5%8F%A3%E7%B8%AE%E9%A0%B8%E5%96%AE%E6%8A%8A%E6%8A%98%E8%82%A9%E6%9D%9F%E8%85%B0%E5%9C%88%E8%B6%B3%E7%BD%90%EF%BC%88%E4%BA%BA%E9%9D%A2%E9%99%B6%E7%BD%90%EF%BC%89.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3424" data-file-width="3424" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/%E4%BE%88%E5%8F%A3%E7%B8%AE%E9%A0%B8%E5%96%AE%E6%8A%8A%E6%8A%98%E8%82%A9%E6%9D%9F%E8%85%B0%E5%9C%88%E8%B6%B3%E7%BD%90%EF%BC%88%E4%BA%BA%E9%9D%A2%E9%99%B6%E7%BD%90%EF%BC%89.jpg/220px-%E4%BE%88%E5%8F%A3%E7%B8%AE%E9%A0%B8%E5%96%AE%E6%8A%8A%E6%8A%98%E8%82%A9%E6%9D%9F%E8%85%B0%E5%9C%88%E8%B6%B3%E7%BD%90%EF%BC%88%E4%BA%BA%E9%9D%A2%E9%99%B6%E7%BD%90%EF%BC%89.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/%E4%BE%88%E5%8F%A3%E7%B8%AE%E9%A0%B8%E5%96%AE%E6%8A%8A%E6%8A%98%E8%82%A9%E6%9D%9F%E8%85%B0%E5%9C%88%E8%B6%B3%E7%BD%90%EF%BC%88%E4%BA%BA%E9%9D%A2%E9%99%B6%E7%BD%90%EF%BC%89.jpg/330px-%E4%BE%88%E5%8F%A3%E7%B8%AE%E9%A0%B8%E5%96%AE%E6%8A%8A%E6%8A%98%E8%82%A9%E6%9D%9F%E8%85%B0%E5%9C%88%E8%B6%B3%E7%BD%90%EF%BC%88%E4%BA%BA%E9%9D%A2%E9%99%B6%E7%BD%90%EF%BC%89.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/%E4%BE%88%E5%8F%A3%E7%B8%AE%E9%A0%B8%E5%96%AE%E6%8A%8A%E6%8A%98%E8%82%A9%E6%9D%9F%E8%85%B0%E5%9C%88%E8%B6%B3%E7%BD%90%EF%BC%88%E4%BA%BA%E9%9D%A2%E9%99%B6%E7%BD%90%EF%BC%89.jpg/440px-%E4%BE%88%E5%8F%A3%E7%B8%AE%E9%A0%B8%E5%96%AE%E6%8A%8A%E6%8A%98%E8%82%A9%E6%9D%9F%E8%85%B0%E5%9C%88%E8%B6%B3%E7%BD%90%EF%BC%88%E4%BA%BA%E9%9D%A2%E9%99%B6%E7%BD%90%EF%BC%89.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%E4%BE%88%E5%8F%A3%E7%B8%AE%E9%A0%B8%E5%96%AE%E6%8A%8A%E6%8A%98%E8%82%A9%E6%9D%9F%E8%85%B0%E5%9C%88%E8%B6%B3%E7%BD%90%EF%BC%88%E4%BA%BA%E9%9D%A2%E9%99%B6%E7%BD%90%EF%BC%89.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Anthropomorphic Jar, unearthed at <a href="/wiki/Shihsanhang_Museum_of_Archaeology" title="Shihsanhang Museum of Archaeology">Shihsanhang</a>, is around 500 to 1800 years old</div></div></div>
<p>Taiwan was joined to the Asian mainland in the <a href="/wiki/Late_Pleistocene" title="Late Pleistocene">Late Pleistocene</a>, until sea levels rose about 10,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GillespieGillespie2009_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-GillespieGillespie2009-87">[70]</a></sup> Fragmentary human remains dated 20,000 to 30,000 years ago have been found on the island, as well as later artifacts of a <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a> culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PrasetyoNastiti2021_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-PrasetyoNastiti2021-88">[71]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-palaeolithic_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-palaeolithic-89">[72]</a></sup> These people were similar to the <a href="/wiki/Negrito" title="Negrito">negritos</a> of the Philippines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[73]</a></sup>
</p><p>Around 6,000 years ago, Taiwan was settled by farmers, most likely from what is now southeast China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJiao200791–94_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJiao200791–94-91">[74]</a></sup> 
They are believed to be the ancestors of today's Taiwanese indigenous peoples, whose languages belong to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austronesian_language_family" title="Austronesian language family">Austronesian language family</a>, but show much greater diversity than the <a href="/wiki/Malayo-Polynesian_languages" title="Malayo-Polynesian languages">rest of the family</a>, which spans a huge area from <a href="/wiki/Maritime_Southeast_Asia" title="Maritime Southeast Asia">Maritime Southeast Asia</a> west to <a href="/wiki/Madagascar" title="Madagascar">Madagascar</a> and east as far as New Zealand, Hawaii and <a href="/wiki/Easter_Island" title="Easter Island">Easter Island</a>. This has led linguists to propose Taiwan as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Urheimat" title="Urheimat">urheimat</a> of the family, from which seafaring peoples dispersed across Southeast Asia and the Pacific and Indian Oceans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ref1_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-ref1-92">[75]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[76]</a></sup> Trade links with the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a> subsisted from the early 2nd millennium BC, including the use of <a href="/wiki/Jade" title="Jade">jade</a> from eastern Taiwan in the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_jade_culture" title="Philippine jade culture">Philippine jade culture</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBellwoodHungIizuka201135–37,_41_94-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBellwoodHungIizuka201135–37,_41-94">[77]</a></sup> The raw jade from Taiwan which was further processed in the Philippines was the basis for Taiwanese-Philippine commerce with ancient <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brunei" title="Brunei">Brunei</a>, <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[78]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Han_Chinese" title="Han Chinese">Han Chinese</a> fishermen began settling in the Penghu islands in the 13th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-shep_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-shep-96">[79]</a></sup> In November 1281, the <a href="/wiki/Yuan_dynasty" title="Yuan dynasty">Yuan dynasty</a> under <a href="/wiki/Kublai_Khan" title="Kublai Khan">Emperor Shizu</a> officially established the <i><a href="/wiki/Penghu" title="Penghu">Penghu</a> Patrol and Inspection Agency</i> under the jurisdiction of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tong%27an" title="Tong'an">Tong'an</a> County, incorporating Penghu into China's sovereign domain, 403 years earlier than Taiwan island.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-官網歷史沿革_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-官網歷史沿革-97">[80]</a></sup> Hostile tribes, and a lack of valuable trade products, meant that few outsiders visited the main island until the 16th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-shep_96-1"><a href="#cite_note-shep-96">[79]</a></sup> During the 16th century, visits to the coast by fishermen and traders from Fujian, as well as Chinese and Japanese pirates, became more frequent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-shep_96-2"><a href="#cite_note-shep-96">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 15th century, the <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming</a> ordered the evacuation of the Penghu Islands as part of their <a href="/wiki/Haijin" title="Haijin">maritime ban</a>. When these restrictions were removed in the late 16th century, legal fishing communities, most of which hailing from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tong%27an" title="Tong'an">Tong'an</a> County,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-澎湖縣誌_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-澎湖縣誌-98">[81]</a></sup> were re-established on the Penghu Islands. The Dutch East India Company attempted to establish a trading outpost on the Penghu Islands (Pescadores) in 1622, but was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sino%E2%80%93Dutch_conflicts" title="Sino–Dutch conflicts">driven off by Ming forces</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWills200688_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWills200688-99">[82]</a></sup>
In 1624, the company established a stronghold called Fort Zeelandia on the coastal islet of Tayouan, which is now part of the main island at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anping,_Tainan" title="Anping, Tainan">Anping, Tainan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Oosterhoff_73-1"><a href="#cite_note-Oosterhoff-73">[58]</a></sup>
When the Dutch arrived, they found southwestern Taiwan already frequented by a mostly transient Chinese population numbering close to 1,500.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAndrade2008Chapter_6_Note_5_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAndrade2008Chapter_6_Note_5-100">[83]</a></sup> David Wright, a Scottish agent of the company who lived on the island in the 1650s, described the lowland areas of the island as being divided among 11 <a href="/wiki/Chiefdom" title="Chiefdom">chiefdoms</a> ranging in size from two settlements to 72. Some of these fell under Dutch control, including the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Middag" title="Kingdom of Middag">Kingdom of Middag</a> in the central western plains, while others remained independent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Oosterhoff_73-2"><a href="#cite_note-Oosterhoff-73">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[84]</a></sup> The Company encouraged farmers to immigrate from <a href="/wiki/Fujian" title="Fujian">Fujian</a> and work the lands under Dutch control.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAndrade2008Chapter_6_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAndrade2008Chapter_6-102">[85]</a></sup> By the 1660s, some 30,000 to 50,000 Chinese were living on the island.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWills200698_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWills200698-103">[86]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Atlas_Blaeu-Van_der_Hem_-_Taioan.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1198" data-file-width="1875" decoding="async" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Atlas_Blaeu-Van_der_Hem_-_Taioan.jpg/220px-Atlas_Blaeu-Van_der_Hem_-_Taioan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Atlas_Blaeu-Van_der_Hem_-_Taioan.jpg/330px-Atlas_Blaeu-Van_der_Hem_-_Taioan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Atlas_Blaeu-Van_der_Hem_-_Taioan.jpg/440px-Atlas_Blaeu-Van_der_Hem_-_Taioan.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Atlas_Blaeu-Van_der_Hem_-_Taioan.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Fort_Zeelandia_(Taiwan)" title="Fort Zeelandia (Taiwan)">Fort Zeelandia</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_Formosa" title="Governor of Formosa">Governor</a>'s residence in Dutch Formosa</div></div></div>
<p>In 1626, the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish Empire</a> landed on and occupied northern Taiwan as a trading base, first at <a href="/wiki/Keelung" title="Keelung">Keelung</a> and in 1628 building <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fort_San_Domingo" title="Fort San Domingo">Fort San Domingo</a> at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tamsui" title="Tamsui">Tamsui</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[87]</a></sup> This colony lasted 16 years until 1642, when the last Spanish fortress fell to Dutch forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWills200691_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWills200691-105">[88]</a></sup> The Dutch then marched south, subduing hundreds of villages in the western plains between their new possessions in the north and their base at Tayouan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWills200691_105-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWills200691-105">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the fall of the <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</a> in Beijing in 1644, <a href="/wiki/Koxinga" title="Koxinga">Koxinga</a> (Zheng Chenggong) pledged allegiance to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yongli_Emperor" title="Yongli Emperor">Yongli Emperor</a> of <a href="/wiki/Southern_Ming" title="Southern Ming">Southern Ming</a> and attacked the Qing dynasty along the southeastern coast of China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LuWangNMHTW_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-LuWangNMHTW-106">[89]</a></sup> In 1661, under increasing Qing pressure, he moved his forces from his base in <a href="/wiki/Xiamen" title="Xiamen">Xiamen</a> to Taiwan, <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Fort_Zeelandia" title="Siege of Fort Zeelandia">expelling the Dutch</a> in the following year. Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs and some analysts consider his regime to be loyal to the Ming, while others argue that he acted as an independent ruler and his intentions were unclear.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TWG2020_107-0"><a href="#cite_note-TWG2020-107">[90]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAndrade2008Preface_Note_1_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAndrade2008Preface_Note_1-108">[91]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWills200694–95_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWills200694–95-109">[92]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[93]</a></sup>
</p><p>After being ousted from Taiwan, the Dutch allied with the new Qing dynasty in China against the Zheng regime in Taiwan. Following some skirmishes the Dutch retook the northern fortress at <a href="/wiki/Keelung" title="Keelung">Keelung</a> in 1664.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[94]</a></sup> Zheng Jing sent troops to dislodge the Dutch, but they were unsuccessful. The Dutch held out at Keelung until 1668, when aborigine resistance,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[95]</a></sup> and the lack of progress in retaking any other parts of the island persuaded the colonial authorities to abandon this final stronghold and withdraw from Taiwan altogether.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[96]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Qing_rule_.281683.E2.80.931895.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Qing_rule_(1683–1895)">Qing rule (1683–1895)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_under_Qing_rule" title="Taiwan under Qing rule">Taiwan under Qing rule</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tainan_Taiwan_Fort-Provintia-01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3355" data-file-width="5032" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Tainan_Taiwan_Fort-Provintia-01.jpg/220px-Tainan_Taiwan_Fort-Provintia-01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Tainan_Taiwan_Fort-Provintia-01.jpg/330px-Tainan_Taiwan_Fort-Provintia-01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Tainan_Taiwan_Fort-Provintia-01.jpg/440px-Tainan_Taiwan_Fort-Provintia-01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tainan_Taiwan_Fort-Provintia-01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Fort_Provintia" title="Fort Provintia">Chihkan Tower</a>, originally built as Fort Provintia by the Dutch, was rebuilt under Qing rule</div></div></div>
<p>In 1683, following the defeat of <a href="/wiki/Koxinga" title="Koxinga">Koxinga</a>'s grandson by an armada led by Admiral <a href="/wiki/Shi_Lang" title="Shi Lang">Shi Lang</a>, the Qing dynasty formally annexed Taiwan, making it a prefecture of Fujian province while retaining its administrative seat (now Tainan) under Koxinga as the capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBallantine195215_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBallantine195215-114">[97]</a></sup> The Qing imperial government tried to reduce piracy and vagrancy in the area, issuing a series of edicts to manage immigration and respect aboriginal land rights. Immigrants mostly from southern Fujian continued to enter Taiwan. The border between taxpaying lands and what was considered "savage" lands shifted eastward, with some aborigines becoming <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sinicized" title="Sinicized">sinicized</a> while others retreated into the mountains. During this time, there were a number of conflicts between different ethnic groups of Han Chinese, Quanzhou Minnanese feuding with Zhangzhou and Hakka peasants, and major clan fights between Minnans (Hoklos), Hakkas and aborigines too.
</p><p>There were more than a hundred rebellions, riots, and instances of civil strife during the Qing administration, including the <a href="/wiki/Lin_Shuangwen_rebellion" title="Lin Shuangwen rebellion">Lin Shuangwen rebellion</a> (1786–1788). Their frequency was evoked by the common saying "every three years an uprising, every five years a rebellion" (三年一反、五年一亂), primarily in reference to the period between 1820 and 1850.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[98]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[99]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RebellionTWCulture_117-0"><a href="#cite_note-RebellionTWCulture-117">[100]</a></sup> These conditions notwithstanding, the production of sugar became profitable on the island and, together with rice, provided surpluses for export to the mainland. Meanwhile, a rapidly increasing population settled the western coastal areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBallantine195216_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBallantine195216-118">[101]</a></sup>
</p><p>Northern Taiwan and the <a href="/wiki/Penghu" title="Penghu">Penghu</a> Islands were the scene of subsidiary campaigns in the <a href="/wiki/Sino-French_War" title="Sino-French War">Sino-French War</a> (August 1884 to April 1885). The French occupied Keelung on 1 October 1884, but were <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Tamsui" title="Battle of Tamsui">repulsed from Tamsui</a> a few days later. The French won some tactical victories but were unable to exploit them, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Keelung_Campaign" title="Keelung Campaign">Keelung Campaign</a> ended in stalemate. The <a href="/wiki/Pescadores_campaign_(1885)" title="Pescadores campaign (1885)">Pescadores Campaign</a>, beginning on 31 March 1885, was a French victory, but had no long-term consequences. The French evacuated both Keelung and the Penghu archipelago after the end of the war.
</p><p>In 1887, the Qing upgraded the island's administration from being the Taiwan Prefecture of Fujian Province to <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Province#History" title="Taiwan Province">Fujian-Taiwan-Province</a>, the twentieth in the empire, with its capital at <a href="/wiki/Taipei" title="Taipei">Taipei</a>. This was accompanied by a modernization drive that included a telegraph line between Tainan and Taipei and the building of China's first railway.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBallantine195215_114-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBallantine195215-114">[97]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDavidson1903247,_620_119-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDavidson1903247,_620-119">[102]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Japanese_rule_.281895.E2.80.931945.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Japanese_rule_(1895–1945)">Japanese rule (1895–1945)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_under_Japanese_rule" title="Taiwan under Japanese rule">Taiwan under Japanese rule</a></div>
<p>Following the Qing defeat in the <a href="/wiki/First_Sino-Japanese_War" title="First Sino-Japanese War">First Sino-Japanese War</a> (1894–1895), Taiwan, its associated islands, and the Penghu archipelago were ceded to the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Empire of Japan</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Shimonoseki" title="Treaty of Shimonoseki">Treaty of Shimonoseki</a>, along with other concessions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ShimonosekiROC_120-0"><a href="#cite_note-ShimonosekiROC-120">[103]</a></sup> Inhabitants on Taiwan and Penghu wishing to remain Qing subjects were given a two-year grace period to sell their property and move to mainland China. Very few Formosans saw this as feasible.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[104]</a></sup> On 25 May 1895, a group of pro-Qing high officials proclaimed the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Formosa" title="Republic of Formosa">Republic of Formosa</a> to resist impending Japanese rule. Japanese forces entered the capital at Tainan and quelled this resistance on 21 October 1895.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[105]</a></sup> Guerrilla fighting continued periodically until about 1902 and ultimately took the lives of 14,000 Taiwanese, or 0.5 per cent of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-msu_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-msu-123">[106]</a></sup> Several subsequent rebellions against the Japanese (the <a href="/wiki/Beipu_uprising" title="Beipu uprising">Beipu uprising</a> of 1907, the <a href="/wiki/Tapani_incident" title="Tapani incident">Tapani incident</a> of 1915, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wushe_incident" title="Wushe incident">Musha incident</a> of 1930) were all unsuccessful but demonstrated opposition to Japanese colonial rule.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Taiwan_Seito_Wanli_Factory_1930s.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1170" data-file-width="2044" decoding="async" height="126" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Taiwan_Seito_Wanli_Factory_1930s.jpg/220px-Taiwan_Seito_Wanli_Factory_1930s.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Taiwan_Seito_Wanli_Factory_1930s.jpg/330px-Taiwan_Seito_Wanli_Factory_1930s.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Taiwan_Seito_Wanli_Factory_1930s.jpg/440px-Taiwan_Seito_Wanli_Factory_1930s.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Taiwan_Seito_Wanli_Factory_1930s.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A sugarcane mill and <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Sugar_Railways" title="Taiwan Sugar Railways">its railways</a> in Tainan in 1930s</div></div></div>
<p>The colonial period was instrumental to the industrialization of the island, with its expansion of railways and other transport networks, the building of an extensive sanitation system, the establishment of a formal <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Taiwan" title="Education in Taiwan">education system</a>, and an end to the practice of <a href="/wiki/Headhunting" title="Headhunting">headhunting</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[107]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[108]</a></sup> During this period, the human and natural resources of Taiwan were used to aid the development of Japan. The production of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cash_crops" title="Cash crops">cash crops</a> such as sugar greatly increased, especially since sugar cane was salable only to a few Japanese sugar mills, and large areas were therefore diverted from the production of rice, which the Formosans could market or consume themselves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBallantine195239_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBallantine195239-126">[109]</a></sup> By 1939, Taiwan was the seventh-greatest sugar producer in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[110]</a></sup>
</p><p>Still, the Hans and the aborigines were classified as second- and third-class citizens. Many prestigious government and business positions were closed to them, leaving few natives capable of taking on leadership and management roles decades later when Japan relinquished the island.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBallantine195248_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBallantine195248-128">[111]</a></sup> After suppressing Chinese guerrillas in the first decade of their rule, Japanese authorities engaged in a series of bloody campaigns against the mountain aborigines, culminating in the Musha Incident of 1930.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[112]</a></sup> Intellectuals and labourers who participated in left-wing movements within Taiwan were also arrested and massacred (e.g. <a href="/wiki/Chiang_Wei-shui" title="Chiang Wei-shui">Chiang Wei-shui</a> and <a href="/wiki/Masanosuke_Watanabe" title="Masanosuke Watanabe">Masanosuke Watanabe</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[113]</a></sup> Around 1935, the Japanese began an island-wide <a href="/wiki/Japanization" title="Japanization">assimilation project</a> to bind the island more firmly to the Japanese Empire. People were taught to see themselves as Japanese under the Kominka Movement, during which Taiwanese culture and religion were outlawed, and the citizens were encouraged to adopt <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japanese_surname" title="Japanese surname">Japanese surnames</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[114]</a></sup> By 1938, 309,000 <a href="/wiki/Japanese_people" title="Japanese people">Japanese settlers</a> were residing in Taiwan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[115]</a></sup>
</p><p>Burdened by Japan's upcoming war effort, the island was developed into a naval and air base while its agriculture, industry, and commerce suffered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBallantine1952110_133-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBallantine1952110-133">[116]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBallantine195247_134-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBallantine195247-134">[117]</a></sup> Initial air attacks and the subsequent invasion of the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a> were launched from Taiwan. The <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Navy" title="Imperial Japanese Navy">Imperial Japanese Navy</a> operated heavily from Taiwanese ports, and its think tank "<a href="/wiki/Nanshin-ron#Theoretical_development" title="Nanshin-ron">South Strike Group</a>" was based at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taihoku_Imperial_University" title="Taihoku Imperial University">Taihoku Imperial University</a> in Taipei. Military bases and industrial centres, such as <a href="/wiki/Kaohsiung" title="Kaohsiung">Kaohsiung</a> and <a href="/wiki/Keelung" title="Keelung">Keelung</a>, became targets of heavy <a href="/wiki/Raid_on_Taipei" title="Raid on Taipei">Allied bombings</a>, which also destroyed many of the factories, dams, and transport facilities built by the Japanese.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[118]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBallantine195247_134-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBallantine195247-134">[117]</a></sup> In October 1944, the <a href="/wiki/Formosa_Air_Battle" title="Formosa Air Battle">Formosa Air Battle</a> was fought between American carriers and Japanese forces in Taiwan.
</p><p>During the course of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, tens of thousands of Taiwanese served in the Japanese military.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[119]</a></sup> In 1944, Lee Teng-hui, who would become Taiwan's president later in life, volunteered for service in the <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Army" title="Imperial Japanese Army">Imperial Japanese Army</a> and became a <a href="/wiki/Second_lieutenant" title="Second lieutenant">second lieutenant</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[120]</a></sup> His elder brother, Lee Teng-chin (李登欽), also volunteered for the <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Navy" title="Imperial Japanese Navy">Imperial Japanese Navy</a> and died in <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Manila_(1945)" title="Battle of Manila (1945)">Manila</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pdo201011030c_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-pdo201011030c-138">[121]</a></sup> In addition, over 2,000 women, euphemistically called "<a href="/wiki/Comfort_women" title="Comfort women">comfort women</a>", were forced into sexual slavery for Imperial Japanese troops.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[122]</a></sup>
</p><p>After <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japan%27s_surrender" title="Japan's surrender">Japan's surrender</a> in WWII, most of Taiwan's approximately 300,000 Japanese residents were <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_evacuation_and_expulsion" title="World War II evacuation and expulsion">expelled and sent to Japan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[123]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Republic_of_China_.281945.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Republic_of_China_(1945–present)">Republic of China (1945–present)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)" title="Republic of China (1912–1949)">Republic of China (1912–1949)</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Taiwan_(1945%E2%80%93present)" title="History of Taiwan (1945–present)">History of Taiwan (1945–present)</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="History of the Republic of China">History of the Republic of China</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ando_Rikichi_surrender.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="401" data-file-width="638" decoding="async" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Ando_Rikichi_surrender.jpg/220px-Ando_Rikichi_surrender.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Ando_Rikichi_surrender.jpg/330px-Ando_Rikichi_surrender.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Ando_Rikichi_surrender.jpg/440px-Ando_Rikichi_surrender.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ando_Rikichi_surrender.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>General <a href="/wiki/Chen_Yi_(Kuomintang)" title="Chen Yi (Kuomintang)">Chen Yi</a> (right) accepting the receipt of <a href="/wiki/General_Order_No._1" title="General Order No. 1">General Order No. 1</a> from <a href="/wiki/Rikichi_And%C5%8D" title="Rikichi Andō">Rikichi Andō</a> (left), the last Japanese Governor-General of Taiwan, in <a href="/wiki/Zhongshan_Hall" title="Zhongshan Hall">Taipei City Hall</a></div></div></div>
<p>While Taiwan was still under Japanese rule, the Republic of China was founded on the mainland on 1 January 1912, following the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Xinhai_Revolution" title="Xinhai Revolution">Xinhai Revolution</a>, which began with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wuchang_uprising" title="Wuchang uprising">Wuchang uprising</a> on 10 October 1911, replacing the Qing dynasty and ending over two thousand years of <a href="/wiki/Dynasties_in_Chinese_history" title="Dynasties in Chinese history">imperial rule</a> in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cuhk_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-cuhk-141">[124]</a></sup> From its founding until 1949 it was based in mainland China. Central authority waxed and waned in response to <a href="/wiki/Warlord_Era" title="Warlord Era">warlordism</a> (1915–28), <a href="/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War" title="Second Sino-Japanese War">Japanese invasion</a> (1937–45), and the Chinese Civil War (1927–50), with central authority strongest during the <a href="/wiki/Nanjing_decade" title="Nanjing decade">Nanjing decade</a> (1927–37), when most of China came under the control of the <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang" title="Kuomintang">Kuomintang</a> (KMT) under an <a href="/wiki/Authoritarianism" title="Authoritarianism">authoritarian</a> <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">one-party state</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[125]</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 1945 following <a href="/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan" title="Surrender of Japan">Japan's surrender in WWII</a>, ROC forces, assisted by small American teams, prepared an amphibious lift into Taiwan to accept the surrender of the Japanese military forces there, under <a href="/wiki/General_Order_No._1" title="General Order No. 1">General Order No. 1</a>, and take over the administration of Taiwan.<sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBallantine195257:_"Chinese_forces_were_prepared_to_move_with_American_aid_by_an_amphibious_lift_into_Formosa&lt;span_class="nowrap"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;..._In_September_1945_the_administration_of_Formosa_was_taken_over_from_the_Japanese_by_Chinese_forces_assisted_by_numerically_small_United_States_teams"_143-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBallantine195257:_"Chinese_forces_were_prepared_to_move_with_American_aid_by_an_amphibious_lift_into_Formosa&lt;span_class="nowrap"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;..._In_September_1945_the_administration_of_Formosa_was_taken_over_from_the_Japanese_by_Chinese_forces_assisted_by_numerically_small_United_States_teams"-143'>[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[127]</a></sup> On 25 October, General <a href="/wiki/Rikichi_And%C5%8D" title="Rikichi Andō">Rikichi Andō</a>, governor-general of Taiwan and commander-in-chief of all Japanese forces on the island, signed the receipt and handed it over to ROC General <a href="/wiki/Chen_Yi_(Kuomintang)" title="Chen Yi (Kuomintang)">Chen Yi</a> to complete the official turnover. Chen proclaimed that day to be "<a href="/wiki/Retrocession_Day" title="Retrocession Day">Taiwan Retrocession Day</a>", but the Allies, having entrusted Taiwan and the Penghu Islands to Chinese administration and military occupation, nonetheless considered them to be under Japanese sovereignty until 1952 when the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_San_Francisco" title="Treaty of San Francisco">Treaty of San Francisco</a> took effect.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[128]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[129]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/1943_Cairo_Declaration" title="1943 Cairo Declaration">1943 Cairo Declaration</a>, US, UK, and ROC representatives specified territories such as Formosa and the Pescadores to be restored by Japan to the Republic of China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cairo1943_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cairo1943-147">[130]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBallantine1952162:_"United_States_Government_replied_on_this_point_as_follows:&lt;span_class="nowrap"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;..._Cairo_Declaration_provided_that_Manchuria,_Formosa,_and_the_Pescadores,_shall_be_restored_to_the_Republic_of_China"_148-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBallantine1952162:_"United_States_Government_replied_on_this_point_as_follows:&lt;span_class="nowrap"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;..._Cairo_Declaration_provided_that_Manchuria,_Formosa,_and_the_Pescadores,_shall_be_restored_to_the_Republic_of_China"-148'>[131]</a></sup> Its terms were later referred to in the <a href="/wiki/Potsdam_Declaration" title="Potsdam Declaration">1945 Potsdam Declaration</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Potsdam1945_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-Potsdam1945-149">[132]</a></sup> whose provisions Japan agreed to carry out in its <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Instrument_of_Surrender" title="Japanese Instrument of Surrender">instrument of surrender</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JapanSurrender_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-JapanSurrender-150">[133]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBallantine195258_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBallantine195258-151">[134]</a></sup> Due to disagreements over which government (PRC or ROC) to invite, China did not attend the eventual signing of the Treaty of San Francisco, whereby Japan renounced all titles and claims to Formosa and the Pescadores without specifying to whom they were surrendered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SanFrancisco1951_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-SanFrancisco1951-152">[135]</a></sup> In 1952, Japan and the ROC signed the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Taipei" title="Treaty of Taipei">Treaty of Taipei</a>, recognizing that all treaties concluded before 9 December 1941 between China and Japan have become null and void.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Taipei1952_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-Taipei1952-153">[136]</a></sup> Interpretations of these documents and their legal implications give rise to the debate over the <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Taiwan" title="Political status of Taiwan">sovereignty status of Taiwan</a>.
</p><p>While initially enthusiastic about the return of Chinese administration and the <a href="/wiki/Three_Principles_of_the_People" title="Three Principles of the People">Three Principles of the People</a>, Formosans grew increasingly dissatisfied about being excluded from higher positions, the postponement of local elections even after the enactment of a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ROC_Constitution" title="ROC Constitution">constitution</a> on the mainland, the smuggling of valuables off the island, the expropriation of businesses into government operated monopolies, and the <a href="/wiki/Hyperinflation" title="Hyperinflation">hyperinflation</a> of 1945–1949.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMakinenWoodward1989_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMakinenWoodward1989-154">[137]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[138]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBallantine195259_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBallantine195259-156">[139]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_States1949923-925_157-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_States1949923-925-157">[140]</a></sup> The shooting of a civilian on 28 February 1947 triggered island-wide unrest, which was suppressed by Chen with military force in what is now called the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/February_28_Incident" title="February 28 Incident">February 28 Incident</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[141]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[142]</a></sup> Mainstream estimates of the number killed range from 18,000 to 30,000. Many native leaders were killed, as well as students and some mainlanders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBallantine195263_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBallantine195263-160">[143]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_States1949932_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_States1949932-161">[144]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[145]</a></sup> Chen was later relieved and replaced by <a href="/wiki/Wei_Tao-ming" title="Wei Tao-ming">Wei Tao-ming</a>, who made an effort to undo previous mismanagement by re-appointing a good proportion of islanders and re-privatizing businesses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBallantine195264-65_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBallantine195264-65-163">[146]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Movement_KMTretreat.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="738" data-file-width="889" decoding="async" height="183" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Movement_KMTretreat.svg/220px-Movement_KMTretreat.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Movement_KMTretreat.svg/330px-Movement_KMTretreat.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Movement_KMTretreat.svg/440px-Movement_KMTretreat.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Movement_KMTretreat.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Nationalists' retreat to Taipei</div></div></div>
<p>After the end of World War II, the Chinese Civil War resumed between the Chinese Nationalists (Kuomintang), led by Generalissimo <a href="/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek" title="Chiang Kai-shek">Chiang Kai-shek</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chinese Communist Party">Chinese Communist Party</a> (CCP), led by <a href="/wiki/Chairman_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chairman of the Chinese Communist Party">CCP Chairman</a> <a href="/wiki/Mao_Zedong" title="Mao Zedong">Mao Zedong</a>. Throughout the months of 1949, a series of Chinese Communist offensives led to the capture of its capital <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">Nanjing</a> on 23 April and the subsequent defeat of the Nationalist army on the mainland, and the Communists <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Proclamation of the People's Republic of China">founded the People's Republic of China</a> on 1 October.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[147]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 7 December 1949, after the loss of four capitals, Chiang <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Retreat_of_the_Republic_of_China_to_Taiwan" title="Retreat of the Republic of China to Taiwan">evacuated his Nationalist government to Taiwan</a> and made Taipei the <a href="/wiki/Temporary_capital" title="Temporary capital">temporary capital</a> of the ROC (also called the "wartime capital" by Chiang Kai-shek).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wartime-capital_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-wartime-capital-165">[148]</a></sup> Some 2 million people, consisting mainly of soldiers, members of the ruling Kuomintang and intellectual and business elites, were evacuated from mainland China to Taiwan at that time, adding to the earlier population of approximately six million. These people came to be known in Taiwan as "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Waisheng_ren" title="Waisheng ren">waisheng ren</a>" (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">外省人</span></span>), residents who came to the island in the 1940s and 50s after Japan's surrender, as well as their descendants. In addition, the ROC government took to Taipei many national treasures and much of China's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gold_reserves" title="Gold reserves">gold</a> and foreign currency reserves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbctimeline-retreat_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbctimeline-retreat-166">[149]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[150]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p>After losing control of mainland China in 1949, the ROC retained control of Taiwan and Penghu (<a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Province" title="Taiwan Province">Taiwan, ROC</a>), parts of Fujian (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fujian_Province,_Republic_of_China" title="Fujian Province, Republic of China">Fujian, ROC</a>)—specifically Kinmen, <a href="/wiki/Wuqiu,_Kinmen" title="Wuqiu, Kinmen">Wuqiu</a> (now part of Kinmen) and the Matsu Islands and two major <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea_Islands" title="South China Sea Islands">islands in the South China Sea</a> (within the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pratas_Islands" title="Pratas Islands">Dongsha</a>/Pratas and <a href="/wiki/Spratly_Islands" title="Spratly Islands">Nansha</a>/Spratly island groups). These territories have remained under ROC governance until the present day. The ROC also briefly retained control of the entirety of <a href="/wiki/Hainan" title="Hainan">Hainan</a> (an island province), parts of <a href="/wiki/Zhejiang" title="Zhejiang">Zhejiang</a> (<a href="/wiki/Chekiang_Province,_Republic_of_China" title="Chekiang Province, Republic of China">Chekiang</a>)—specifically the <a href="/wiki/Dachen_Islands" title="Dachen Islands">Dachen Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yijiangshan_Islands" title="Yijiangshan Islands">Yijiangshan Islands</a>—and portions of <a href="/wiki/Tibet_(1912%E2%80%931951)" title="Tibet (1912–1951)">Tibet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Qinghai" title="Qinghai">Qinghai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Xinjiang_Province,_Republic_of_China" title="Xinjiang Province, Republic of China">Sinkiang</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yunnan" title="Yunnan">Yunnan</a>. The Communists <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Hainan_Island" title="Battle of Hainan Island">captured Hainan</a> in 1950, captured the Dachen Islands and Yijiangshan Islands during the <a href="/wiki/First_Taiwan_Strait_Crisis" title="First Taiwan Strait Crisis">First Taiwan Strait Crisis</a> in 1955 and defeated the <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang_Islamic_insurgency" title="Kuomintang Islamic insurgency">ROC revolts in Northwest China</a> in 1958. ROC forces in Yunnan province entered Burma and Thailand in the 1950s and <a href="/wiki/1960%E2%80%9361_campaign_at_the_China%E2%80%93Burma_border" title="1960–61 campaign at the China–Burma border">were defeated by Communists in 1961</a>. Ever since losing control of mainland China, the Kuomintang continued to claim sovereignty over 'all of China', which it defined to include mainland China (including Tibet), Taiwan (including Penghu), <a href="/wiki/Outer_Mongolia" title="Outer Mongolia">Outer Mongolia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Taiwan" title="Administrative divisions of Taiwan">other minor territories</a>.
</p>
<h4><span id="Martial_law_era_.281949.E2.80.931987.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Martial_law_era_(1949–1987)">Martial law era (1949–1987)</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Martial_law_in_Taiwan" title="Martial law in Taiwan">Martial law in Taiwan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Miracle" title="Taiwan Miracle">Taiwan Miracle</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chiang_Kai-shek_in_full_uniform.jpeg"><img alt="A Chinese man in military uniform, smiling and looking towards the left. He holds a sword in his left hand and has a medal in shape of a sun on his chest." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="646" data-file-width="469" decoding="async" height="234" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Chiang_Kai-shek_in_full_uniform.jpeg/170px-Chiang_Kai-shek_in_full_uniform.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Chiang_Kai-shek_in_full_uniform.jpeg/255px-Chiang_Kai-shek_in_full_uniform.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Chiang_Kai-shek_in_full_uniform.jpeg/340px-Chiang_Kai-shek_in_full_uniform.jpeg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chiang_Kai-shek_in_full_uniform.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek" title="Chiang Kai-shek">Chiang Kai-shek</a>, leader of the <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang" title="Kuomintang">Kuomintang</a> from 1925 until his death in 1975</div></div></div>
<p>Martial law, declared on Taiwan in May 1949,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-martial_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-martial-169">[152]</a></sup> continued to be in effect after the central government relocated to Taiwan. It was also used as a way to suppress the political opposition and was not repealed until 38 years later in 1987.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-martial_169-1"><a href="#cite_note-martial-169">[152]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[153]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/White_Terror_(Taiwan)" title="White Terror (Taiwan)">White Terror</a>, as the period is known, 140,000 people were imprisoned or executed for being perceived as anti-KMT or pro-Communist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[154]</a></sup> Many citizens were arrested, tortured, imprisoned and executed for their real or perceived link to the Chinese Communist Party. Since these people were mainly from the intellectual and social elite, an entire generation of political and social leaders was decimated. In 1998, a law was passed to create the "Compensation Foundation for Improper Verdicts" which oversaw compensation to White Terror victims and families. President <a href="/wiki/Ma_Ying-jeou" title="Ma Ying-jeou">Ma Ying-jeou</a> made an official apology in 2008, expressing hope that there would never be a tragedy similar to White Terror.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[155]</a></sup>
</p><p>Due to the eruption of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Korean_war" title="Korean war">Korean war</a>, and in the context of the Cold War, US President <a href="/wiki/Harry_S._Truman" title="Harry S. Truman">Harry S. Truman</a> decided to intervene again and dispatched the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Seventh_Fleet" title="United States Seventh Fleet">United States Seventh Fleet</a> into the <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Strait" title="Taiwan Strait">Taiwan Strait</a> to prevent hostilities between Taiwan and mainland China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1950-US-DoD_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-1950-US-DoD-173">[156]</a></sup> Continuing fierce combat between both sides of the Chinese Civil War through the 1950s, and intervention by the United States notably resulted in legislation such as the <a href="/wiki/Sino-American_Mutual_Defense_Treaty" title="Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty">Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Formosa_Resolution_of_1955" title="Formosa Resolution of 1955">Formosa Resolution of 1955</a>. By virtue of aforementioned pacts, the KMT regime received substantial <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foreign_aid" title="Foreign aid">foreign aid</a> from the US between 1951 and 1965.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[157]</a></sup>  In the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_San_Francisco" title="Treaty of San Francisco">Treaty of San Francisco</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Taipei" title="Treaty of Taipei">Treaty of Taipei</a>, which came into force respectively on 28 April 1952 and 5 August 1952, Japan formally renounced all right, claim and title to Taiwan and Penghu, and renounced all treaties signed with China before 1942. Neither treaty specified to whom sovereignty over the islands should be transferred, because the United States and the United Kingdom disagreed on whether the ROC or the PRC was the legitimate government of China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[158]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:U.S._President_Eisenhower_visited_TAIWAN_%E7%BE%8E%E5%9C%8B%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%89%BE%E6%A3%AE%E8%B1%AA%E6%96%BC1960%E5%B9%B46%E6%9C%88%E8%A8%AA%E5%95%8F%E8%87%BA%E7%81%A3%E5%8F%B0%E5%8C%97%E6%99%82%E8%88%87%E8%94%A3%E4%B8%AD%E6%AD%A3%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1-2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="689" data-file-width="1102" decoding="async" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/U.S._President_Eisenhower_visited_TAIWAN_%E7%BE%8E%E5%9C%8B%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%89%BE%E6%A3%AE%E8%B1%AA%E6%96%BC1960%E5%B9%B46%E6%9C%88%E8%A8%AA%E5%95%8F%E8%87%BA%E7%81%A3%E5%8F%B0%E5%8C%97%E6%99%82%E8%88%87%E8%94%A3%E4%B8%AD%E6%AD%A3%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1-2.jpg/220px-U.S._President_Eisenhower_visited_TAIWAN_%E7%BE%8E%E5%9C%8B%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%89%BE%E6%A3%AE%E8%B1%AA%E6%96%BC1960%E5%B9%B46%E6%9C%88%E8%A8%AA%E5%95%8F%E8%87%BA%E7%81%A3%E5%8F%B0%E5%8C%97%E6%99%82%E8%88%87%E8%94%A3%E4%B8%AD%E6%AD%A3%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1-2.jpg"
