srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/U.S._President_Eisenhower_visited_TAIWAN_%E7%BE%8E%E5%9C%8B%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%89%BE%E6%A3%AE%E8%B1%AA%E6%96%BC1960%E5%B9%B46%E6%9C%88%E8%A8%AA%E5%95%8F%E8%87%BA%E7%81%A3%E5%8F%B0%E5%8C%97%E6%99%82%E8%88%87%E8%94%A3%E4%B8%AD%E6%AD%A3%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1-2.jpg/330px-U.S._President_Eisenhower_visited_TAIWAN_%E7%BE%8E%E5%9C%8B%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%89%BE%E6%A3%AE%E8%B1%AA%E6%96%BC1960%E5%B9%B46%E6%9C%88%E8%A8%AA%E5%95%8F%E8%87%BA%E7%81%A3%E5%8F%B0%E5%8C%97%E6%99%82%E8%88%87%E8%94%A3%E4%B8%AD%E6%AD%A3%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/U.S._President_Eisenhower_visited_TAIWAN_%E7%BE%8E%E5%9C%8B%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%89%BE%E6%A3%AE%E8%B1%AA%E6%96%BC1960%E5%B9%B46%E6%9C%88%E8%A8%AA%E5%95%8F%E8%87%BA%E7%81%A3%E5%8F%B0%E5%8C%97%E6%99%82%E8%88%87%E8%94%A3%E4%B8%AD%E6%AD%A3%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1-2.jpg/440px-U.S._President_Eisenhower_visited_TAIWAN_%E7%BE%8E%E5%9C%8B%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%89%BE%E6%A3%AE%E8%B1%AA%E6%96%BC1960%E5%B9%B46%E6%9C%88%E8%A8%AA%E5%95%8F%E8%87%BA%E7%81%A3%E5%8F%B0%E5%8C%97%E6%99%82%E8%88%87%E8%94%A3%E4%B8%AD%E6%AD%A3%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1-2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:U.S._President_Eisenhower_visited_TAIWAN_%E7%BE%8E%E5%9C%8B%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%89%BE%E6%A3%AE%E8%B1%AA%E6%96%BC1960%E5%B9%B46%E6%9C%88%E8%A8%AA%E5%95%8F%E8%87%BA%E7%81%A3%E5%8F%B0%E5%8C%97%E6%99%82%E8%88%87%E8%94%A3%E4%B8%AD%E6%AD%A3%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1-2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>With Chiang Kai-shek, US president <a href="/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower" title="Dwight D. Eisenhower">Dwight D. Eisenhower</a> waved to crowds during his visit to Taipei in June 1960.</div></div></div>
<p>As the Chinese Civil War continued without truce, the government built up military fortifications throughout Taiwan. Within this effort, KMT veterans built the now famous <a href="/wiki/Central_Cross-Island_Highway" title="Central Cross-Island Highway">Central Cross-Island Highway</a> through the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taroko_Gorge" title="Taroko Gorge">Taroko Gorge</a> in the 1950s. The two sides would continue to engage in sporadic military clashes with seldom publicized details well into the 1960s on the China coastal islands with an unknown number of <a href="/wiki/Project_National_Glory" title="Project National Glory">night raids</a>. During the <a href="/wiki/Second_Taiwan_Strait_Crisis" title="Second Taiwan Strait Crisis">Second Taiwan Strait Crisis</a> in September 1958, Taiwan's landscape saw <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nike-Hercules_missile" title="Nike-Hercules missile">Nike-Hercules missile</a> batteries added, with the formation of the 1st Missile Battalion Chinese Army that would not be deactivated until 1997. Newer generations of missile batteries have since replaced the Nike Hercules systems throughout the island.
</p><p>During the 1960s and 1970s, the ROC maintained an authoritarian, single-party government while its economy became industrialized and technology-oriented.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbctimeline-coldwar_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbctimeline-coldwar-176">[159]</a></sup> This rapid economic growth, known as the <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Miracle" title="Taiwan Miracle">Taiwan Miracle</a>, occurred following a strategy of prioritizing agriculture, light industries, and heavy industries in that order.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHsü1982173_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHsü1982173-177">[160]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ten_Major_Construction_Projects" title="Ten Major Construction Projects">Infrastructure projects</a> such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sun_Yat-sen_Freeway" title="Sun Yat-sen Freeway">Sun Yat-sen Freeway</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taoyuan_International_Airport" title="Taoyuan International Airport">Taoyuan International Airport</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taichung_Harbor" title="Taichung Harbor">Taichung Harbor</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jinshan_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Jinshan Nuclear Power Plant">Jinshan Nuclear Power Plant</a> were launched, while the rise of steel, petrochemical, and shipbuilding industries in southern Taiwan saw the transformation of Kaohsiung into a special municipality on par with Taipei.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHsü1982174_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHsü1982174-178">[161]</a></sup> In the 1970s, Taiwan became the second fastest growing economy in Asia after Japan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[162]</a></sup> In 1978, the combination of tax incentives and a cheap, well-trained labor force attracted investments of over $1.9 billion from <a href="/wiki/Overseas_Chinese" title="Overseas Chinese">overseas Chinese</a>, the United States, and Japan, especially in the manufacturing of electrical and electronic products.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHsü1982175,_176_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHsü1982175,_176-180">[163]</a></sup> By 1980, foreign trade reached $39 billion per year and generated a surplus of $46.5 million, while the income ratio of the highest to the lowest 20 percent of wage earners dropped from 15:1 to 4:1 between 1952 and 1978, less than even that of the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHsü1982173_177-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHsü1982173-177">[160]</a></sup> Along with Hong Kong, Singapore, and South Korea, Taiwan became known as one of the <a href="/wiki/Four_Asian_Tigers" title="Four Asian Tigers">Four Asian Tigers</a>.
</p><p>Because of the Cold War, most Western nations and the United Nations regarded the ROC as the sole legitimate government of China until the 1970s. Eventually, especially after the termination of the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty, most nations switched <a href="/wiki/Diplomatic_recognition" title="Diplomatic recognition">diplomatic recognition</a> to the PRC (see United Nations General Assembly Resolution 2758). Until the 1970s, the ROC government was regarded by Western critics as undemocratic for upholding <a href="/wiki/Martial_law" title="Martial law">martial law</a>, severely repressing any political opposition, and controlling the media. The KMT did not allow the creation of new parties and those that existed did not seriously compete with the KMT. Thus, competitive democratic elections did not exist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[164]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[165]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFung200067_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFung200067-183">[166]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFung200085_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFung200085-184">[167]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[168]</a></sup> From the late 1970s to the 1990s, however, Taiwan went through reforms and social changes that transformed it from an authoritarian state to a democracy. In 1979, a pro-democracy protest known as the <a href="/wiki/Kaohsiung_Incident" title="Kaohsiung Incident">Kaohsiung Incident</a> took place in <a href="/wiki/Kaohsiung" title="Kaohsiung">Kaohsiung</a> to celebrate <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Day" title="Human Rights Day">Human Rights Day</a>. Although the protest was rapidly crushed by the authorities, it is today considered as the main event that united Taiwan's opposition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[169]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Chiang_Ching-kuo" title="Chiang Ching-kuo">Chiang Ching-kuo</a>, Chiang Kai-shek's son and successor as the ROC president and chairman of the KMT, began <a href="/wiki/History_of_Taiwan#Democratic_reforms" title="History of Taiwan">reforms</a> to the political system in the mid-1980s. He sought to move more authority to "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bensheng_ren" title="Bensheng ren">bensheng ren</a>" (residents of Taiwan before Japan's surrender in World War II and their descendants) instead of continuing to promote "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Waisheng_ren" title="Waisheng ren">waisheng ren</a>" (residents who came to the island in the 1940s and 50s after Japan's surrender and their descendants) as his father had.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kagan_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kagan-187">[170]</a></sup> In 1984, the younger Chiang selected <a href="/wiki/Lee_Teng-hui" title="Lee Teng-hui">Lee Teng-hui</a>, a Taiwan-born, US-educated technocrat, to be his vice-president. In 1986, the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Progressive_Party" title="Democratic Progressive Party">Democratic Progressive Party</a> (DPP) was formed and inaugurated as the first opposition party in the ROC to counter the KMT. A year later, Chiang Ching-kuo lifted martial law on the main island of Taiwan (martial law was lifted on Penghu in 1979, Matsu island in 1992 and Kinmen island in 1993). With the KMT lifting martial law, moving toward democracy, and choosing the native Taiwanese Lee Teng-hui to lead the country, the opposition DPP groped for a message; it would go on to lose the first direct presidential election in 1996.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EckholmNYT2000_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-EckholmNYT2000-188">[171]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Transition_to_democracy_.281987.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Transition_to_democracy_(1987–present)">Transition to democracy (1987–present)</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Politics of the Republic of China">Politics of the Republic of China</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:President_Lee_teng_hui.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="725" data-file-width="500" decoding="async" height="247" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/President_Lee_teng_hui.png/170px-President_Lee_teng_hui.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/President_Lee_teng_hui.png/255px-President_Lee_teng_hui.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/President_Lee_teng_hui.png/340px-President_Lee_teng_hui.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:President_Lee_teng_hui.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>In 1988, <a href="/wiki/Lee_Teng-hui" title="Lee Teng-hui">Lee Teng-hui</a> became the first president of the Republic of China born in Taiwan and was the first to be directly elected in 1996.</div></div></div>
<p>After the death of Chiang Ching-kuo in January 1988, Lee Teng-hui succeeded him and became the first president born in Taiwan. Lee continued the democratic reforms to the government and replaced many "waisheng ren" in government positions with "bensheng ren". Under Lee, Taiwan underwent a process of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taiwanese_localization_movement" title="Taiwanese localization movement">localization</a> in which Taiwanese culture and history were promoted over a pan-China viewpoint in contrast to earlier KMT policies. Lee's reforms included printing banknotes from the Central Bank rather than the Provincial Bank of Taiwan, and streamlining the <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Provincial_Government" title="Taiwan Provincial Government">Taiwan Provincial Government</a> with most of its functions transferred to the <a href="/wiki/Executive_Yuan" title="Executive Yuan">Executive Yuan</a>. Under Lee, the original members of the <a href="/wiki/Legislative_Yuan" title="Legislative Yuan">Legislative Yuan</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Assembly_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="National Assembly of the Republic of China">National Assembly</a> (a former supreme legislative body defunct in 2005),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[172]</a></sup> elected in 1947 to represent mainland Chinese constituencies and having held the seats without re-election for more than four decades, were forced to resign in 1991. The previously nominal representation in the Legislative Yuan was brought to an end, reflecting the reality that the ROC had no jurisdiction over mainland China, and vice versa. Restrictions on the use of <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_Hokkien" title="Taiwanese Hokkien">Taiwanese Hokkien</a> in the broadcast media and in schools were also lifted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ÁrokayGvozdanović2014_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-ÁrokayGvozdanović2014-190">[173]</a></sup>
</p><p>Reforms continued in the 1990s. The <a href="/wiki/Additional_Articles_of_the_Constitution_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Additional Articles of the Constitution of the Republic of China">Additional Articles of the Constitution of the Republic of China</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Act_Governing_Relations_between_the_People_of_the_Taiwan_Area_and_the_Mainland_Area" title="Act Governing Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area">Act Governing Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area</a> defined the status of the ROC, making Taiwan its <i>de facto</i> territory. Lee Teng-hui was re-elected as the KMT candidate in 1996, in the first direct presidential election in the history of the ROC, defeating DDP candidate Peng Ming-min.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[175]</a></sup> With democratization, the issue of the political status of Taiwan gradually resurfaced as a controversial issue where, previously, the discussion of anything other than unification under the ROC was <a href="/wiki/Taboo" title="Taboo">taboo</a>. During the later years of Lee's administration, he was involved in corruption controversies relating to government release of land and weapons purchase, although no legal proceedings commenced. In 1997, "To meet the requisites of the nation prior to national unification",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[176]</a></sup> the Additional Articles of the Constitution of the Republic of China was passed and then the former "constitution of five powers" turns to be more tripartite.
</p><p>In 2000, <a href="/wiki/Chen_Shui-bian" title="Chen Shui-bian">Chen Shui-bian</a> of the Democratic Progressive Party was elected as the first non-Kuomintang (KMT) President and was re-elected to serve his second and last term since 2004, even after he backtracked on the need to declare Taiwan's independence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EckholmNYT2000_188-1"><a href="#cite_note-EckholmNYT2000-188">[171]</a></sup> Meanwhile, polarized politics emerged in Taiwan with the formation of the <a href="/wiki/Pan-Blue_Coalition" title="Pan-Blue Coalition">Pan-Blue Coalition</a>, led by the KMT, and the <a href="/wiki/Pan-Green_Coalition" title="Pan-Green Coalition">Pan-Green Coalition</a>, led by the DPP. The former prefers eventual <a href="/wiki/Chinese_unification" title="Chinese unification">Chinese unification</a>, while the latter prefers <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_independence_movement" title="Taiwan independence movement">Taiwanese independence</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[177]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2004, the Chen administration pushed for a referendum on <a href="/wiki/2004_Taiwanese_cross-Strait_relations_referendum" title="2004 Taiwanese cross-Strait relations referendum">cross-Strait relations</a>. In early 2006, Chen Shui-bian remarked: "The National Unification Council will cease to function. No budget will be ear-marked for it and its personnel must return to their original posts<span class="nowrap"> </span>... The National Unification Guidelines will cease to apply."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[178]</a></sup> On 30 September 2007, the ruling DPP approved a <a href="/wiki/Resolution_(law)" title="Resolution (law)">resolution</a> asserting a separate identity from China and called for the enactment of a new constitution for a "normal country". It also called for general use of "Taiwan" as the country's name, without abolishing its formal name, the Republic of China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[179]</a></sup>
</p><p>However, Chen alienated moderate constituents who supported the status quo and those with cross-strait economic ties, as well as creating tension with the mainland and disagreements with the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT2008_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT2008-197">[180]</a></sup> In 2008, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2008_Taiwanese_United_Nations_membership_referendums" title="2008 Taiwanese United Nations membership referendums">referendums</a> were held on the same day as the presidential election asking whether Taiwan should join the UN under "Taiwan" (DPP's motion) or "Republic of China"/any other suitable name (KMT's motion). Both failed because only 35 percent of the electorate, below the required threshold of 50 percent, voted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lam200803_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-lam200803-198">[181]</a></sup> The Chen administration was also dogged by public concerns over reduced economic growth, legislative gridlock due to a pan-blue, opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan, and <a href="/wiki/Chen_Shui-bian_corruption_charges" title="Chen Shui-bian corruption charges">corruption investigations</a> involving the First Family as well as government officials, lowering the President's ratings to the 20s near the end of his second term.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-economist20080323_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-economist20080323-199">[182]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ft20080325_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-ft20080325-200">[183]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT2008_197-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYT2008-197">[180]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2008_Republic_of_China_legislative_election" title="2008 Republic of China legislative election">January 2008 legislative elections</a>, the KMT's majority in the Legislative Yuan increased. Its nominee Ma Ying-jeou went on to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2008_Republic_of_China_presidential_election" title="2008 Republic of China presidential election">win the presidency</a> in March of the same year, campaigning on a platform of increased economic growth and better ties with the PRC under a policy of "<a href="/wiki/Special_non-state-to-state_relations" title="Special non-state-to-state relations">mutual non-denial</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lam200803_198-1"><a href="#cite_note-lam200803-198">[181]</a></sup> Under Ma, Taiwan and China opened up direct flights and cargo shipments, with the latter country even making it possible for Taiwan to participate in the annual <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Assembly" title="World Health Assembly">World Health Assembly</a>. Threats from China faded from the public's mind, although U.S. analysts Richard Fisher and Richard Bush argued that military tensions with the PRC had not been reduced.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[184]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%E5%A4%AA%E9%99%BD%E8%8A%B1%E5%AD%B8%E9%81%8B_IMG_5932_(13822412824).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1936" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/%E5%A4%AA%E9%99%BD%E8%8A%B1%E5%AD%B8%E9%81%8B_IMG_5932_%2813822412824%29.jpg/220px-%E5%A4%AA%E9%99%BD%E8%8A%B1%E5%AD%B8%E9%81%8B_IMG_5932_%2813822412824%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/%E5%A4%AA%E9%99%BD%E8%8A%B1%E5%AD%B8%E9%81%8B_IMG_5932_%2813822412824%29.jpg/330px-%E5%A4%AA%E9%99%BD%E8%8A%B1%E5%AD%B8%E9%81%8B_IMG_5932_%2813822412824%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/%E5%A4%AA%E9%99%BD%E8%8A%B1%E5%AD%B8%E9%81%8B_IMG_5932_%2813822412824%29.jpg/440px-%E5%A4%AA%E9%99%BD%E8%8A%B1%E5%AD%B8%E9%81%8B_IMG_5932_%2813822412824%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%E5%A4%AA%E9%99%BD%E8%8A%B1%E5%AD%B8%E9%81%8B_IMG_5932_(13822412824).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sunflower_Student_Movement" title="Sunflower Student Movement">Student protest</a> in Taipei against a controversial <a href="/wiki/Cross-Strait_Service_Trade_Agreement" title="Cross-Strait Service Trade Agreement">trade agreement with China</a> in March 2014</div></div></div>
<p>In 2014, a group of university students successfully occupied the Legislative Yuan and prevented the ratification of the <a href="/wiki/Cross-Strait_Service_Trade_Agreement" title="Cross-Strait Service Trade Agreement">Cross-Strait Service Trade Agreement</a> in what became known as the <a href="/wiki/Sunflower_Student_Movement" title="Sunflower Student Movement">Sunflower Student Movement</a>. The movement gave rise to youth-based third parties such as the <a href="/wiki/New_Power_Party" title="New Power Party">New Power Party</a>, and is viewed to have contributed to Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) victories the <a href="/wiki/2016_Taiwanese_presidential_election" title="2016 Taiwanese presidential election">2016 presidential</a> and <a href="/wiki/2016_Taiwanese_legislative_election" title="2016 Taiwanese legislative election">legislative elections</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[185]</a></sup> This marked the first time in Taiwanese history that the KMT lost its legislative majority.
</p><p>In 2016, <a href="/wiki/Tsai_Ing-wen" title="Tsai Ing-wen">Tsai Ing-wen</a> of the DPP became the president of Taiwan. In 2020, she called on the international community to defend the self-ruled island's democracy in the face of renewed threats from China and called on the latter to democratize and renounce the use of military force against Taiwan. <a href="/wiki/Paramount_leader" title="Paramount leader">Chinese leader</a> <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping" title="Xi Jinping">Xi Jinping</a> had earlier expressed that Taiwan was part of China, who reserves the right to use force but will strive to achieve peaceful reunification. Xi also offered to discuss unification with parties or individuals under the precondition of "one China", but both Tsai and the KMT rejected Xi's proposal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TsaiDemocracy_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-TsaiDemocracy-203">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TsaiDemocratizePRC_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-TsaiDemocratizePRC-204">[187]</a></sup>
</p><p>In January 2020, Tsai was <a href="/wiki/2020_Taiwanese_presidential_election" title="2020 Taiwanese presidential election">re-elected</a> and in the simultaneous <a href="/wiki/2020_Taiwanese_legislative_election" title="2020 Taiwanese legislative election">legislative election</a> President Tsai's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) won a majority with 61 out of 113 seats. The Kuomintang (KMT) got 38 seats.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[188]</a></sup> The 2020 <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">Democracy Index</a> published by London-based <a href="/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit" title="Economist Intelligence Unit">Economist Intelligence Unit</a> upgraded Taiwan from a "flawed democracy" to a "full democracy", raising it from the 31st place previously to the 11th, a greater improvement than any other country. It ranked below Canada but above Germany, Japan, and the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-indexreport2020_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-indexreport2020-206">[189]</a></sup> Currently, as of 2022, Taiwan ranks 8th place in the Democracy Index, with a score of 8.99 out of 10, now above Canada.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Taiwan" title="Geography of Taiwan">Geography of Taiwan</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Taiwan_NASA_Terra_MODIS_2022-07-21.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1886" data-file-width="1330" decoding="async" height="369" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Taiwan_NASA_Terra_MODIS_2022-07-21.jpg/260px-Taiwan_NASA_Terra_MODIS_2022-07-21.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Taiwan_NASA_Terra_MODIS_2022-07-21.jpg/390px-Taiwan_NASA_Terra_MODIS_2022-07-21.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Taiwan_NASA_Terra_MODIS_2022-07-21.jpg/520px-Taiwan_NASA_Terra_MODIS_2022-07-21.jpg 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Taiwan_NASA_Terra_MODIS_2022-07-21.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A satellite image of Taiwan, showing it is mostly mountainous in the east, with gently sloping plains in the west. The <a href="/wiki/Penghu" title="Penghu">Penghu Islands</a> are west of the main island.</div></div></div>
<p>The land controlled by the ROC consists of <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Taiwan" title="List of islands of Taiwan">168 islands</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Taiwan_Islands_47-1"><a href="#cite_note-Taiwan_Islands-47">[l]</a></sup> with a combined area of 36,193 square kilometres (13,974 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-taiwansnapshot_26-2"><a href="#cite_note-taiwansnapshot-26">[16]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NDC2021_48-1"><a href="#cite_note-NDC2021-48">[34]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ROC_territory_34-1"><a href="#cite_note-ROC_territory-34">[j]</a></sup> The main island, known historically as <i>Formosa</i>, makes up 99 percent of this area, measuring 35,808 square kilometres (13,826 sq mi) and lying some 180 kilometres (112 mi) across the <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Strait" title="Taiwan Strait">Taiwan Strait</a> from the southeastern coast of <a href="/wiki/Mainland_China" title="Mainland China">mainland China</a>. The <a href="/wiki/East_China_Sea" title="East China Sea">East China Sea</a> lies to its north, the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Sea" title="Philippine Sea">Philippine Sea</a> to its east, the <a href="/wiki/Luzon_Strait" title="Luzon Strait">Luzon Strait</a> directly to its south and the <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China Sea</a> to its southwest. Smaller islands include the <a href="/wiki/Penghu" title="Penghu">Penghu Islands</a> in the Taiwan Strait, the <a href="/wiki/Kinmen" title="Kinmen">Kinmen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Matsu_Islands" title="Matsu Islands">Matsu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wuqiu,_Kinmen" title="Wuqiu, Kinmen">Wuqiu</a> islands near the Chinese coast, and some of the <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China Sea</a> islands.
</p><p>The main island is a tilted <a href="/wiki/Fault_block" title="Fault block">fault block</a>, characterized by the contrast between the eastern two-thirds, consisting mostly of five rugged mountain ranges parallel to the east coast, and the flat to gently rolling plains of the western third, where the majority of Taiwan's population reside. There are several peaks over 3,500 metres, the highest being <a href="/wiki/Yu_Shan" title="Yu Shan">Yu Shan</a> at 3,952 m (12,966 ft), making Taiwan the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_by_highest_point" title="List of islands by highest point">fourth-highest island</a>. The tectonic boundary that formed these ranges is still active, and the island experiences many earthquakes, a few of them highly destructive. There are also many active <a href="/wiki/Submarine_volcano" title="Submarine volcano">submarine volcanoes</a> in the Taiwan Strait.
</p><p>Taiwan contains four terrestrial ecoregions: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jian_Nan_subtropical_evergreen_forests" title="Jian Nan subtropical evergreen forests">Jian Nan subtropical evergreen forests</a>, South China Sea Islands, <a href="/wiki/South_Taiwan_monsoon_rain_forests" title="South Taiwan monsoon rain forests">South Taiwan monsoon rain forests</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_subtropical_evergreen_forests" title="Taiwan subtropical evergreen forests">Taiwan subtropical evergreen forests</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DinersteinOlson2017_207-0"><a href="#cite_note-DinersteinOlson2017-207">[190]</a></sup> The eastern mountains are heavily forested and home to a diverse range of wildlife, while land use in the western and northern lowlands is intensive. The country had a 2019 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 6.38/10, ranking it 76th globally out of 172 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-208">[191]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Taiwan" title="Climate change in Taiwan">Climate change in Taiwan</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_TWN_present.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1060" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="279" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Koppen-Geiger_Map_TWN_present.svg/290px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_TWN_present.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Koppen-Geiger_Map_TWN_present.svg/435px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_TWN_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Koppen-Geiger_Map_TWN_present.svg/580px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_TWN_present.svg.png 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_TWN_present.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Köppen climate classification of Taiwan</div></div></div>
<p>Taiwan lies on the <a href="/wiki/Tropic_of_Cancer" title="Tropic of Cancer">Tropic of Cancer</a>, and its general <a href="/wiki/Climate" title="Climate">climate</a> is marine <a href="/wiki/Tropical_climate" title="Tropical climate">tropical</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia-factbook_20-2"><a href="#cite_note-cia-factbook-20">[14]</a></sup> The northern and central regions are subtropical, whereas the south is tropical and the mountainous regions are temperate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEExec._Yuan201444_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEExec._Yuan201444-209">[192]</a></sup> The average rainfall is 2,600 millimetres (100 inches) per year for the island proper; the <a href="/wiki/East_Asian_rainy_season" title="East Asian rainy season">rainy season</a> is concurrent with the onset of the summer <a href="/wiki/East_Asian_Monsoon" title="East Asian Monsoon">East Asian Monsoon</a> in May and June.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEExec._Yuan201445_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEExec._Yuan201445-210">[193]</a></sup> The entire island experiences hot, humid weather from June through September. <a href="/wiki/Typhoon" title="Typhoon">Typhoons</a> are most common in July, August and September.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEExec._Yuan201445_210-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEExec._Yuan201445-210">[193]</a></sup> During the winter (November to March), the northeast experiences steady rain, while the central and southern parts of the island are mostly sunny.
</p><p>Due to <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Taiwan" title="Climate change in Taiwan">climate change</a>, the average temperature in Taiwan has risen 1.4 °C (2.5 °F) in the last 100 years, which is twice of the worldwide temperature rise.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[194]</a></sup> The goal of the Taiwanese government is to cut <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carbon_emissions" title="Carbon emissions">carbon emissions</a> by 20 per cent in 2030 compared to 2005 levels, and by 50 per cent in 2050 compared to 2005 levels. Carbon emissions increased by 0.92 per cent between 2005 and 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[195]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Geology">Geology</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geology_of_Taiwan" title="Geology of Taiwan">Geology of Taiwan</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%E5%A4%A7%E9%9C%B8%E5%B0%96%E5%B1%B1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3648" data-file-width="5472" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/%E5%A4%A7%E9%9C%B8%E5%B0%96%E5%B1%B1.jpg/220px-%E5%A4%A7%E9%9C%B8%E5%B0%96%E5%B1%B1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/%E5%A4%A7%E9%9C%B8%E5%B0%96%E5%B1%B1.jpg/330px-%E5%A4%A7%E9%9C%B8%E5%B0%96%E5%B1%B1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/%E5%A4%A7%E9%9C%B8%E5%B0%96%E5%B1%B1.jpg/440px-%E5%A4%A7%E9%9C%B8%E5%B0%96%E5%B1%B1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%E5%A4%A7%E9%9C%B8%E5%B0%96%E5%B1%B1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mount_Dabajian" title="Mount Dabajian">Mount Dabajian</a> was selected as one of the <a href="/wiki/100_Peaks_of_Taiwan" title="100 Peaks of Taiwan">100 Peaks of Taiwan</a></div></div></div>
<p>The island of Taiwan lies in a complex <a href="/wiki/Tectonics" title="Tectonics">tectonic</a> area between the <a href="/wiki/Yangtze_Plate" title="Yangtze Plate">Yangtze Plate</a> to the west and north, the <a href="/wiki/Okinawa_Plate" title="Okinawa Plate">Okinawa Plate</a> on the north-east, and the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Mobile_Belt" title="Philippine Mobile Belt">Philippine Mobile Belt</a> on the east and south. The upper part of the crust on the island is primarily made up of a series of <a href="/wiki/Terrane" title="Terrane">terranes</a>, mostly old <a href="/wiki/Island_arc" title="Island arc">island arcs</a> which have been forced together by the collision of the forerunners of the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_Plate" title="Eurasian Plate">Eurasian Plate</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Sea_Plate" title="Philippine Sea Plate">Philippine Sea Plate</a>. These have been further uplifted as a result of the detachment of a portion of the Eurasian Plate as it was <a href="/wiki/Subduction" title="Subduction">subducted</a> beneath remnants of the Philippine Sea Plate, a process which left the crust under Taiwan more buoyant.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[196]</a></sup>
</p><p>The east and south of Taiwan are a complex system of belts formed by, and part of the zone of, active collision between the North Luzon Trough portion of the <a href="/wiki/Luzon_Volcanic_Arc" title="Luzon Volcanic Arc">Luzon Volcanic Arc</a> and South China, where accreted portions of the Luzon Arc and Luzon forearc form the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Haian_Range" title="Haian Range">eastern Coastal Range</a> and parallel inland <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Huatung_Valley" title="Huatung Valley">Longitudinal Valley</a> of Taiwan, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[197]</a></sup>
</p><p>The major seismic faults in Taiwan correspond to the various suture zones between the various terranes. These have produced major quakes throughout the history of the island. On 21 September 1999, a 7.3 quake known as the "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1999_Jiji_(Chichi)_earthquake" title="1999 Jiji (Chichi) earthquake">921 earthquake</a>" killed more than 2,400 people. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seismic_hazard_map" title="Seismic hazard map">seismic hazard map</a> for Taiwan by the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Geological_Survey" title="United States Geological Survey">USGS</a> shows 9/10 of the island at the highest rating (most hazardous).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[198]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_and_legal_status"><span class="anchor" id="status"></span>Political and legal status</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Taiwan" title="Political status of Taiwan">Political status of Taiwan</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_limited_recognition" title="List of states with limited recognition">List of states with limited recognition</a>; <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_China#International_territorial_disputes" title="Foreign relations of China">Foreign relations of China § International territorial disputes</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Taiwan,_China" title="Taiwan, China">Taiwan, China</a></div>
<p>The political and legal statuses of Taiwan are contentious issues. The People's Republic of China (PRC) claims that Taiwan is Chinese territory and that itself has replaced the ROC government in 1949, becoming the sole legal government of China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PRCNorway_86-1"><a href="#cite_note-PRCNorway-86">[69]</a></sup> The ROC, however, has its <a href="/wiki/New_Taiwan_dollar" title="New Taiwan dollar">own currency</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_passport" title="Taiwan passport">widely accepted passport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Postage_stamps_and_postal_history_of_Taiwan" title="Postage stamps and postal history of Taiwan">postage stamps</a>, internet <a href="/wiki/Top-level_domain" title="Top-level domain">TLD</a>, armed forces and constitution with an independently elected president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tfp09_216-0"><a href="#cite_note-tfp09-216">[199]</a></sup> It has not formally renounced its claim to the mainland, but ROC government publications have increasingly downplayed this historical claim.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[200]</a></sup>
</p><p>Though it was a <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_United_Nations#Original_members" title="Member states of the United Nations">founding member of United Nations</a>, the ROC now has neither official membership nor observer status in the organization.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Relations_with_the_PRC">Relations with the PRC</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Cross-Strait_relations" title="Cross-Strait relations">Cross-Strait relations</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Mainland_Affairs_Council" title="Mainland Affairs Council">Mainland Affairs Council</a> (MAC) of Taiwan is responsible for relations with the PRC, while the <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Affairs_Office" title="Taiwan Affairs Office">Taiwan Affairs Office</a> (TAO) of the PRC is responsible for relations with Taiwan. Exchanges are conducted through private organizations both founded in 1991: the <a href="/wiki/Straits_Exchange_Foundation" title="Straits Exchange Foundation">Straits Exchange Foundation</a> (SEF) of Taiwan and the <a href="/wiki/Association_for_Relations_Across_the_Taiwan_Straits" title="Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits">Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits</a> (ARATS) of the PRC.
</p><p>The political environment is complicated by the potential for military conflict<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mol21_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-mol21-218">[201]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mar21_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-mar21-219">[202]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yn21_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-yn21-220">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cha21_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-cha21-221">[204]</a></sup> should events outlined in the PRC's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anti-secession_law" title="Anti-secession law">anti-secession law</a> occur, such as Taiwan declaring <i><a href="/wiki/De_jure" title="De jure">de jure</a></i> independence. While it aims for peaceful reunification, the PRC does not rule out the use of force.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PRCNorway_86-2"><a href="#cite_note-PRCNorway-86">[69]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-scmp2014sep27_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-scmp2014sep27-222">[205]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc21_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbc21-223">[206]</a></sup> There is a substantial military presence on the Fujian coast as well as PRC sorties into Taiwan's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ADIZ" title="ADIZ">ADIZ</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[207]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2004NatDefRpt_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-2004NatDefRpt-225">[208]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-srf21_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-srf21-226">[209]</a></sup> The PRC's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/One-China_policy" title="One-China policy">One-China principle</a> states that Taiwan and mainland China are both part of China, and that the PRC is the only legitimate <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Government_of_China_(disambiguation)" title="Government of China (disambiguation)">government of China</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-woo21_59-2"><a href="#cite_note-woo21-59">[44]</a></sup> It seeks to prevent or reduce any formal recognition of the ROC as an independent sovereign state,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[210]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[211]</a></sup> meaning that Taiwan participates in many international forums as a non-state member under names such as "Chinese Taipei".
</p><p>For almost 60 years, there were no direct transportation links, including direct flights, between Taiwan and the PRC. This was a problem for many Taiwanese businesses that had opened factories or branches in mainland China. In the 2006 Lunar New Year Speech, President Chen Shui-bian called for managed opening of links. Direct weekend charter flights between Taiwan and mainland China began in July 2008 under the KMT government, and the first direct daily charter flights took off in December 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[212]</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 1992, the ARATS and SEF held a meeting which would later become known as the <a href="/wiki/1992_Consensus" title="1992 Consensus">1992 Consensus</a>. The SEF announced that both sides agreed that there was only one China, but disagreed on the definition of China (i.e. the ROC vs. PRC), while the ARATS announced that the two agreed on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/One_China_Policy" title="One China Policy">One China Principle</a>, but did not mention differences regarding its definition made in the SEF statement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-230">[213]</a></sup> This discrepancy between the two statements was criticized by the DPP and former president <a href="/wiki/Lee_Teng-hui" title="Lee Teng-hui">Lee Teng-hui</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lee92_231-0"><a href="#cite_note-lee92-231">[214]</a></sup> The PRC has since viewed it as a prerequisite for dialogue between the ROC and PRC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lee92_231-1"><a href="#cite_note-lee92-231">[214]</a></sup> In February 2000, the PRC suggested the "<a href="/wiki/One_country,_two_systems" title="One country, two systems">one country, two systems</a>" employed in <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> as a model for peaceful unification with Taiwan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PRCNorway_86-3"><a href="#cite_note-PRCNorway-86">[69]</a></sup>
</p><p>President <a href="/wiki/Chen_Shui-bian" title="Chen Shui-bian">Chen Shui-bian</a> of the DPP, elected in March 2000, initially indicated a willingness to accept the 1992 Consensus, but later backed down due to pressure within his party and sought a middle ground by attempting dialogue with the PRC on the basis of the 1992 Consensus without explicitly accepting the One China Principle; this was not well received by the PRC and official dialogue was suspended.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[215]</a></sup> On 29 April 2005, Kuomintang <a href="/wiki/Chairman_of_the_Kuomintang" title="Chairman of the Kuomintang">Chairman</a> <a href="/wiki/Lien_Chan" title="Lien Chan">Lien Chan</a> travelled to Beijing and <a href="/wiki/2005_Pan%E2%80%93Blue_visits_to_mainland_China" title="2005 Pan–Blue visits to mainland China">met</a> with Chinese Communist Party <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party" title="General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party">General Secretary</a> <a href="/wiki/Hu_Jintao" title="Hu Jintao">Hu Jintao</a>, the first meeting between the leaders of the two parties since the end of the Chinese Civil War in 1949.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[216]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AP-Guardian-2005-04-29_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-AP-Guardian-2005-04-29-234">[217]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TP-2005-03-28_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-TP-2005-03-28-235">[218]</a></sup> According to US sources, Hu said in 2008 that talks between Taiwan and the mainland should be restored on the basis of the 1992 Consensus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ft20080403_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-ft20080403-236">[219]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PRCVancouver20080326_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-PRCVancouver20080326-237">[220]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bw20080327_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-bw20080327-238">[221]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2015_Ma%E2%80%93Xi_Meeting_08.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3840" data-file-width="5760" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/2015_Ma%E2%80%93Xi_Meeting_08.jpg/220px-2015_Ma%E2%80%93Xi_Meeting_08.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/2015_Ma%E2%80%93Xi_Meeting_08.jpg/330px-2015_Ma%E2%80%93Xi_Meeting_08.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/2015_Ma%E2%80%93Xi_Meeting_08.jpg/440px-2015_Ma%E2%80%93Xi_Meeting_08.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2015_Ma%E2%80%93Xi_Meeting_08.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ma%E2%80%93Xi_meeting" title="Ma–Xi meeting">Ma–Xi meeting</a> was the first meeting between the leaders from both sides of the Taiwan Strait since 1949</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Ma_Ying-jeou" title="Ma Ying-jeou">Ma Ying-jeou</a> of the KMT fully endorsed the 1992 Consensus, though he stated that there would be neither unification nor declaration of independence during his presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cnn-2014-11-04_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-cnn-2014-11-04-239">[222]</a></sup> After becoming elected president in 2008, talks between the ROC and PRC resumed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[223]</a></sup> On 11 February 2014, <a href="/wiki/Mainland_Affairs_Council" title="Mainland Affairs Council">Mainland Affairs Council</a> head <a href="/wiki/Wang_Yu-chi" title="Wang Yu-chi">Wang Yu-chi</a> travelled to <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">Nanjing</a> and met with <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Affairs_Office" title="Taiwan Affairs Office">Taiwan Affairs Office</a> head <a href="/wiki/Zhang_Zhijun" title="Zhang Zhijun">Zhang Zhijun</a>, the <a href="/wiki/2014_Wang%E2%80%93Zhang_meetings" title="2014 Wang–Zhang meetings">first meeting between high-ranking officials</a> from either side.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[224]</a></sup> Zhang paid a reciprocal visit to Taiwan and met Wang on 25 June 2014, making Zhang the first minister-level PRC official to ever visit Taiwan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[225]</a></sup> On 7 November 2015, Ma Ying-jeou and Xi Jinping<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[226]</a></sup> had a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2015_Ma%E2%80%93Xi_meeting" title="2015 Ma–Xi meeting">face-to-face meeting in Singapore</a>, the first time two ROC and PRC leaders had met since 1949.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cnaupdate_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-cnaupdate-244">[227]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[228]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/2016_Taiwanese_presidential_election" title="2016 Taiwanese presidential election">2016 Taiwanese presidential election</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tsai_Ing-wen" title="Tsai Ing-wen">Tsai Ing-wen</a> of the DPP initially pursued a similar strategy as <a href="/wiki/Chen_Shui-bian" title="Chen Shui-bian">Chen Shui-bian</a>, but after winning the election she received a similarly frosty reception from the PRC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[229]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[230]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[231]</a></sup> In 2019, Tsai, who supported the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_Hong_Kong_protests" title="2019–20 Hong Kong protests">2019–20 Hong Kong protests</a>, pledged that as long as she is Taiwan's president, she will never accept "<a href="/wiki/One_country,_two_systems" title="One country, two systems">one country, two systems</a>", and that since the PRC equated the 1992 Consensus with "one country, two systems", she could not accept the 1992 Consensus as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[232]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-an21_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-an21-250">[233]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TsaiDemocracy_203-1"><a href="#cite_note-TsaiDemocracy-203">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Horton_251-0"><a href="#cite_note-Horton-251">[234]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Taiwan" title="Foreign relations of Taiwan">Foreign relations of Taiwan</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Countries_recognizing_the_Republic_of_China_(Taiwan).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1398" data-file-width="2754" decoding="async" height="132" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Countries_recognizing_the_Republic_of_China_%28Taiwan%29.svg/260px-Countries_recognizing_the_Republic_of_China_%28Taiwan%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Countries_recognizing_the_Republic_of_China_%28Taiwan%29.svg/390px-Countries_recognizing_the_Republic_of_China_%28Taiwan%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Countries_recognizing_the_Republic_of_China_%28Taiwan%29.svg/520px-Countries_recognizing_the_Republic_of_China_%28Taiwan%29.svg.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Countries_recognizing_the_Republic_of_China_(Taiwan).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:black; color:white;"> </span> Republic of China (Taiwan)</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#007f00; color:white;"> </span> Countries that have formal relations with Taiwan</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#8fbc8f; color:black;"> </span> Countries that have formal relations with the PRC and informal relations with Taiwan</div></div></div></div>
<p>Before 1928, the <a href="/wiki/Foreign_policy" title="Foreign policy">foreign policy</a> of Republican China was complicated by a lack of internal unity—competing centres of power all claimed legitimacy. This situation changed after the defeat of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beiyang_Government" title="Beiyang Government">Peiyang Government</a> by the Kuomintang (KMT), which led to widespread diplomatic recognition of the Republic of China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[235]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the KMT's retreat to Taiwan, most countries, notably the countries in the <a href="/wiki/Western_Bloc" title="Western Bloc">Western Bloc</a>, continued to maintain relations with the ROC, but recognition gradually eroded and many countries switched recognition to the People's Republic of China in the 1970s. On 25 October 1971, UN Resolution 2758 was adopted by 76 votes to 35 with 17 abstensions, recognizing the PRC, founded in 1949 on the mainland, as China's sole representative in the United Nations; countries in support included France, India, the UK, and the USSR, and countries in opposition included Japan and the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[236]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[237]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Taiwanese_Embassy_in_Mbabane.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Taiwanese_Embassy_in_Mbabane.JPG/220px-Taiwanese_Embassy_in_Mbabane.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Taiwanese_Embassy_in_Mbabane.JPG/330px-Taiwanese_Embassy_in_Mbabane.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Taiwanese_Embassy_in_Mbabane.JPG/440px-Taiwanese_Embassy_in_Mbabane.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Taiwanese_Embassy_in_Mbabane.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Embassy_of_the_Republic_of_China_(Taiwan)_in_the_Kingdom_of_Eswatini" title="Embassy of the Republic of China (Taiwan) in the Kingdom of Eswatini">ROC embassy</a> in <a href="/wiki/Eswatini" title="Eswatini">Eswatini</a></div></div></div>
<p>The PRC refuses to have <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diplomatic_relations" title="Diplomatic relations">diplomatic relations</a> with any nation that has diplomatic relations with the ROC, and requires all nations with which it has diplomatic relations to make a statement recognizing its claims to Taiwan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[238]</a></sup> As a result, only <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_recognition_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="International recognition of the Republic of China">13 UN member states</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a> maintain official diplomatic relations with the Republic of China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-woo21_59-3"><a href="#cite_note-woo21-59">[44]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_60-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-60">[45]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wule21_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-wule21-256">[239]</a></sup> The ROC maintains unofficial relations with most countries via <i>de facto</i> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Embassy" title="Embassy">embassies</a> and <a href="/wiki/Consul_(representative)" title="Consul (representative)">consulates</a> called <a href="/wiki/Taipei_Economic_and_Cultural_Representative_Office" title="Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office">Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Offices</a> (TECRO), with branch offices called "Taipei Economic and Cultural Offices" (TECO). Both TECRO and TECO are "unofficial commercial entities" of the ROC in charge of maintaining <a href="/wiki/Diplomacy" title="Diplomacy">diplomatic relations</a>, providing consular services (i.e. visa applications), and serving the national interests of the ROC in other countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[240]</a></sup>
</p><p>From 1954 to 1979, the United States was a partner with Taiwan in a mutual defense treaty. The United States remains one of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_of_China-United_States_relations" title="Republic of China-United States relations">main supporters</a> of Taiwan and, through the <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Relations_Act" title="Taiwan Relations Act">Taiwan Relations Act</a> passed in 1979, has continued selling arms and providing military training to the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_Armed_Forces" title="Republic of China Armed Forces">Armed Forces</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TRA-review_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-TRA-review-258">[241]</a></sup> This situation continues to be an issue for the People's Republic of China, which considers US involvement disruptive to the stability of the region. In January 2010, the US announced its intention to sell $6.4 billion worth of military hardware to Taiwan. As a consequence, the PRC warned that its co-operation with the US on international and regional issues could suffer and that the companies involved, namely <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Raytheon" title="Raytheon">Raytheon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lockheed_Martin" title="Lockheed Martin">Lockheed Martin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boeing" title="Boeing">Boeing</a>, and <a href="/wiki/United_Technologies" title="United Technologies">United Technologies</a>, could face Chinese sanctions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SanctionsAFP_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-SanctionsAFP-259">[242]</a></sup>
</p><p>The official position of the United States is that the PRC is expected to "use no force or threat[en] to use force against Taiwan" and the ROC is to "exercise prudence in managing all aspects of <a href="/wiki/Cross-Strait_relations" title="Cross-Strait relations">Cross-Strait relations</a>." Both are to refrain from performing actions or espousing statements "that would unilaterally alter Taiwan's status".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UsPolicyToTaiwan_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-UsPolicyToTaiwan-260">[243]</a></sup> On 16 December 2015, the <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Barack_Obama" title="Presidency of Barack Obama">Obama administration</a> announced a deal to sell $1.83 billion worth of arms to the armed forces of the ROC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[244]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[245]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China">foreign ministry of the PRC</a> had expressed its disapproval for the sales and issued the US a "stern warning", saying it would hurt <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="China–United States relations">PRC–US relations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[246]</a></sup> In response to US support for Taiwan, the PRC defense minister <a href="/wiki/Wei_Fenghe" title="Wei Fenghe">Wei Fenghe</a> said in 2019, "If anyone dares to split Taiwan from China, the Chinese military has no choice but to fight at all costs".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[247]</a></sup> President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> in March 2020 signed the <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Allies_International_Protection_and_Enhancement_Initiative_Act" title="Taiwan Allies International Protection and Enhancement Initiative Act">TAIPEI ACT</a> and, in December of the same year, the Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2021, which incorporated the Taiwan Assurance Act of 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[248]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Participation_in_international_events_and_organizations">Participation in international events and organizations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Taiwan#Relation_with_International_organizations" title="Foreign relations of Taiwan">Foreign relations of Taiwan § Relation with International organizations</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Taipei" title="Chinese Taipei">Chinese Taipei</a></div>
<p>The ROC was a founding member of the United Nations, and held the <a href="/wiki/China_and_the_United_Nations" title="China and the United Nations">seat of China</a> on the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">Security Council</a> and other UN bodies until 1971, when it was expelled by Resolution 2758 and replaced in all UN organs with the PRC. Each year since 1992, the ROC has petitioned the UN for entry, but its applications have not made it past committee stage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[249]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Chinese_Taipei_for_Olympic_games.svg"><img alt="A white symbol in shape of a five petal flower ringed by a blue and a red line. In its centre stands a circular symbol depicting a white sun on a blue background. The five Olympic circles (blue, yellow, black, green and red) stand below it." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Flag_of_Chinese_Taipei_for_Olympic_games.svg/220px-Flag_of_Chinese_Taipei_for_Olympic_games.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Flag_of_Chinese_Taipei_for_Olympic_games.svg/330px-Flag_of_Chinese_Taipei_for_Olympic_games.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Flag_of_Chinese_Taipei_for_Olympic_games.svg/440px-Flag_of_Chinese_Taipei_for_Olympic_games.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Chinese_Taipei_for_Olympic_games.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The flag used by Taiwan at the Olympic Games, where it competes as "<a href="/wiki/Chinese_Taipei" title="Chinese Taipei">Chinese Taipei</a>" (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hant-TW">中華台北</span></span>)</div></div></div>
<p>Due to its limited international recognition, the Republic of China has been a member of the <a href="/wiki/Unrepresented_Nations_and_Peoples_Organization" title="Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organization">Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organization</a> (UNPO) since the foundation of the organization in 1991, represented by a government-funded organization, the <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Foundation_for_Democracy" title="Taiwan Foundation for Democracy">Taiwan Foundation for Democracy</a> (TFD), under the name "Taiwan".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[250]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[251]</a></sup>
</p><p>Also due to its One China policy, the PRC only participates in international organizations where the ROC does not participate as a sovereign country. Most <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_United_Nations" title="Member states of the United Nations">member states</a>, including the United States, do not wish to discuss the issue of the ROC's political status for fear of souring diplomatic ties with the PRC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[252]</a></sup> However, both the US and Japan publicly support the ROC's bid for membership in the World Health Organization (WHO) as an observer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[253]</a></sup> However, though the ROC sought to participate in the WHO since 1997,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[254]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[255]</a></sup> their efforts were rejected until 2009, when they participated under the name "Chinese Taipei" after reaching an agreement with Beijing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WHO2009_85-1"><a href="#cite_note-WHO2009-85">[68]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[256]</a></sup> In 2017, Taiwan again began to be excluded from the WHO even in an observer capacity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[257]</a></sup> This exclusion caused a number of scandals during the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19" title="COVID-19">COVID-19</a> outbreak.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[258]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[259]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_at_the_Olympics#Nagoya_Resolution" title="Republic of China at the Olympics">Nagoya Resolution</a> in 1979 between Taiwan (ROC), China (PRC), and the <a href="/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee" title="International Olympic Committee">International Olympic Committee</a> (IOC) provided a compromise for the ROC to use the name "Chinese Taipei" in international events where the PRC is also a party, such as the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympic Games</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brownell2007_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-Brownell2007-277">[260]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lin_278-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lin-278">[261]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chinese-taipei_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-chinese-taipei-279">[262]</a></sup> Under the IOC charter, <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Flag of the Republic of China">ROC flags</a> cannot be flown at any official Olympic venue or gathering; this caused some concern in 2002 when residents of a downtown condominium in <a href="/wiki/Salt_Lake_City" title="Salt Lake City">Salt Lake City</a> hung two flags from Taiwan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[263]</a></sup> The ROC also participates in the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation</a> forum (since 1991) and the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (since 2002) under the names "Chinese Taipei" and "Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu", respectively. It was a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Asian_Development_Bank" title="Asian Development Bank">Asian Development Bank</a>, but since China's ascension in 1986 has participated under the name "Taipei,China". The ROC is able to participate as "China" in organizations in which the PRC does not participate, such as the <a href="/wiki/World_Organization_of_the_Scout_Movement" title="World Organization of the Scout Movement">World Organization of the Scout Movement</a>. A <a href="/wiki/2018_Taiwanese_referendum" title="2018 Taiwanese referendum">referendum question in 2018</a> asked if Taiwan's athletes should compete under "Taiwan" in the <a href="/wiki/2020_Summer_Olympics" title="2020 Summer Olympics">2020 Summer Olympics</a> but did not pass; the New York Times attributed the failure to a campaign cautioning that a name change might lead to Taiwan being banned "under Chinese pressure".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HortonNYT2018_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-HortonNYT2018-281">[264]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Domestic_opinion">Domestic opinion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_independence_movement" title="Taiwan independence movement">Taiwan independence movement</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_unification" title="Chinese unification">Chinese unification</a></div>
<p>Broadly speaking, domestic public opinion has preferred maintaining the status quo, though pro-independence sentiment has steadily risen since 1994. In June 2021, an annual poll run by the National Chengchi University found that 28.2 percent of respondents supported the status quo and postponing a decision, 27.5 percent supported maintaining the status quo indefinitely, 25.8 percent supported the status quo with a move toward independence, 5.9 percent supported the status quo with a move toward unification, 5.7 percent gave no response, 5.6 percent supported independence as soon as possible, and 1.5 percent supported unification as soon as possible.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chengchiIndepUnif_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-chengchiIndepUnif-282">[265]</a></sup>
</p><p>The KMT, the largest Pan-Blue party, supports the status quo for the indefinite future with a stated ultimate goal of unification. However, it does not support unification in the short term with the PRC as such a prospect would be unacceptable to most of its members and the public.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[266]</a></sup> Ma Ying-jeou, chairman of the KMT and former president of the ROC, has set out democracy, economic development to a level near that of Taiwan, and equitable wealth distribution as the conditions that the PRC must fulfill for reunification to occur.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[267]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Democratic Progressive Party, the largest Pan-Green party, officially seeks independence, but in practice also supports the status quo because neither independence nor re-unification seems likely in the short or even medium term.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[268]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 2 September 2008, the Mexican newspaper <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/El_Sol_de_Mexico" title="El Sol de Mexico">El Sol de México</a></i> asked President Ma of the KMT about his views on the subject of "<a href="/wiki/Two_Chinas" title="Two Chinas">two Chinas</a>" and if there was a solution for the sovereignty issues between the two. The president replied that the relations are neither between two Chinas nor two states. It is a special relationship. Further, he stated that the sovereignty issues between the two cannot be resolved at present, but he quoted the "<a href="/wiki/1992_Consensus" title="1992 Consensus">1992 Consensus</a>", accepted by both the KMT and the Chinese Communist Party, as a temporary measure until a solution becomes available.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[269]</a></sup> However, the consensus was rejected by former president <a href="/wiki/Lee_Teng-hui" title="Lee Teng-hui">Lee Teng-hui</a>, as well as President <a href="/wiki/Tsai_Ing-wen" title="Tsai Ing-wen">Tsai Ing-wen</a> and most of the <a href="/wiki/Pan-Green_Coalition" title="Pan-Green Coalition">Pan-Green Coalition</a>.
</p><p>On 27 September 2017, Taiwanese premier <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/William_Lai" title="William Lai">William Lai</a> of the Democratic Progressive Party said that he was a "political worker who advocates Taiwan independence", but that as Taiwan was already an independent country called the Republic of China,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cha21_221-1"><a href="#cite_note-cha21-221">[204]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc21_223-1"><a href="#cite_note-bbc21-223">[206]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-srf21_226-1"><a href="#cite_note-srf21-226">[209]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gra21_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-gra21-287">[270]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dpa21-10_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-dpa21-10-288">[271]</a></sup> it had no need to declare independence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[272]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Government of the Republic of China">Government of the Republic of China</a> and <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Politics of the Republic of China">Politics of the Republic of China</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Taiwan" title="Elections in Taiwan">Elections in Taiwan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Taiwan" title="Human rights in Taiwan">Human rights in Taiwan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/North%E2%80%93South_divide_in_Taiwan" title="North–South divide in Taiwan">North–South divide in Taiwan</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%E4%B8%96%E7%95%8C%E6%9C%80%E7%BE%8E%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E5%BA%9C.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4500" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/%E4%B8%96%E7%95%8C%E6%9C%80%E7%BE%8E%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E5%BA%9C.jpg/220px-%E4%B8%96%E7%95%8C%E6%9C%80%E7%BE%8E%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E5%BA%9C.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/%E4%B8%96%E7%95%8C%E6%9C%80%E7%BE%8E%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E5%BA%9C.jpg/330px-%E4%B8%96%E7%95%8C%E6%9C%80%E7%BE%8E%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E5%BA%9C.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/%E4%B8%96%E7%95%8C%E6%9C%80%E7%BE%8E%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E5%BA%9C.jpg/440px-%E4%B8%96%E7%95%8C%E6%9C%80%E7%BE%8E%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E5%BA%9C.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%E4%B8%96%E7%95%8C%E6%9C%80%E7%BE%8E%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E5%BA%9C.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Taiwan's popularly elected president resides in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Presidential_Office_Building_(Republic_of_China)" title="Presidential Office Building (Republic of China)">Presidential Office Building, Taipei</a>, originally built in the Japanese era for colonial governors</div></div></div>
<p>The government of the Republic of China was founded on the 1947 <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Constitution of the Republic of China">Constitution of the ROC</a> and its <a href="/wiki/Three_Principles_of_the_People" title="Three Principles of the People">Three Principles of the People</a>, which states that the ROC "shall be a democratic republic of the people, to be governed by the people and for the people".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yb:government_290-0"><a href="#cite_note-yb:government-290">[273]</a></sup> It underwent significant revisions in the 1990s, known collectively as the Additional Articles. The government is divided into five branches (<i>Yuan</i>): the Executive Yuan (cabinet), the Legislative Yuan (Congress or Parliament), the <a href="/wiki/Judicial_Yuan" title="Judicial Yuan">Judicial Yuan</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Control_Yuan" title="Control Yuan">Control Yuan</a> (audit agency), and the <a href="/wiki/Examination_Yuan" title="Examination Yuan">Examination Yuan</a> (civil service examination agency).
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%E8%94%A1%E8%8B%B1%E6%96%87%E5%AE%98%E6%96%B9%E5%85%83%E9%A6%96%E8%82%96%E5%83%8F%E7%85%A7.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="676" data-file-width="564" decoding="async" height="204" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/%E8%94%A1%E8%8B%B1%E6%96%87%E5%AE%98%E6%96%B9%E5%85%83%E9%A6%96%E8%82%96%E5%83%8F%E7%85%A7.png/170px-%E8%94%A1%E8%8B%B1%E6%96%87%E5%AE%98%E6%96%B9%E5%85%83%E9%A6%96%E8%82%96%E5%83%8F%E7%85%A7.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/%E8%94%A1%E8%8B%B1%E6%96%87%E5%AE%98%E6%96%B9%E5%85%83%E9%A6%96%E8%82%96%E5%83%8F%E7%85%A7.png/255px-%E8%94%A1%E8%8B%B1%E6%96%87%E5%AE%98%E6%96%B9%E5%85%83%E9%A6%96%E8%82%96%E5%83%8F%E7%85%A7.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/%E8%94%A1%E8%8B%B1%E6%96%87%E5%AE%98%E6%96%B9%E5%85%83%E9%A6%96%E8%82%96%E5%83%8F%E7%85%A7.png/340px-%E8%94%A1%E8%8B%B1%E6%96%87%E5%AE%98%E6%96%B9%E5%85%83%E9%A6%96%E8%82%96%E5%83%8F%E7%85%A7.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%E8%94%A1%E8%8B%B1%E6%96%87%E5%AE%98%E6%96%B9%E5%85%83%E9%A6%96%E8%82%96%E5%83%8F%E7%85%A7.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Tsai_Ing-wen" title="Tsai Ing-wen">Tsai Ing-wen</a>, <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="President of the Republic of China">President of the Republic of China</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> and <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the armed forces is the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="President of the Republic of China">president</a>, who is elected by popular vote for a maximum of 2 four-year terms on the same ticket as the vice-president. The president appoints the members of the Executive Yuan as their cabinet, including a <a href="/wiki/Premier_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Premier of the Republic of China">premier</a>, who is officially the President of the Executive Yuan; members are responsible for policy and administration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yb:government_290-1"><a href="#cite_note-yb:government-290">[273]</a></sup>
