</p><p>The main <a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">legislative body</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Unicameralism" title="Unicameralism">unicameral</a> Legislative Yuan with 113 seats. Seventy-three are elected by popular vote from single-member constituencies; thirty-four are elected based on the proportion of nationwide votes received by participating political parties in a separate party list ballot; and six are elected from two three-member aboriginal constituencies. Members serve four-year terms. Originally the unicameral National Assembly, as a standing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitutional_convention_(political_meeting)" title="Constitutional convention (political meeting)">constitutional convention</a> and <a href="/wiki/Electoral_college" title="Electoral college">electoral college</a>, held some parliamentary functions, but the <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_(Republic_of_China)" title="National Assembly (Republic of China)">National Assembly</a> was abolished in 2005 with the power of constitutional amendments handed over to the Legislative Yuan and all eligible voters of the Republic via referendums.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yb:government_290-2"><a href="#cite_note-yb:government-290">[273]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[274]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%E8%98%87%E8%B2%9E%E6%98%8C%E9%99%A2%E9%95%B7%E8%88%87%E5%9F%BA%E9%9A%86%E5%B8%82%E6%9E%97%E5%8F%B3%E6%98%8C%E5%B8%82%E9%95%B7%E4%B8%80%E5%90%8C%E7%99%BB%E4%B8%8A%E5%9F%BA%E9%9A%86%E7%87%88%E5%A1%94%E4%B8%A6%E5%90%88%E5%BD%B1%E7%95%99%E5%BF%B5%EF%BC%88cropped%EF%BC%89.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="986" data-file-width="789" decoding="async" height="212" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/%E8%98%87%E8%B2%9E%E6%98%8C%E9%99%A2%E9%95%B7%E8%88%87%E5%9F%BA%E9%9A%86%E5%B8%82%E6%9E%97%E5%8F%B3%E6%98%8C%E5%B8%82%E9%95%B7%E4%B8%80%E5%90%8C%E7%99%BB%E4%B8%8A%E5%9F%BA%E9%9A%86%E7%87%88%E5%A1%94%E4%B8%A6%E5%90%88%E5%BD%B1%E7%95%99%E5%BF%B5%EF%BC%88cropped%EF%BC%89.jpg/170px-%E8%98%87%E8%B2%9E%E6%98%8C%E9%99%A2%E9%95%B7%E8%88%87%E5%9F%BA%E9%9A%86%E5%B8%82%E6%9E%97%E5%8F%B3%E6%98%8C%E5%B8%82%E9%95%B7%E4%B8%80%E5%90%8C%E7%99%BB%E4%B8%8A%E5%9F%BA%E9%9A%86%E7%87%88%E5%A1%94%E4%B8%A6%E5%90%88%E5%BD%B1%E7%95%99%E5%BF%B5%EF%BC%88cropped%EF%BC%89.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/%E8%98%87%E8%B2%9E%E6%98%8C%E9%99%A2%E9%95%B7%E8%88%87%E5%9F%BA%E9%9A%86%E5%B8%82%E6%9E%97%E5%8F%B3%E6%98%8C%E5%B8%82%E9%95%B7%E4%B8%80%E5%90%8C%E7%99%BB%E4%B8%8A%E5%9F%BA%E9%9A%86%E7%87%88%E5%A1%94%E4%B8%A6%E5%90%88%E5%BD%B1%E7%95%99%E5%BF%B5%EF%BC%88cropped%EF%BC%89.jpg/255px-%E8%98%87%E8%B2%9E%E6%98%8C%E9%99%A2%E9%95%B7%E8%88%87%E5%9F%BA%E9%9A%86%E5%B8%82%E6%9E%97%E5%8F%B3%E6%98%8C%E5%B8%82%E9%95%B7%E4%B8%80%E5%90%8C%E7%99%BB%E4%B8%8A%E5%9F%BA%E9%9A%86%E7%87%88%E5%A1%94%E4%B8%A6%E5%90%88%E5%BD%B1%E7%95%99%E5%BF%B5%EF%BC%88cropped%EF%BC%89.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/%E8%98%87%E8%B2%9E%E6%98%8C%E9%99%A2%E9%95%B7%E8%88%87%E5%9F%BA%E9%9A%86%E5%B8%82%E6%9E%97%E5%8F%B3%E6%98%8C%E5%B8%82%E9%95%B7%E4%B8%80%E5%90%8C%E7%99%BB%E4%B8%8A%E5%9F%BA%E9%9A%86%E7%87%88%E5%A1%94%E4%B8%A6%E5%90%88%E5%BD%B1%E7%95%99%E5%BF%B5%EF%BC%88cropped%EF%BC%89.jpg/340px-%E8%98%87%E8%B2%9E%E6%98%8C%E9%99%A2%E9%95%B7%E8%88%87%E5%9F%BA%E9%9A%86%E5%B8%82%E6%9E%97%E5%8F%B3%E6%98%8C%E5%B8%82%E9%95%B7%E4%B8%80%E5%90%8C%E7%99%BB%E4%B8%8A%E5%9F%BA%E9%9A%86%E7%87%88%E5%A1%94%E4%B8%A6%E5%90%88%E5%BD%B1%E7%95%99%E5%BF%B5%EF%BC%88cropped%EF%BC%89.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%E8%98%87%E8%B2%9E%E6%98%8C%E9%99%A2%E9%95%B7%E8%88%87%E5%9F%BA%E9%9A%86%E5%B8%82%E6%9E%97%E5%8F%B3%E6%98%8C%E5%B8%82%E9%95%B7%E4%B8%80%E5%90%8C%E7%99%BB%E4%B8%8A%E5%9F%BA%E9%9A%86%E7%87%88%E5%A1%94%E4%B8%A6%E5%90%88%E5%BD%B1%E7%95%99%E5%BF%B5%EF%BC%88cropped%EF%BC%89.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Su_Tseng-chang" title="Su Tseng-chang">Su Tseng-chang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Premier_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Premier of the Republic of China">Premier of the Republic of China</a></div></div></div>
<p>The premier is selected by the president without the need for approval from the legislature, but the legislature can pass laws without regard for the president, as neither he nor the Premier wields veto power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yb:government_290-3"><a href="#cite_note-yb:government-290">[273]</a></sup> Thus, there is little incentive for the president and the legislature to negotiate on legislation if they are of opposing parties. After the election of the pan-Green's Chen Shui-bian as president in 2000, legislation repeatedly stalled because of deadlock with the Legislative Yuan, which was controlled by a pan-Blue majority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[275]</a></sup> Historically, the ROC has been dominated by strongman single party politics. This legacy has resulted in executive powers currently being concentrated in the office of the president rather than the premier, even though the constitution does not explicitly state the extent of the president's executive power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[276]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Judicial Yuan is the highest <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">judicial</a> organ. It interprets the constitution and other laws and decrees, judges administrative suits, and disciplines public functionaries. The president and vice-president of the Judicial Yuan and additional thirteen justices form the Council of Grand Justices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[277]</a></sup> They are nominated and appointed by the president, with the consent of the Legislative Yuan. The highest court, the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Supreme Court of the Republic of China">Supreme Court</a>, consists of a number of civil and criminal divisions, each of which is formed by a presiding judge and four associate judges, all appointed for life. In 1993, a separate <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_constitutional_courts" title="List of constitutional courts">constitutional court</a> was established to resolve constitutional disputes, regulate the activities of political parties and accelerate the democratization process. There is no <a href="/wiki/Jury_trial" title="Jury trial">trial by jury</a> but the right to a fair public trial is protected by law and respected in practice; many cases are presided over by multiple judges.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yb:government_290-4"><a href="#cite_note-yb:government-290">[273]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Control Yuan is a watchdog agency that monitors (controls) the actions of the executive. It can be considered a standing <a href="/wiki/Government_agency" title="Government agency">commission</a> for administrative inquiry and can be compared to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Court_of_Auditors" title="Court of Auditors">Court of Auditors</a> of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> or the <a href="/wiki/Government_Accountability_Office" title="Government Accountability Office">Government Accountability Office</a> of the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yb:government_290-5"><a href="#cite_note-yb:government-290">[273]</a></sup> It is also responsible for the <a href="/wiki/National_Human_Rights_Commission_(Taiwan)" title="National Human Rights Commission (Taiwan)">National Human Rights Commission</a>.
</p><p>The Examination Yuan is in charge of validating the qualification of civil servants. It is based on the old <a href="/wiki/Imperial_examination" title="Imperial examination">imperial examination</a> system used in dynastic China. It can be compared to the <a href="/wiki/European_Personnel_Selection_Office" title="European Personnel Selection Office">European Personnel Selection Office</a> of the European Union or the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Office_of_Personnel_Management" title="Office of Personnel Management">Office of Personnel Management</a> of the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yb:government_290-6"><a href="#cite_note-yb:government-290">[273]</a></sup> It was downsized in 2019, and there have been calls for its abolition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2020amend_295-0"><a href="#cite_note-2020amend-295">[278]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[279]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Constitution">Constitution</span></h3>
<p>The constitution was drafted in by the KMT while the ROC still governed the Chinese mainland, went into effect on 25 December 1947.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[280]</a></sup> The ROC remained under martial law from 1948 until 1987 and much of the constitution was not in effect.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[282]</a></sup> Political reforms beginning in the late 1970s resulted in the end of martial law in 1987, and Taiwan transformed into a multiparty democracy in the early 1990s. The constitutional basis for this transition to democracy was gradually laid in the Additional Articles of the Constitution of the Republic of China. In addition, these articles localized the Constitution by suspending portions of the Constitution designed for the governance of mainland China and replacing them with articles adapted for the governance of and guaranteeing the political rights of residents of the Taiwan Area, as defined in the Act Governing Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[283]</a></sup>
</p><p>National boundaries were not explicitly prescribed by the 1947 Constitution, and the Constitutional Court declined to define these boundaries in a 1993 interpretation, viewing the question as a political question to be resolved by the Executive and Legislative Yuans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[284]</a></sup> The 1947 Constitution included articles regarding representatives from former Qing dynasty territories including <a href="/wiki/Tibet" title="Tibet">Tibet</a> and Mongolia (though it did not specify whether this excluded Outer Mongolia).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[285]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[286]</a></sup> The ROC recognized <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a> as an independent country in 1946 after signing the 1945 <a href="/wiki/Sino-Soviet_Treaty_of_Friendship_and_Alliance" title="Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance">Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance</a>, but after retreating to Taiwan in 1949 it reneged on its agreement in order to preserve its claim over mainland China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[287]</a></sup> The Additional Articles of the 1990s did not alter national boundaries, but suspended articles regarding Mongolian and Tibetan representatives. The ROC began to accept the Mongolian passport and removed clauses referring to Outer Mongolia from the Act Governing Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area in 2002.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[288]</a></sup> In 2012 the Mainland Affairs Council issued a statement clarifying that Outer Mongolia was not part of the ROC's national territory in 1947,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[289]</a></sup> and that the termination of the Sino-Soviet Treaty had not altered national territory according to the Constitution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mongolia_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mongolia-307">[290]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Mongolian_and_Tibetan_Affairs_Commission" title="Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission">Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission</a> in the Executive Yuan was abolished in 2017.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Major_camps">Major camps</span></h3>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:208px;max-width:208px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:102px;max-width:102px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:DPP-Taiwan.png"><img alt='A circular logo representing the island of Taiwan surrounded by the text "DEMOCRATIC PROGRESSIVE PARTY" and "民主進步黨"' data-file-height="800" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/DPP-Taiwan.png/100px-DPP-Taiwan.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/DPP-Taiwan.png/150px-DPP-Taiwan.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/DPP-Taiwan.png/200px-DPP-Taiwan.png 2x" width="100"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Progressive_Party" title="Democratic Progressive Party">Democratic Progressive Party</a>, the main <a href="/wiki/Pan-Green_Coalition" title="Pan-Green Coalition">Pan-Green Coalition</a> party</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:102px;max-width:102px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Emblem_of_the_Kuomintang.svg"><img alt="A circular logo representing a white sun on a blue background. The sun is a circle surrounded by twelve triangles." data-file-height="600" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Emblem_of_the_Kuomintang.svg/100px-Emblem_of_the_Kuomintang.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Emblem_of_the_Kuomintang.svg/150px-Emblem_of_the_Kuomintang.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Emblem_of_the_Kuomintang.svg/200px-Emblem_of_the_Kuomintang.svg.png 2x" width="100"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Emblem of the <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang" title="Kuomintang">Kuomintang</a>, the main <a href="/wiki/Pan-Blue_Coalition" title="Pan-Blue Coalition">Pan-Blue Coalition</a> party</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Taiwan's political scene is divided into two major camps in terms of cross-Strait relations, i.e. how Taiwan should relate to China or the PRC. The Pan-Green Coalition (e.g. the Democratic Progressive Party) leans pro-independence, and the Pan-Blue Coalition (e.g. the Kuomintang) leans pro-unification. Moderates in both camps regard the Republic of China as a sovereign independent state, but the Pan-Green Coalition regard the ROC as <a href="/wiki/Four-Stage_Theory_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Four-Stage Theory of the Republic of China">synonymous with Taiwan</a>, while moderates in the Pan-Blue Coalition view it as <a href="/wiki/1992_Consensus" title="1992 Consensus">synonymous with China</a>. These positions formed against the backdrop of the PRC's <a href="/wiki/Anti-Secession_Law" title="Anti-Secession Law">Anti-Secession Law</a>, which threatens invasion in the event of formal independence.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%E4%B8%AD%E8%8F%AF%E6%B0%91%E5%9C%8B%E7%AC%AC%E4%B8%80%E4%BD%8D%E6%B0%91%E9%81%B8%E9%A6%96%E9%83%BD%E5%B8%82%E9%95%B7%E5%90%B3%E4%B8%89%E9%80%A3%E6%96%BC1951%E5%B9%B4%E5%8B%9D%E9%81%B8%E5%BE%8C_First_People-elected_Mayor_of_Taipei,_the_Capital_of_TAIWAN.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="474" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="174" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/%E4%B8%AD%E8%8F%AF%E6%B0%91%E5%9C%8B%E7%AC%AC%E4%B8%80%E4%BD%8D%E6%B0%91%E9%81%B8%E9%A6%96%E9%83%BD%E5%B8%82%E9%95%B7%E5%90%B3%E4%B8%89%E9%80%A3%E6%96%BC1951%E5%B9%B4%E5%8B%9D%E9%81%B8%E5%BE%8C_First_People-elected_Mayor_of_Taipei%2C_the_Capital_of_TAIWAN.jpg/220px-%E4%B8%AD%E8%8F%AF%E6%B0%91%E5%9C%8B%E7%AC%AC%E4%B8%80%E4%BD%8D%E6%B0%91%E9%81%B8%E9%A6%96%E9%83%BD%E5%B8%82%E9%95%B7%E5%90%B3%E4%B8%89%E9%80%A3%E6%96%BC1951%E5%B9%B4%E5%8B%9D%E9%81%B8%E5%BE%8C_First_People-elected_Mayor_of_Taipei%2C_the_Capital_of_TAIWAN.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/%E4%B8%AD%E8%8F%AF%E6%B0%91%E5%9C%8B%E7%AC%AC%E4%B8%80%E4%BD%8D%E6%B0%91%E9%81%B8%E9%A6%96%E9%83%BD%E5%B8%82%E9%95%B7%E5%90%B3%E4%B8%89%E9%80%A3%E6%96%BC1951%E5%B9%B4%E5%8B%9D%E9%81%B8%E5%BE%8C_First_People-elected_Mayor_of_Taipei%2C_the_Capital_of_TAIWAN.jpg/330px-%E4%B8%AD%E8%8F%AF%E6%B0%91%E5%9C%8B%E7%AC%AC%E4%B8%80%E4%BD%8D%E6%B0%91%E9%81%B8%E9%A6%96%E9%83%BD%E5%B8%82%E9%95%B7%E5%90%B3%E4%B8%89%E9%80%A3%E6%96%BC1951%E5%B9%B4%E5%8B%9D%E9%81%B8%E5%BE%8C_First_People-elected_Mayor_of_Taipei%2C_the_Capital_of_TAIWAN.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/%E4%B8%AD%E8%8F%AF%E6%B0%91%E5%9C%8B%E7%AC%AC%E4%B8%80%E4%BD%8D%E6%B0%91%E9%81%B8%E9%A6%96%E9%83%BD%E5%B8%82%E9%95%B7%E5%90%B3%E4%B8%89%E9%80%A3%E6%96%BC1951%E5%B9%B4%E5%8B%9D%E9%81%B8%E5%BE%8C_First_People-elected_Mayor_of_Taipei%2C_the_Capital_of_TAIWAN.jpg/440px-%E4%B8%AD%E8%8F%AF%E6%B0%91%E5%9C%8B%E7%AC%AC%E4%B8%80%E4%BD%8D%E6%B0%91%E9%81%B8%E9%A6%96%E9%83%BD%E5%B8%82%E9%95%B7%E5%90%B3%E4%B8%89%E9%80%A3%E6%96%BC1951%E5%B9%B4%E5%8B%9D%E9%81%B8%E5%BE%8C_First_People-elected_Mayor_of_Taipei%2C_the_Capital_of_TAIWAN.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%E4%B8%AD%E8%8F%AF%E6%B0%91%E5%9C%8B%E7%AC%AC%E4%B8%80%E4%BD%8D%E6%B0%91%E9%81%B8%E9%A6%96%E9%83%BD%E5%B8%82%E9%95%B7%E5%90%B3%E4%B8%89%E9%80%A3%E6%96%BC1951%E5%B9%B4%E5%8B%9D%E9%81%B8%E5%BE%8C_First_People-elected_Mayor_of_Taipei,_the_Capital_of_TAIWAN.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Taiwanese-born <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tangwai" title="Tangwai">Tangwai</a> ("independent") politician Wu San-lien (second left) celebrates with supporters his victory in Taipei's first mayoral election in 1951.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Pan-Green_Coalition" title="Pan-Green Coalition">Pan-Green Coalition</a> is mainly led by the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party and <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Statebuilding_Party" title="Taiwan Statebuilding Party">Taiwan Statebuilding Party</a> (TSP). They oppose the idea that Taiwan is part of China, and seek wide diplomatic recognition and an eventual declaration of formal <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taiwan_independence" title="Taiwan independence">Taiwan independence</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[291]</a></sup> In September 2007, the then ruling Democratic Progressive Party approved a resolution asserting separate identity from China and called for the enactment of a new constitution for a "<i>normal country</i>". It called also for general use of "<i>Taiwan</i>" as the country's name, without abolishing its formal name, the "Republic of China".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[292]</a></sup> The name "Taiwan" has been used increasingly often after the emergence of the Taiwanese independence movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT2008_197-2"><a href="#cite_note-NYT2008-197">[180]</a></sup> Some members of the coalition, such as former President Chen Shui-bian, argue that it is unnecessary to proclaim independence because "Taiwan is already an independent, sovereign country" and the Republic of China is the same as Taiwan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[293]</a></sup> Despite being a member of KMT prior to and during his presidency, Lee Teng-hui also held a similar view and was a supporter of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taiwanization" title="Taiwanization">Taiwanization</a> movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[294]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Pan-Blue_Coalition" title="Pan-Blue Coalition">Pan-Blue Coalition</a>, composed of the pro-unification Kuomintang, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/People_First_Party_(Republic_of_China)" title="People First Party (Republic of China)">People First Party</a> (PFP) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Party_(Republic_of_China)" title="New Party (Republic of China)">New Party</a> generally support the spirit of the 1992 Consensus, where the KMT claimed that there is one China, but that the ROC and PRC have different interpretations of what "China" means. They favour eventual re-unification of China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-panblue-reunif-chineseid_312-0"><a href="#cite_note-panblue-reunif-chineseid-312">[295]</a></sup> Regarding independence, the mainstream Pan-Blue position is to maintain the status quo, while refusing immediate reunification.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[296]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[297]</a></sup> President Ma Ying-jeou stated that there will be no unification nor declaration of independence during his presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MasClaimtoMainland_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-MasClaimtoMainland-315">[298]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chinapost.com.tw_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-chinapost.com.tw-316">[299]</a></sup> As of 2009<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Taiwan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Pan-Blue members usually seek to improve relationships with PRC, with a current focus on improving economic ties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[300]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="National_identity">National identity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_people#The_current_state_of_Taiwanese_identity" title="Taiwanese people">Taiwanese people § The current state of Taiwanese identity</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Opinion_polling_on_Taiwanese_identity" title="Opinion polling on Taiwanese identity">Opinion polling on Taiwanese identity</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:National_Chengchi_University_identity_survey.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/National_Chengchi_University_identity_survey.svg/330px-National_Chengchi_University_identity_survey.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/National_Chengchi_University_identity_survey.svg/495px-National_Chengchi_University_identity_survey.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/National_Chengchi_University_identity_survey.svg/660px-National_Chengchi_University_identity_survey.svg.png 2x" width="330"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:National_Chengchi_University_identity_survey.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Results from an identity survey conducted each year from 1992 to 2020 by the Election Study Center, <a href="/wiki/National_Chengchi_University" title="National Chengchi University">National Chengchi University</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nccu_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-nccu-318">[301]</a></sup> Responses are Taiwanese (green), Chinese (red) or Both Taiwanese and Chinese (hatched). No response is shown as grey.</div></div></div>
<p>Roughly 84 per cent of Taiwan's population are descendants of Han Chinese immigrants from Qing China between 1683 and 1895. Another significant fraction descends from Han Chinese who immigrated from mainland China in the late 1940s and early 1950s. The shared cultural origin combined with several hundred years of geographical separation, some hundred years of political separation and foreign influences, as well as hostility between the rival ROC and PRC have resulted in national identity being a contentious issue with political overtones.
</p><p>Since democratic reforms and the lifting of martial law, a distinct Taiwanese identity (as opposed to Taiwanese identity as a subset of a Chinese identity) is often at the heart of political debates. Its acceptance makes the island distinct from mainland China, and therefore may be seen as a step towards forming a consensus for <i>de jure</i> Taiwan independence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-power-shift_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-power-shift-319">[302]</a></sup> The Pan-Green camp supports a predominantly Taiwanese identity (although "Chinese" may be viewed as cultural heritage), while the Pan-Blue camp supports a predominantly Chinese identity (with "Taiwanese" as a regional/diasporic Chinese identity).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-panblue-reunif-chineseid_312-1"><a href="#cite_note-panblue-reunif-chineseid-312">[295]</a></sup> The KMT has downplayed this stance in the recent years and now supports a Taiwanese identity as part of a Chinese identity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[303]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[304]</a></sup>
</p><p>In annual polls conducted by National Chengchi University, Taiwanese identification has increased substantially since the early 1990s, while Chinese identification has fallen to a low level, and identification as both has also seen a reduction. In 1992, 17.6 percent of respondents identified as Taiwanese, 25.5 percent as Chinese, 46.4 percent as both, and 10.5 percent non-response. In June 2021, 63.3 percent identified as Taiwanese, 2.6 percent as Chinese, 31.4 percent as both, and 2.7 percent non-response.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nccu_318-1"><a href="#cite_note-nccu-318">[301]</a></sup> A survey conducted in Taiwan by Global Views Survey Research Center in July 2009 showed that 82.8 percent of respondents consider the ROC and the PRC as two separate countries with each developing on its own but 80.2 percent think they are members of the Chinese.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[305]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Taiwan" title="Administrative divisions of Taiwan">Administrative divisions of Taiwan</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_administrative_divisions_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)" title="History of the administrative divisions of China (1912–1949)">History of the administrative divisions of China (1912–1949)</a></div>
<table>
<tbody><tr>
<td><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ROC_Administrative_and_Claims.svg"><img alt='A map showing the island of Taiwan, China and Mongolia. Taiwan and other nearby small islands are highlighted in dark blue and are identified as the "Free Area" of the ROC. China is highlighted in light blue and is identified as an area claimed by the ROC and controlled by the PRC. Mongolia is highlighted in red. Other minor areas are highlighted in different colors for having historically been claimed by the ROC but are now controlled by other countries including Russia, Japan or Pakistan among others.' class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="754" decoding="async" height="199" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/ROC_Administrative_and_Claims.svg/250px-ROC_Administrative_and_Claims.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/ROC_Administrative_and_Claims.svg/375px-ROC_Administrative_and_Claims.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/ROC_Administrative_and_Claims.svg/500px-ROC_Administrative_and_Claims.svg.png 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ROC_Administrative_and_Claims.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A map showing the official divisions and territories historically claimed by the Republic of China, along with their status as of 2005.</div></div></div>
</td>
<td><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:272px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ROC_vs_PRC.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="918" data-file-width="1339" decoding="async" height="185" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/ROC_vs_PRC.svg/270px-ROC_vs_PRC.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/ROC_vs_PRC.svg/405px-ROC_vs_PRC.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/ROC_vs_PRC.svg/540px-ROC_vs_PRC.svg.png 2x" width="270"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ROC_vs_PRC.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map comparing political divisions as drawn by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%9349)" title="Republic of China (1912–49)">Republic of China</a> and the <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">People's Republic of China</a>.</div></div></div>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>According to the 1947 constitution, the territory of the ROC is according to its "existing national boundaries".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-constitution_323-0"><a href="#cite_note-constitution-323">[306]</a></sup> The ROC is, <i>de jure</i> constitutionally, divided into <a href="#History">provinces</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;"> [<a class="extiw" href="https://zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E7%9C%81_(%E4%B8%AD%E8%8F%AF%E6%B0%91%E5%9C%8B)" title="zh:省 (中華民國)">zh</a>]</span>, <a href="/wiki/Special_municipality_(Taiwan)" title="Special municipality (Taiwan)">special municipalities</a> (which are further divided into districts for local administration), and the province-level <a href="/wiki/Tibet_Area_(administrative_division)" title="Tibet Area (administrative division)">Tibet Area</a>. Each province is subdivided into <a href="/wiki/Provincial_city_(Taiwan)" title="Provincial city (Taiwan)">cities</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/County_(Taiwan)" title="County (Taiwan)">counties</a>, which are further divided into townships and county-administered cities, each having elected mayors and city councillors who share duties with the county. Some divisions are indigenous divisions which have different degrees of autonomy to standard ones. In addition, districts, cities and townships are further divided into villages and neighbourhoods. The provinces have been "streamlined" and are no longer functional.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[307]</a></sup> Similarly, <a href="/wiki/Banners_of_Inner_Mongolia" title="Banners of Inner Mongolia">banners</a> in both <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a> and mainland China (<a href="/wiki/Inner_Mongolia" title="Inner Mongolia">Inner Mongolia</a>) also existed, but they were abolished in 2006 and the ROC reaffirmed its recognition of Mongolia in 2002, as stipulated in the 1946 constitution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[308]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mongolia_307-1"><a href="#cite_note-Mongolia-307">[290]</a></sup>
</p><p>With provinces non-functional, Taiwan is, in practice, divided into 22 subnational divisions, each with a self-governing body led by an elected leader and a legislative body with elected members. Duties of local governments include social services, education, urban planning, public construction, water management, environmental protection, transport, public safety, and more. 
</p><p>When the ROC retreated to Taiwan in 1949, its claimed territory consisted of 35 provinces, 12 special municipalities, 1 special administrative region and 2 autonomous regions. However, since its retreat, the ROC has controlled only <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Province" title="Taiwan Province">Taiwan Province</a> and some islands of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fujian_Province,_Republic_of_China" title="Fujian Province, Republic of China">Fujian Province</a>. The ROC also controls the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pratas_Islands" title="Pratas Islands">Pratas Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taiping_Island" title="Taiping Island">Taiping Island</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Spratly_Islands" title="Spratly Islands">Spratly Islands</a>, which are part of the disputed <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea_Islands" title="South China Sea Islands">South China Sea Islands</a>. They were placed under <a href="/wiki/Kaohsiung" title="Kaohsiung">Kaohsiung</a> administration after the retreat to Taiwan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[310]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="text-align:center">

<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:234px; top:4px"><a href="/wiki/East_China_Sea" title="East China Sea"><span style="color:white;"><i>East China Sea</i></span></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:42px; top:232px"><a href="/wiki/Pescadores_Channel" title="Pescadores Channel"><span style="color:white;"><i>Pescadores <br/>Channel</i></span></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:183px; top:397px"><a href="/wiki/Bashi_Channel" title="Bashi Channel"><span style="color:white;"><i>Bashi  Channel</i></span></a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:234px; top:277px"><a href="/wiki/Philippine_Sea" title="Philippine Sea"><span style="color:white;"><i>Philippine Sea</i></span></a><br/><a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean"><span style="color:white;">(<i>Pacific  Ocean</i>)</span></a></div>
</div>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="5"><a href="/wiki/Free_area_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Free area of the Republic of China">Free area</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[i]</a></sup>
</td>
