<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-greek">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-a-330"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-a_330-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-a_330-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-a_330-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-a_330-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-a_330-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-a_330-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Has an elected executive and an elected legislative council.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-b-335"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-b_335-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-b_335-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-b_335-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Has an appointed district administrator for managing local affairs and carrying out tasks commissioned by superior agency.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-337"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-337">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Has an elected village administrator for managing local affairs and carrying out tasks commissioned by superior agency.</span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>
<p><br/>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_Armed_Forces" title="Republic of China Armed Forces">Republic of China Armed Forces</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_Military_Academy" title="Republic of China Military Academy">Republic of China Military Academy</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:05.25_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A6%96%E5%B0%8E%E6%BC%A2%E5%85%8933%E8%99%9F%E6%BC%94%E7%BF%92_(34750802021).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1365" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/05.25_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A6%96%E5%B0%8E%E6%BC%A2%E5%85%8933%E8%99%9F%E6%BC%94%E7%BF%92_%2834750802021%29.jpg/220px-05.25_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A6%96%E5%B0%8E%E6%BC%A2%E5%85%8933%E8%99%9F%E6%BC%94%E7%BF%92_%2834750802021%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/05.25_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A6%96%E5%B0%8E%E6%BC%A2%E5%85%8933%E8%99%9F%E6%BC%94%E7%BF%92_%2834750802021%29.jpg/330px-05.25_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A6%96%E5%B0%8E%E6%BC%A2%E5%85%8933%E8%99%9F%E6%BC%94%E7%BF%92_%2834750802021%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/05.25_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A6%96%E5%B0%8E%E6%BC%A2%E5%85%8933%E8%99%9F%E6%BC%94%E7%BF%92_%2834750802021%29.jpg/440px-05.25_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A6%96%E5%B0%8E%E6%BC%A2%E5%85%8933%E8%99%9F%E6%BC%94%E7%BF%92_%2834750802021%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:05.25_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A6%96%E5%B0%8E%E6%BC%A2%E5%85%8933%E8%99%9F%E6%BC%94%E7%BF%92_(34750802021).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Han_Kuang_Exercise" title="Han Kuang Exercise">Han Kuang Exercise</a> is the annual exercise of the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_Armed_Forces" title="Republic of China Armed Forces">ROC Armed Forces</a> for a possible attack from the PRC</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:IDF_Pre-production.jpg"><img alt="A light fighter aircraft on the ground with two men who are maintaining it." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="763" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/IDF_Pre-production.jpg/220px-IDF_Pre-production.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/IDF_Pre-production.jpg/330px-IDF_Pre-production.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/IDF_Pre-production.jpg/440px-IDF_Pre-production.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:IDF_Pre-production.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_Air_Force" title="Republic of China Air Force">Republic of China Air Force</a> <a href="/wiki/AIDC_F-CK-1_Ching-kuo" title="AIDC F-CK-1 Ching-kuo">indigenously produced fighter</a> airplane in <a href="/wiki/Ching_Chuan_Kang_Air_Base" title="Ching Chuan Kang Air Base">Ching Chuan Kang Air Base</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_Army" title="Republic of China Army">Republic of China Army</a> takes its roots in the <a href="/wiki/National_Revolutionary_Army" title="National Revolutionary Army">National Revolutionary Army</a>, which was established by <a href="/wiki/Sun_Yat-sen" title="Sun Yat-sen">Sun Yat-sen</a> in 1925 in <a href="/wiki/Guangdong" title="Guangdong">Guangdong</a> with a goal of reunifying China under the Kuomintang. When the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army" title="People's Liberation Army">People's Liberation Army</a> won the Chinese Civil War, much of the National Revolutionary Army retreated to Taiwan along with the government. It was later reformed into the Republic of China Army. Units which surrendered and remained in mainland China were either disbanded or incorporated into the People's Liberation Army.
</p><p>From 1949 to the 1970s, the primary mission of the Taiwanese military was to "retake mainland China" through Project National Glory. As this mission has transitioned away from attack because the relative strength of the PRC has massively increased, the ROC military has begun to shift emphasis from the traditionally dominant Army to the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_Air_Force" title="Republic of China Air Force">air force</a> and <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_Navy" title="Republic of China Navy">navy</a>. Control of the armed forces has also passed into the hands of the civilian government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-towards_339-0"><a href="#cite_note-towards-339">[311]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[312]</a></sup>
</p><p>The ROC began a series of force reduction plans since 1990s, <i>Jingshi An</i> (translated to streamlining program) was one of the programs to scale down its military from a level of 450,000 in 1997 to 380,000 in 2001.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[313]</a></sup> As of 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Taiwan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the total strength of the Armed Forces is capped at 215,000 with 90% manning ratio for volunteer military.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[314]</a></sup> Conscription remains universal for qualified males reaching age eighteen, but as a part of the reduction effort many are given the opportunity to fulfill their draft requirement through alternative service and are redirected to government agencies or arms related industries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[315]</a></sup> Taiwan cut compulsory military service to four months in 2013 but a proposal to extend military service is under consideration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[316]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[317]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[318]</a></sup> The military's reservists is around 2.5 million including first-wave reservists numbered at 300,000 as of 2022<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Taiwan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[319]</a></sup> Taiwan's defense spending as a percentage of its GDP has been trending downwards over the first two decades of the twenty-first century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[320]</a></sup> The ROC government spent approximately two percent of GDP on defense and failed to raise the spending as high as proposed three percent of GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[321]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[322]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[323]</a></sup> In 2022, Taiwan proposed 2.4 percent of projected GDP in defense spending for the following year, continued to remain below three percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[324]</a></sup>
</p><p>The ROC and the United States signed the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty in 1954, and established the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Taiwan_Defense_Command" title="United States Taiwan Defense Command">United States Taiwan Defense Command</a>. About 30,000 US troops were stationed in Taiwan, until the United States established diplomatic relations with the PRC in 1979.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[325]</a></sup> A significant amount of military hardware has been bought from the United States, and continues to be legally guaranteed by the <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Relations_Act" title="Taiwan Relations Act">Taiwan Relations Act</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TRA-review_258-1"><a href="#cite_note-TRA-review-258">[241]</a></sup> In the past, France and the Netherlands have also sold military weapons and hardware to the ROC, but they almost entirely stopped in the 1990s under pressure of the PRC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[326]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[327]</a></sup>
</p><p>There is no guarantee in the Taiwan Relations Act or any other treaty that the United States will defend Taiwan, even in the event of invasion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[328]</a></sup> The joint declaration on security between the US and Japan signed in 1996 may imply that Japan would be involved in any response. However, Japan has refused to stipulate whether the "area surrounding Japan" mentioned in the pact includes Taiwan, and the precise purpose of the pact is unclear.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[329]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Australia,_New_Zealand,_United_States_Security_Treaty" title="Australia, New Zealand, United States Security Treaty">Australia, New Zealand, United States Security Treaty</a> (ANZUS Treaty) may mean that other US allies, such as Australia, could theoretically be involved.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[330]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sei21_359-0"><a href="#cite_note-sei21-359">[331]</a></sup> While this would risk damaging economic ties with China,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[332]</a></sup> a conflict over Taiwan could lead to an economic blockade of China by a greater coalition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[333]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[334]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[335]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[336]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[337]</a></sup> President <a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a> stated that the United States will intervene if the PRC attempts to invade Taiwan on several occasions in 2021 and 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[338]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[339]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[340]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[341]</a></sup> However, when asked about the answer, the White House officials insisted that US policy on Taiwan has not changed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[342]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Taiwan" title="Economy of Taiwan">Economy of Taiwan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_Taiwan" title="Economic history of Taiwan">Economic history of Taiwan</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Economic_history">Economic history</span></h3>
<p>The quick industrialization and rapid growth of Taiwan during the latter half of the 20th century has been called the "Taiwan Miracle". Taiwan is one of the "Four Asian Tigers" alongside Hong Kong, South Korea and Singapore.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kaohsiung_harbour_skyline_2016.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1271" data-file-width="1920" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Kaohsiung_harbour_skyline_2016.jpg/220px-Kaohsiung_harbour_skyline_2016.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Kaohsiung_harbour_skyline_2016.jpg/330px-Kaohsiung_harbour_skyline_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Kaohsiung_harbour_skyline_2016.jpg/440px-Kaohsiung_harbour_skyline_2016.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kaohsiung_harbour_skyline_2016.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Port_of_Kaohsiung" title="Port of Kaohsiung">Port of Kaohsiung</a> is operated as the largest harbor in Taiwan</div></div></div>
<p>Japanese rule prior to and during World War II brought changes in the public and private sectors, most notably in the area of public works, which enabled rapid communications and facilitated transport throughout much of the island. The Japanese also improved public education and made it compulsory for all residents of Taiwan. By 1945, hyperinflation was in progress in mainland China and Taiwan as a result of the war with Japan. To isolate Taiwan from it, the Nationalist government created a new currency area for the island, and began a price stabilization program which helped to significantly slow inflation.
</p><p>When the KMT government fled to Taiwan it brought millions of <a href="/wiki/Tael" title="Tael">taels</a> (where 1 tael = 37.5 g or ~1.2 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Troy_ounce" title="Troy ounce">ozt</a>) of gold and the foreign currency reserve of mainland China, which, according to the KMT, stabilized prices and reduced hyperinflation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[343]</a></sup> Perhaps more importantly, as part of its retreat to Taiwan, the KMT brought the intellectual and business elites from mainland China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[344]</a></sup> The KMT government instituted many laws and <a href="/wiki/Land_reform" title="Land reform">land reforms</a> that it had never effectively enacted on mainland China. The government also implemented a policy of <a href="/wiki/Import_substitution_industrialization" title="Import substitution industrialization">import-substitution</a>, attempting to produce imported goods domestically.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[345]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1950, with the outbreak of the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a>, the United States began an aid programme which resulted in fully stabilized prices by 1952.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[346]</a></sup> Economic development was encouraged by American economic aid and programmes such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Joint_Commission_on_Rural_Reconstruction" title="Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction">Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction</a>, which turned the agricultural sector into the basis for later growth. Under the combined stimulus of the land reform and the agricultural development programmes, agricultural production increased at an average annual rate of 4 per cent from 1952 to 1959, which was greater than the population growth, 3.6 per cent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[347]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1962, Taiwan had a (nominal) per-capita gross national product (GNP) of $170, placing its economy on a par with those of the Democratic Republic of the Congo. On a <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> (PPP) basis, its GDP per capita in the early 1960s was $1,353 (in 1990 prices). By 2011 per-capita GNP, adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP), had risen to $37,000, contributing to a <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a> (HDI) equivalent to that of other developed countries. In 2019, the HDI calculated by Taiwan's government was the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_in_Asia_and_Oceania_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries in Asia and Oceania by Human Development Index">seventh-highest in the Asia-Pacific region</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HDI_2019_31-2"><a href="#cite_note-HDI_2019-31">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1974, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chiang_Ching-Kuo" title="Chiang Ching-Kuo">Chiang Ching-Kuo</a> implemented the <a href="/wiki/Ten_Major_Construction_Projects" title="Ten Major Construction Projects">Ten Major Construction Projects</a>, the transportation, energy, and basic industry infrastructure that helped Taiwan transform into its current export driven economy. Since the 1990s, a number of Taiwan-based technology firms have expanded their reach around the world. Well-known international technology companies headquartered in Taiwan include personal computer manufacturers <a href="/wiki/Acer_Inc." title="Acer Inc.">Acer Inc.</a> and <a href="/wiki/Asus" title="Asus">Asus</a>, mobile phone maker <a href="/wiki/HTC" title="HTC">HTC</a>, as well as electronics manufacturing giant <a href="/wiki/Foxconn" title="Foxconn">Foxconn</a>, which makes products for <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc." title="Apple Inc.">Apple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amazon_(company)" title="Amazon (company)">Amazon</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Microsoft" title="Microsoft">Microsoft</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1-376">[348]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Computex_Taipei" title="Computex Taipei">Computex</a> is a major computer convention, held annually in Taipei since 1981, and is attended by major tech companies like AMD and Nvidia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[349]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sun_Down_(250260941).jpeg"><img alt="Photo of Taipei 101 tower against a blue sky." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2048" data-file-width="1225" decoding="async" height="284" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Sun_Down_%28250260941%29.jpeg/170px-Sun_Down_%28250260941%29.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Sun_Down_%28250260941%29.jpeg/255px-Sun_Down_%28250260941%29.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Sun_Down_%28250260941%29.jpeg/340px-Sun_Down_%28250260941%29.jpeg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sun_Down_(250260941).jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Taipei_101" title="Taipei 101">Taipei 101</a> held the world record for the highest skyscraper from 2004 to 2010.</div></div></div>
<p>In 2001, agriculture constituted only 2 per cent of GDP, down from 35 per cent in 1952.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[350]</a></sup> Traditional labour-intensive industries are steadily being moved offshore and with more capital and technology-intensive industries replacing them. High-technology industrial parks have sprung up in every region in Taiwan. The ROC has become a major foreign investor in the PRC, Thailand, Indonesia, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Vietnam. It is estimated that some 50,000 Taiwanese businesses and 1,000,000 businesspeople and their dependents are established in the PRC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[351]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the beginning of the 1990s, the economic ties between Taiwan and the People's Republic of China have been extensive. As of 2008<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Taiwan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, more than US$150 billion<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[352]</a></sup> have been invested in the PRC by Taiwanese companies. Although the economy of Taiwan benefits from this situation, some have expressed the view that the island has become increasingly dependent on the mainland Chinese economy. A 2008 white paper by the Department of Industrial Technology states that "Taiwan should seek to maintain stable relation with China while continuing to protect national security, and avoiding excessive 'Sinicization' of Taiwanese economy."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[353]</a></sup> Others argue that close economic ties between Taiwan and mainland China would make any military intervention by the PLA against Taiwan very costly, and therefore less probable.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[354]</a></sup>
</p><p>Today Taiwan has a dynamic, <a href="/wiki/Capitalism" title="Capitalism">capitalist</a>, export-driven economy with gradually decreasing state involvement in investment and foreign trade. In keeping with this trend, some large government-owned banks and industrial firms are being <a href="/wiki/Privatization" title="Privatization">privatized</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[355]</a></sup> Real growth in GDP has averaged about 8 per cent during the past three decades. Exports have provided the primary impetus for industrialization. The trade surplus is substantial, and foreign reserves are the world's fifth largest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[356]</a></sup> The official currency of Taiwan by the ROC is the <a href="/wiki/New_Taiwan_dollar" title="New Taiwan dollar">New Taiwan dollar</a>. Taiwan's total trade in 2010 reached an all-time high of US$526.04 billion, according to Taiwan's Ministry of Finance. Both exports and imports for the year reached record levels, totaling US$274.64 billion and US$251.4 billion, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[357]</a></sup>
</p><p>Because of its conservative financial approach and its entrepreneurial strengths, Taiwan suffered little compared with many of its neighbours in the <a href="/wiki/1997_Asian_financial_crisis" title="1997 Asian financial crisis">1997 Asian financial crisis</a>. Unlike its neighbours, South Korea and Japan, the Taiwanese economy is dominated by small and medium-sized businesses, rather than the large business groups. The global economic downturn, however, combined with poor policy co-ordination by the new administration and increasing bad debts in the banking system, pushed Taiwan into <a href="/wiki/Recession" title="Recession">recession</a> in 2001, the first whole year of negative growth since 1947. Due to the relocation of many manufacturing and labour-intensive industries to the PRC, unemployment also reached a level not seen since the 1970s oil crisis. This became a major issue in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2004_Republic_of_China_presidential_election" title="2004 Republic of China presidential election">2004 presidential election</a>. Growth averaged more than 4 per cent in the 2002–2006 period and the unemployment rate fell below 4 per cent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[358]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="High-tech_manufacturing">High-tech manufacturing</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:TSMC_Fab5.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1339" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/TSMC_Fab5.JPG/220px-TSMC_Fab5.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/TSMC_Fab5.JPG/330px-TSMC_Fab5.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/TSMC_Fab5.JPG/440px-TSMC_Fab5.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:TSMC_Fab5.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/TSMC" title="TSMC">TSMC</a> fab 5 located in <a href="/wiki/Hsinchu_Science_Park" title="Hsinchu Science Park">Hsinchu Science Park</a></div></div></div>
<p>Taiwan's rise in the key semiconductor industry was largely attributed to <a href="/wiki/TSMC" title="TSMC">Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.</a> (TSMC) and <a href="/wiki/United_Microelectronics_Corporation" title="United Microelectronics Corporation">United Microelectronic Corporation</a> (UMC).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[359]</a></sup> TSMC was founded 21 February 1987 and as of December 2021 its <a href="/wiki/Market_capitalization" title="Market capitalization">market capitalization</a> equated to roughly 90% of Taiwan's GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[360]</a></sup> The company is the 9th largest in the world by market capitalization<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[361]</a></sup> as well as the world's biggest semiconductor manufacturing company, surpassing <a href="/wiki/Intel" title="Intel">Intel</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samsung_Semiconductor_Inc." title="Samsung Semiconductor Inc.">Samsung</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[362]</a></sup>  Its major customers include <a href="/wiki/Qualcomm" title="Qualcomm">Qualcomm</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nvidia" title="Nvidia">Nvidia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Broadcom_Inc." title="Broadcom Inc.">Broadcom</a>, Intel, <a href="/wiki/Advanced_Micro_Devices" title="Advanced Micro Devices">AMD</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc." title="Apple Inc.">Apple Inc.</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ampere_Computing" title="Ampere Computing">Ampere</a>, <a href="/wiki/Microsoft" title="Microsoft">Microsoft</a>, <a href="/wiki/MediaTek" title="MediaTek">MediaTek</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sony" title="Sony">Sony</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[363]</a></sup> In 2018, the company's <a href="/wiki/7_nm_process" title="7 nm process">N7+</a> node became the first commercial node to be made with <a href="/wiki/Extreme_ultraviolet_lithography" title="Extreme ultraviolet lithography">EUV</a> <a href="/wiki/Lithography" title="Lithography">lithography</a>, as well its N7 node being the first sub-10 nm node to enter volume production.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[364]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[365]</a></sup> TSMC was the first Taiwanese company to be listed on the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange" title="New York Stock Exchange">New York Stock Exchange</a>, under the trade name <a class="external text" href="https://www.nyse.com/quote/XNYS:TSM" rel="nofollow">NYSE: TSM</a>, in October 1997.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[366]</a></sup>
</p><p>UMC, another major company in Taiwan's high-tech exports and global semiconductors, does not however, compete with TSMC on advance semiconductor processes. Instead it competes with the American <a href="/wiki/GlobalFoundries" title="GlobalFoundries">GlobalFoundries</a>, and others, for less advanced semiconductor processes and for silicon wafers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[367]</a></sup> Its major customers include, MediaTek, <a href="/wiki/Texas_Instruments" title="Texas Instruments">Texas Instruments</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Realtek" title="Realtek">Realtek</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[368]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Foxconn" title="Foxconn">Foxconn</a>, a major smart-device manufacturer, is headquartered in New Taipei City.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[369]</a></sup> It is also listed in the <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Stock_Exchange" title="Taiwan Stock Exchange">Taiwan Stock Exchange</a> under the trade name <a class="external text" href="https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/2317.TW/" rel="nofollow">Hon Hai Precision Industry</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[370]</a></sup> Most of its factories are located in East Asia, with a majority of 12 factories located in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[371]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[372]</a></sup> Its major customers include Apple, Microsoft, Amazon, Google, and <a href="/wiki/Huawei" title="Huawei">Huawei</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_376-1"><a href="#cite_note-:1-376">[348]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="International_participation">International participation</span></h3>
<p>The ROC often joins international organizations (especially ones that also include the People's Republic of China) under a politically neutral name. The ROC has been a member of governmental trade organizations such as the World Trade Organization under the name Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu (Chinese Taipei) since 2002.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[373]</a></sup> Taiwan has unofficial diplomatic offices for tourism and other economically related duties, mostly under a politically neutral name.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[374]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[375]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transportation_in_Taiwan" title="Transportation in Taiwan">Transportation in Taiwan</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:China_Airlines_Lineup_TPE.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/China_Airlines_Lineup_TPE.jpg/220px-China_Airlines_Lineup_TPE.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/China_Airlines_Lineup_TPE.jpg/330px-China_Airlines_Lineup_TPE.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/China_Airlines_Lineup_TPE.jpg/440px-China_Airlines_Lineup_TPE.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:China_Airlines_Lineup_TPE.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/China_Airlines" title="China Airlines">China Airlines</a> aircraft line-up at <a href="/wiki/Taoyuan_International_Airport" title="Taoyuan International Airport">Taoyuan International Airport</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Transportation_and_Communications_(Republic_of_China)" title="Ministry of Transportation and Communications (Republic of China)">Ministry of Transportation and Communications</a> of the Republic of China is the cabinet-level governing body of the transport network in Taiwan.
</p><p>Civilian transport in Taiwan is characterised by extensive use of <a href="/wiki/Scooter_(motorcycle)" title="Scooter (motorcycle)">scooters</a>. In March 2019, 13.86 million were registered, twice that of cars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[376]</a></sup>
</p><p>Both highways and railways are concentrated near the coasts, where the majority of the population resides, with 1,619 km (1,006 mi) of <a href="/wiki/Controlled-access_highway" title="Controlled-access highway">motorway</a>.
</p><p>Railways in Taiwan are primarily used for passenger services, with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taiwan_Railway_Administration" title="Taiwan Railway Administration">Taiwan Railway Administration</a> (TRA) operating a circular route and <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_High_Speed_Rail" title="Taiwan High Speed Rail">Taiwan High Speed Rail</a> (THSR) running high speed services on the west coast. Urban transit systems include <a href="/wiki/Taipei_Metro" title="Taipei Metro">Taipei Metro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kaohsiung_Metro" title="Kaohsiung Metro">Kaohsiung Metro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taoyuan_Metro" title="Taoyuan Metro">Taoyuan Metro</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_Taipei_Metro" title="New Taipei Metro">New Taipei Metro</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Taichung_Metro" title="Taichung Metro">Taichung Metro</a>.
</p><p>Major airports include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taiwan_Taoyuan_International_Airport" title="Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport">Taiwan Taoyuan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kaohsiung_International_Airport" title="Kaohsiung International Airport">Kaohsiung</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taipei_Songshan_Airport" title="Taipei Songshan Airport">Taipei Songshan</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taichung_Airport" title="Taichung Airport">Taichung</a>. There are currently seven airlines in Taiwan, with the largest two being <a href="/wiki/China_Airlines" title="China Airlines">China Airlines</a> and <a href="/wiki/EVA_Air" title="EVA Air">EVA Air</a>.
</p><p>There are seven international seaports: <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Keelung" title="Port of Keelung">Keelung</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Taipei" title="Port of Taipei">Taipei</a>, Suao, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Taichung" title="Port of Taichung">Taichung</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Kaohsiung" title="Port of Kaohsiung">Kaohsiung</a>, <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Anping" title="Port of Anping">Anping</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Hualien" title="Port of Hualien">Hualien</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[377]</a></sup> The Port of Kaohsiung handled the largest volume of cargo in Taiwan, with about 440 million shipping tonnes, which accounted for 58.6% of Taiwan's total throughput in 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[378]</a></sup> The shipping tonnage followed by Taichung (18.6%), Taipei (12%) and Keelung (8.7%).
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Taiwan" title="Education in Taiwan">Education in Taiwan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Academia_Sinica" title="Academia Sinica">Academia Sinica</a>, and <a href="/wiki/History_of_education_in_Taiwan" title="History of education in Taiwan">History of education in Taiwan</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Scholarships_in_Taiwan" title="Scholarships in Taiwan">Scholarships in Taiwan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Taiwan#Science" title="Economy of Taiwan">Economy of Taiwan § Science</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%E8%87%BA%E7%81%A3%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%B8%E6%A0%A1%E9%96%80.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3872" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/%E8%87%BA%E7%81%A3%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%B8%E6%A0%A1%E9%96%80.JPG/220px-%E8%87%BA%E7%81%A3%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%B8%E6%A0%A1%E9%96%80.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/%E8%87%BA%E7%81%A3%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%B8%E6%A0%A1%E9%96%80.JPG/330px-%E8%87%BA%E7%81%A3%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%B8%E6%A0%A1%E9%96%80.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/%E8%87%BA%E7%81%A3%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%B8%E6%A0%A1%E9%96%80.JPG/440px-%E8%87%BA%E7%81%A3%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%B8%E6%A0%A1%E9%96%80.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%E8%87%BA%E7%81%A3%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%B8%E6%A0%A1%E9%96%80.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gate of <a href="/wiki/National_Taiwan_University" title="National Taiwan University">National Taiwan University</a>, the university was founded in 1928 during Japanese rule</div></div></div>
<p>Taiwan's higher education system was established by Japan during the colonial period. However, after the Republic of China took over in 1945, the system was promptly replaced by the same system as in mainland China which mixed features of the Chinese and American educational systems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[379]</a></sup>
</p><p>Taiwan is well known for adhering to the Confucian paradigm of valuing education as a means to improve one's socioeconomic position in society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[380]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto2_409-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-409">[381]</a></sup> Heavy investment and a cultural valuing of education has catapulted the resource-poor nation consistently to the top of global education rankings. Taiwan is one of the top-performing countries in reading literacy, mathematics and sciences. In 2015, Taiwanese students achieved one of the world's best results in mathematics, science and literacy, as tested by the <a href="/wiki/Programme_for_International_Student_Assessment" title="Programme for International Student Assessment">Programme for International Student Assessment</a> (PISA), with the average student scoring 519, compared with the OECD average of 493, placing it seventh in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[382]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[383]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[384]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Taiwanese education system has been praised for various reasons, including its comparatively high test results and its major role in promoting Taiwan's economic development while creating one of the world's most highly educated workforces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[385]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[386]</a></sup> Taiwan has also been praised for its high university entrance rate where the university acceptance rate has increased from around 20 per cent before the 1980s to 49 per cent in 1996 and over 95 per cent since 2008, among the highest in Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto3_415-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-415">[387]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[388]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto-417">[389]</a></sup> The nation's high university entrance rate has created a highly skilled workforce making Taiwan one of the most highly educated countries in the world with 68.5 per cent of Taiwanese high school students going on to attend university.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto1_418-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-418">[390]</a></sup> Taiwan has a high percentage of its citizens holding a tertiary education degree where 45 per cent of Taiwanese aged 25–64 hold a bachelor's degree or higher compared with the average of 33 per cent among member countries of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_417-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto-417">[389]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[391]</a></sup>
</p><p>On the other hand, the system has been criticised for placing excessive pressure on students while eschewing creativity and producing an excess supply of over-educated university graduates and a high graduate unemployment rate. With a large number of university graduates seeking a limited number of prestigious white collar jobs in an economic environment that is increasingly losing its competitive edge, this has led many graduates to be employed in lower-end jobs with salaries far beneath their expectations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[392]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto2_409-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto2-409">[381]</a></sup> Taiwan's universities have also been under criticism for not being able to fully meet the requirements and demands of Taiwan's 21st-century fast-moving labour market, citing a skills mismatch among a large number of self-assessed, overeducated university graduates who do not fit the demands of the modern Taiwanese labour market.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[393]</a></sup> The Taiwanese government has also received criticism for undermining the economy as it has been unable to produce enough jobs to meet the demands of numerous underemployed university graduates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto3_415-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-415">[387]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[394]</a></sup>
</p><p>As the Taiwanese economy is largely science and technology based, the labour market demands people who have achieved some form of higher education, particularly related to science and engineering to gain a competitive edge when searching for employment. Although current Taiwanese law mandates only nine years of schooling, 95 per cent of junior high graduates go on to attend a senior vocational high school, university, junior college, trade school, or other higher education institution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto1_418-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-418">[390]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[395]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since <a href="/wiki/Made_in_China_2025" title="Made in China 2025">Made in China 2025</a> was announced in 2015, aggressive campaigns to recruit Taiwanese chip industry talent to support its mandates resulted in the loss of more than 3,000 chip engineers to mainland China,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nikkei_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nikkei-424">[396]</a></sup> and raised concerns of a "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brain_drain" title="Brain drain">brain drain</a>" in Taiwan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[397]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nikkei_424-1"><a href="#cite_note-Nikkei-424">[396]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[398]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many Taiwanese students attend <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cram_schools#Taiwan" title="Cram schools">cram schools</a>, or <i>buxiban</i>, to improve skills and knowledge on problem solving against exams of subjects like mathematics, nature science, history and many others. Courses are available for most popular subjects and include lectures, reviews, private tutorial sessions, and recitations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[399]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[400]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2020<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Taiwan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Literacy_rate" title="Literacy rate">literacy rate</a> in Taiwan was 99.03 percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[401]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Taiwan" title="Demographics of Taiwan">Demographics of Taiwan</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Taiwan_population_density_map.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1982" data-file-width="1440" decoding="async" height="303" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Taiwan_population_density_map.svg/220px-Taiwan_population_density_map.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Taiwan_population_density_map.svg/330px-Taiwan_population_density_map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Taiwan_population_density_map.svg/440px-Taiwan_population_density_map.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Taiwan_population_density_map.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Population density map of Taiwan (residents per square kilometre)</div></div></div>
<p>Taiwan has a population of about 23.4 million,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEExec._Yuan201436_430-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEExec._Yuan201436-430">[402]</a></sup> most of whom are on the island of Taiwan. The remainder live on the outlying islands of Penghu (101,758), Kinmen (127,723), and Matsu (12,506).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-taiwan-popstat_431-0"><a href="#cite_note-taiwan-popstat-431">[403]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Largest_cities_and_counties">Largest cities and counties</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Taiwan" title="List of cities in Taiwan">List of cities in Taiwan</a></div>
<p>The figures below are the March 2019 estimates for the twenty most populous administrative divisions; a different ranking exists when considering the total <a href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_Taiwan#Metropolitan_areas_in_Taiwan" title="List of metropolitan areas in Taiwan">metropolitan area populations</a> (in such rankings the <a href="/wiki/Taipei%E2%80%93Keelung_metropolitan_area" title="Taipei–Keelung metropolitan area">Taipei-Keelung metro area</a> is by far the largest agglomeration). The figures reflect the number of household registrations in each city, which may differ from the number of actual residents.
</p>
