<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_people" title="Taiwanese people">Taiwanese people</a>, <a href="/wiki/Han_Taiwanese" title="Han Taiwanese">Han Taiwanese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_indigenous_peoples" title="Taiwanese indigenous peoples">Taiwanese indigenous peoples</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Plains_indigenous_peoples" title="Plains indigenous peoples">Plains indigenous peoples</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Formosan_Distribution_01.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="267" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Formosan_Distribution_01.png/200px-Formosan_Distribution_01.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Formosan_Distribution_01.png/300px-Formosan_Distribution_01.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Formosan_Distribution_01.png/400px-Formosan_Distribution_01.png 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Formosan_Distribution_01.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Original geographic distributions of Taiwanese indigenous peoples</div></div></div>
<p>The ROC government reports that over 95 per cent of the population is <a href="/wiki/Han_Chinese" title="Han Chinese">Han</a>. The overwhelming majority of them (85 per cent) are descendants of <a href="/wiki/Hoklo_people" title="Hoklo people">Hoklo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hakka_people" title="Hakka people">Hakka</a> who arrived in large numbers in the 17th to 18th century. A minority (10 to 15 per cent) are <i><a href="/wiki/Waishengren" title="Waishengren">waishengren</a></i>, descendants of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_Nationalists" title="Chinese Nationalists">Chinese nationalists</a> who fled to Taiwan the end of the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a> in 1949. There are also 2 per cent indigenous Malayo-Polynesian peoples and 2 per cent new immigrants primarily from China and Southeast Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TWG2020_107-1"><a href="#cite_note-TWG2020-107">[90]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia-factbook_20-3"><a href="#cite_note-cia-factbook-20">[14]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Hoklo people are the largest ethnic group (70 per cent of the total population), whose ancestors migrated from the coastal southern Fujian region across the Taiwan Strait starting in the 17th century. The Hakka comprise about 15 per cent of the total population, and descend from Han migrants from eastern Guangdong.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[404]</a></sup>
</p><p>The indigenous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taiwanese_aborigines" title="Taiwanese aborigines">Taiwanese aborigines</a> number about 533,600, and the government recognises 16 groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEExec._Yuan201449_433-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEExec._Yuan201449-433">[405]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Amis_people" title="Amis people">Ami</a>, <a href="/wiki/Atayal_people" title="Atayal people">Atayal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bunun_people" title="Bunun people">Bunun</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kanakanavu_people" title="Kanakanavu people">Kanakanavu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kavalan_people" title="Kavalan people">Kavalan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paiwan_people" title="Paiwan people">Paiwan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puyuma_people" title="Puyuma people">Puyuma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rukai_people" title="Rukai people">Rukai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saisiyat_people" title="Saisiyat people">Saisiyat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saaroa_people" title="Saaroa people">Saaroa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sakizaya_people" title="Sakizaya people">Sakizaya</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sediq_people" title="Sediq people">Sediq</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thao_people" title="Thao people">Thao</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Truku_people" title="Truku people">Truku</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tsou_people" title="Tsou people">Tsou</a> live mostly in the eastern half of the island, while the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yami_people" title="Yami people">Yami</a> inhabit <a href="/wiki/Orchid_Island" title="Orchid Island">Orchid Island</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[406]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[407]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_the_most_commonly_used_home_language_in_Taiwan.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1300" data-file-width="960" decoding="async" height="379" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Map_of_the_most_commonly_used_home_language_in_Taiwan.svg/280px-Map_of_the_most_commonly_used_home_language_in_Taiwan.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Map_of_the_most_commonly_used_home_language_in_Taiwan.svg/420px-Map_of_the_most_commonly_used_home_language_in_Taiwan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Map_of_the_most_commonly_used_home_language_in_Taiwan.svg/560px-Map_of_the_most_commonly_used_home_language_in_Taiwan.svg.png 2x" width="280"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_the_most_commonly_used_home_language_in_Taiwan.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Most commonly used home language in each area, darker in proportion to the lead over the next most common<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#000080; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_Chinese" title="Mandarin Chinese">Mandarin Chinese</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#008000; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Hokkien" title="Hokkien">Hokkien</a> or Min Nan</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FF0066; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Hakka_Chinese" title="Hakka Chinese">Hakka Chinese</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#800000; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_languages" title="Austronesian languages">Austronesian languages</a></div></div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Taiwan" title="Languages of Taiwan">Languages of Taiwan</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_Mandarin" title="Taiwanese Mandarin">Mandarin</a> is the primary language used in business and education, and is spoken by the vast majority of the population. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese" title="Traditional Chinese">Traditional Chinese</a> is used as the writing system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yb-languages_436-0"><a href="#cite_note-yb-languages-436">[408]</a></sup> The Republic of China does not have any legally designated <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official language</a>, but <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_Mandarin" title="Taiwanese Mandarin">Mandarin</a> plays the role of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Defacto" title="Defacto">de facto</a> <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official language</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-推動雙語國家政策問題研析_5-1"><a href="#cite_note-推動雙語國家政策問題研析-5">[3]</a></sup>
</p><p>Around 70% of Taiwan's population belong to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hoklo" title="Hoklo">Hoklo</a> ethnic group and are speakers of <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_Hokkien" title="Taiwanese Hokkien">Taiwanese Hokkien</a> as native language.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[409]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hakka" title="Hakka">Hakka</a> group, comprising some 14–18 per cent of the population, speak <a href="/wiki/Hakka_Chinese" title="Hakka Chinese">Hakka</a>. Although Mandarin is the language of instruction in schools and dominates television and radio, non-Mandarin <a href="/wiki/Varieties_of_Chinese" title="Varieties of Chinese">Chinese varieties</a> have undergone a revival in public life in Taiwan, particularly since restrictions on their use were lifted in the 1990s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yb-languages_436-1"><a href="#cite_note-yb-languages-436">[408]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Formosan_languages" title="Formosan languages">Formosan languages</a> are spoken primarily by the indigenous peoples of Taiwan. They do not belong to the Chinese or Sino-Tibetan language family, but to the <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_languages" title="Austronesian languages">Austronesian language family</a>, and are written in <a href="/wiki/Writing_systems_of_Formosan_languages" title="Writing systems of Formosan languages">Latin alphabet</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[410]</a></sup> Their use among aboriginal minority groups has been in decline as usage of Mandarin has risen.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yb-languages_436-2"><a href="#cite_note-yb-languages-436">[408]</a></sup> Of the 14 extant languages, five are considered <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moribund_language" title="Moribund language">moribund</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[411]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Classical_Chinese">Classical Chinese</span></h4>
<p>Since the <a href="/wiki/May_Fourth_Movement" title="May Fourth Movement">May Fourth Movement</a>, <a href="/wiki/Written_vernacular_Chinese" title="Written vernacular Chinese">written vernacular Chinese</a> had replaced <a href="/wiki/Classical_Chinese" title="Classical Chinese">Classical Chinese</a> and emerged as the mainstream <a href="/wiki/Written_vernacular_Chinese" title="Written vernacular Chinese">written Chinese</a> in the Republic of China. But Classical Chinese continued to be widely used in the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Government of the Republic of China">Government of the Republic of China</a>. Most government documents in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_of_China" title="Republic of China">Republic of China</a> were written in Classical Chinese until reforms in the 1970s, in a reform movement spearheaded by President <a href="/wiki/Yen_Chia-kan" title="Yen Chia-kan">Yen Chia-kan</a> to shift the written style to a more integrated vernacular Chinese and Classical Chinese style (文白合一行文).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[412]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[413]</a></sup> After 1 January 2005, the <a href="/wiki/Executive_Yuan" title="Executive Yuan">Executive Yuan</a> also changed the long-standing official document writing habit from vertical writing style to horizontal writing style.
</p><p>Today, pure Classical Chinese is occasionally used in formal or ceremonial occasions, religious or cultural rites in Taiwan. The <i><a href="/wiki/National_Anthem_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="National Anthem of the Republic of China">National Anthem of the Republic of China</a></i> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hant-TW">中華民國國歌</span></span>), for example, is in Classical Chinese. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taoist" title="Taoist">Taoist</a> texts are still preserved in Classical Chinese from the time they were composed. <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhist</a> texts, or <a href="/wiki/Sutra" title="Sutra">sutras</a>, are still preserved in Classical Chinese from the time they were composed or translated from <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> sources. In practice there is a socially accepted continuum between vernacular Chinese and Classical Chinese. Most official <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Government of the Republic of China">government</a> documents, <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Taiwan" title="Law of Taiwan">legal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Supreme Court of the Republic of China">courts rulings</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Justice_(Taiwan)" title="Ministry of Justice (Taiwan)">judiciary</a> documents use a combined vernacular Chinese and Classical Chinese style (文白合一行文).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[414]</a></sup> For example, most official notices and formal letters are written with a number of stock Classical Chinese expressions (e.g. salutation, closing). Personal letters, on the other hand, are mostly written in vernacular, but with some Classical phrases, depending on the subject matter, the writer's level of education, etc.
</p><p>As many legal documents are still written in Classical Chinese, which is not easily understood by the general public, a group of Taiwanese had launched the <i>Legal Vernacular Movement</i> hoping to bring more Vernacular Chinese into the legal writings of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_of_China" title="Republic of China">Republic of China</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[415]</a></sup>
</p><p>Taiwan is officially multilingual. A national language in Taiwan is legally defined as "a natural language used by an original people group of Taiwan and the <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Sign_Language" title="Taiwan Sign Language">Taiwan Sign Language</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-natLangAct_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-natLangAct-15">[11]</a></sup> As of 2019, policies on national languages are in early stages of implementation, with Hakka and indigenous languages designated as such.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Taiwan" title="Religion in Taiwan">Religion in Taiwan</a></div>
<div class="PieChartTemplate thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px">
<div class="mw-no-invert" style="background-color:white;margin:auto;position:relative;width:200px;height:200px;overflow:hidden;border-radius:100px;border:1px solid black;transform:scaleX(-1)rotate(-90deg)">
<div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:0; top:0; border-width:0 200px 200px 0; border-color:GreenYellow"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:0; top:0; border-width:0 200px 200px 0; border-color:DodgerBlue"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 262.14865391968px; border-left-color:Honeydew"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Honeydew"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Honeydew"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 36.002215309576px; border-left-color:Blue"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Blue"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Blue"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:100px; border-width:80.901699437495px 58.778525229247px 0 0; border-top-color:Crimson"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Crimson"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:0; border-width:0 243.58297171766px 100px 0; border-right-color:Yellow"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;right:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 100px 0;border-color:Yellow"></div>
</div>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<p>Estimated religious composition in 2020<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pew_religion_stats_19-1"><a href="#cite_note-Pew_religion_stats-19">[13]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Yellow; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Chinese_folk_religion" title="Chinese folk religion">Chinese folk religion</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a>) (43.8%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Crimson; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Taiwan" title="Buddhism in Taiwan">Buddhists</a> (21.2%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Blue; color:white;"> </span> Others (including <a href="/wiki/Taoism" title="Taoism">Taoists</a>) (15.5%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Honeydew; color:black;"> </span> Unaffiliated (13.7%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:DodgerBlue; color:black;"> </span> Christians (5.8%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:GreenYellow; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Taiwan" title="Islam in Taiwan">Muslims</a> (1%)</div>
</div>
</div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%E8%90%AC%E5%92%8C%E5%AE%AE%E4%B9%8B%E7%BE%8E-.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2856" data-file-width="4284" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/%E8%90%AC%E5%92%8C%E5%AE%AE%E4%B9%8B%E7%BE%8E-.jpg/220px-%E8%90%AC%E5%92%8C%E5%AE%AE%E4%B9%8B%E7%BE%8E-.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/%E8%90%AC%E5%92%8C%E5%AE%AE%E4%B9%8B%E7%BE%8E-.jpg/330px-%E8%90%AC%E5%92%8C%E5%AE%AE%E4%B9%8B%E7%BE%8E-.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/%E8%90%AC%E5%92%8C%E5%AE%AE%E4%B9%8B%E7%BE%8E-.jpg/440px-%E8%90%AC%E5%92%8C%E5%AE%AE%E4%B9%8B%E7%BE%8E-.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%E8%90%AC%E5%92%8C%E5%AE%AE%E4%B9%8B%E7%BE%8E-.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Wanhe_Temple" title="Wanhe Temple">Wanhe Temple</a> is one of the temples dedicated to the sea goddess <a href="/wiki/Mazu" title="Mazu">Mazu</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Constitution of the Republic of China protects people's <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of religion</a> and the practices of belief.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[416]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion_in_Taiwan" title="Freedom of religion in Taiwan">Freedom of religion in Taiwan</a> is strong and ranks high at 9.2 in 2018 according to <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[417]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2005, the census reported that the five largest religions were: <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taoism" title="Taoism">Taoism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yiguandao" title="Yiguandao">Yiguandao</a>, <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestantism</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism" title="Roman Catholicism">Roman Catholicism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-religion_446-0"><a href="#cite_note-religion-446">[418]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Research</a>, the religious composition of Taiwan in 2020<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[419]</a></sup> is estimated to be 43.8 per cent <a href="/wiki/Chinese_folk_religion" title="Chinese folk religion">Folk religions</a>, 21.2 per cent <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Taiwan" title="Buddhism in Taiwan">Buddhist</a>, 15.5 Others (including <a href="/wiki/Taoism" title="Taoism">Taoism</a>), 13.7 per cent Unaffiliated, 5.8 per cent Christian and 1% Muslim. Taiwanese aborigines comprise a notable subgroup among professing Christians: "...<span class="nowrap"> </span>over 64 per cent identify as Christian<span class="nowrap"> </span>... Church buildings are the most obvious markers of Aboriginal villages, distinguishing them from Taiwanese or Hakka villages".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[420]</a></sup> There has been a small <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Taiwan" title="Islam in Taiwan">Muslim</a> community of <a href="/wiki/Hui_people" title="Hui people">Hui people</a> in Taiwan since the 17th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[421]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a> is a philosophy that deals with secular moral ethics, and serves as the foundation of both <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Culture_of_China" title="Culture of China">Chinese</a> and <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Taiwan" title="Culture of Taiwan">Taiwanese culture</a>. The majority of <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_people" title="Taiwanese people">Taiwanese people</a> usually combine the secular moral teachings of Confucianism with whatever religions they are affiliated with.
</p><p>As of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Taiwan&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, there were 15,175 <a href="/wiki/Place_of_worship" title="Place of worship">religious buildings</a> in Taiwan, approximately one <a href="/wiki/Place_of_worship" title="Place of worship">place of worship</a> per 1,572 residents. 12,279 temples were dedicated to <a href="/wiki/Taoism" title="Taoism">Taoism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Taiwan" title="Buddhism in Taiwan">Buddhism</a>. There were 9,684 <a href="/wiki/Taoism" title="Taoism">Taoist</a> Temples and 2,317 <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Taiwan" title="Buddhism in Taiwan">Buddhist</a> Temples.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-表23各宗教教務概況_450-0"><a href="#cite_note-表23各宗教教務概況-450">[422]</a></sup> In Taiwan's 36,000 square kilometers of land, there are more than 33,000 places for religious (believers) to worship and gather. On average, there is one temple or church (church) or religious building for every square kilometer. The high density of place of worship is rare in the world, and it is the area with the highest density of religious buildings in the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_territories_where_Chinese_is_an_official_language" title="List of countries and territories where Chinese is an official language">Chinese-speaking world</a>. Taiwan is also the most religious region in the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_territories_where_Chinese_is_an_official_language" title="List of countries and territories where Chinese is an official language">Chinese-speaking world</a>. Even for <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, there are 2,845 Churches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-表23各宗教教務概況_450-1"><a href="#cite_note-表23各宗教教務概況-450">[422]</a></sup>
</p><p>A significant percentage of the population of Taiwan is non-religious. Taiwan's strong human rights protections, lack of state-sanctioned discrimination, and generally high regard for freedom of religion or belief earned it a joint #1 ranking in the 2018 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Freedom_of_Thought_Report" title="Freedom of Thought Report">Freedom of Thought Report</a>, alongside the Netherlands and Belgium.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-451"><a href="#cite_note-451">[423]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Taiwan is clearly an outlier in the top 3, all-clear countries. It is non-European, and demographically much more religious. But in its relatively open, democratic and tolerant society we have recorded no evidence of laws or social discrimination against members of the non-religious minority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[424]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="LGBT_rights">LGBT rights</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Taiwan" title="LGBT rights in Taiwan">LGBT rights in Taiwan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage_in_Taiwan" title="Same-sex marriage in Taiwan">Same-sex marriage in Taiwan</a></div>
<p>On 24 May 2017, the <a href="/wiki/Judicial_Yuan#Constitutional_Court" title="Judicial Yuan">Constitutional Court</a> ruled that then-current marriage laws had been violating the Constitution by denying Taiwanese same-sex couples the right to marry. The Court ruled that if the Legislative Yuan did not pass adequate amendments to Taiwanese marriage laws within two years, same-sex marriages would automatically become lawful in Taiwan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[425]</a></sup> In a <a href="/wiki/2018_Taiwanese_referendum" title="2018 Taiwanese referendum">referendum question in 2018</a>, however, voters expressed overwhelming opposition to same-sex marriage and supported the removal of content about homosexuality from primary school textbooks. According to the New York Times, the aforementioned referendum questions were subject to a "well-funded and highly organized campaign led by conservative Christians and other groups" involving the use of "misinformation, the bulk of which was spread online."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HortonNYT2018_281-1"><a href="#cite_note-HortonNYT2018-281">[264]</a></sup> Nevertheless, the vote against same-sex marriage does not affect the court ruling, and on 17 May 2019, Taiwan's parliament approved a bill legalising same-sex marriage, making it the first country in Asia to do so.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454"><a href="#cite_note-454">[426]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455"><a href="#cite_note-455">[427]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[428]</a></sup>
</p><p>Taiwan has an annual pride event, <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Pride" title="Taiwan Pride">Taiwan Pride</a>. It currently holds the record for the largest <a href="/wiki/LGBT" title="LGBT">LGBT</a> gathering in <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East-Asia</a>, rivaling <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv_Pride" title="Tel Aviv Pride">Tel Aviv Pride</a> in <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[429]</a></sup> The event draws more than 200,000 people to demonstrate for equal rights for LGBT people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[430]</a></sup> The event is organized by the Taiwan LGBT Pride Community, and is held on the last Sunday of October.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[431]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Taiwan" title="Healthcare in Taiwan">Healthcare in Taiwan</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Taipei_Taiwan_National-Taiwan-University-Hospital-05.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3869" data-file-width="3410" decoding="async" height="250" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Taipei_Taiwan_National-Taiwan-University-Hospital-05.jpg/220px-Taipei_Taiwan_National-Taiwan-University-Hospital-05.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Taipei_Taiwan_National-Taiwan-University-Hospital-05.jpg/330px-Taipei_Taiwan_National-Taiwan-University-Hospital-05.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Taipei_Taiwan_National-Taiwan-University-Hospital-05.jpg/440px-Taipei_Taiwan_National-Taiwan-University-Hospital-05.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Taipei_Taiwan_National-Taiwan-University-Hospital-05.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/National_Taiwan_University_Hospital" title="National Taiwan University Hospital">National Taiwan University Hospital</a></div></div></div>
<p>The current <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Healthcare_system" title="Healthcare system">healthcare system</a> in Taiwan, known as National Health Insurance (NHI, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a>: <span lang="zh">全民健康保險</span>), was instituted in 1995. NHI is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Single-payer_health_care" title="Single-payer health care">single-payer</a> compulsory social insurance plan that centralizes the disbursement of healthcare funds. The system promises equal access to healthcare for all citizens, and the population coverage had reached 99 per cent by the end of 2004.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[432]</a></sup> NHI is mainly financed through premiums, which are based on the payroll tax, and is supplemented with out-of-pocket co-payments and direct government funding.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461"><a href="#cite_note-461">[433]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462"><a href="#cite_note-462">[434]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463"><a href="#cite_note-463">[435]</a></sup> Low-income families, veterans, centenarians, children under three years old, and catastrophic diseases are exempt from co-payments. Co-pays are reduced for disabled and low income households maintain 100 percent premium coverage by the NHI.
</p><p>Early in the program, the payment system was predominantly <a href="/wiki/Fee-for-service" title="Fee-for-service">fee-for-service</a>. Most health providers operate in the private sector and form a competitive market on the health delivery side. However, many healthcare providers took advantage of the system by offering unnecessary services to a larger number of patients and then billing the government. In the face of increasing loss and the need for cost containment, NHI changed the payment system from fee-for-service to a global budget, a kind of <a href="/wiki/Prospective_payment_system" title="Prospective payment system">prospective payment system</a>, in 2002.
</p><p>The implementation of universal healthcare created fewer <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Health_disparities" title="Health disparities">health disparities</a> for lower-income citizens in Taiwan. According to a recently published survey, out of 3,360 patients surveyed at a randomly chosen hospital, 75.1 per cent of the patients said they are "very satisfied" with the hospital service; 20.5 per cent said they are "okay" with the service. Only 4.4 per cent of the patients said they are either "not satisfied" or "very not satisfied" with the service or care provided.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464"><a href="#cite_note-464">[436]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Taiwanese disease control authority is the <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Centers_for_Disease_Control" title="Taiwan Centers for Disease Control">Taiwan Centers for Disease Control</a> (CDC), and during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome" title="Severe acute respiratory syndrome">SARS</a> outbreak in March 2003 there were 347 confirmed cases. During the outbreak the CDC and local governments set up monitoring stations throughout public transportation, recreational sites and other public areas. With full containment in July 2003, there has not been a case of SARS since.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465"><a href="#cite_note-465">[437]</a></sup> Owing to the lessons from SARS, a <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=National_Health_Command_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="National Health Command Center (page does not exist)">National Health Command Center</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;"> [<a class="extiw" href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centre_de_commandement_national_de_la_sant%C3%A9" title="fr:Centre de commandement national de la santé">fr</a>]</span> was established in 2004, which includes the <a href="/wiki/Central_Epidemic_Command_Center" title="Central Epidemic Command Center">Central Epidemic Command Center</a> (CECC). The CECC has since played a central role in Taiwan's approach to epidemics, including the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Taiwan" title="COVID-19 pandemic in Taiwan">COVID-19 pandemic</a>.
</p><p>In 2019, the infant mortality rate was 4.2 deaths per 1,000 live births, with 20 physicians and 71 hospital beds per 10,000 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[438]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467"><a href="#cite_note-467">[439]</a></sup> Life expectancy at birth in 2020 is 77.5 years and 83.9 years for males and females, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[440]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Taiwan" title="Culture of Taiwan">Culture of Taiwan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cultural_history_of_Taiwan" title="Cultural history of Taiwan">Cultural history of Taiwan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Cultural_Renaissance" title="Chinese Cultural Renaissance">Chinese Cultural Renaissance</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_wave" title="Taiwanese wave">Taiwanese wave</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Taiwanese_aborigines.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Taiwanese_aborigines.JPG/220px-Taiwanese_aborigines.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Taiwanese_aborigines.JPG/330px-Taiwanese_aborigines.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Taiwanese_aborigines.JPG/440px-Taiwanese_aborigines.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Taiwanese_aborigines.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Amis_people" title="Amis people">Amis people</a> of Taiwan performing a traditional dance</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:201402_%E5%9C%8B%E7%AB%8B%E6%95%85%E5%AE%AE%E5%8D%9A%E7%89%A9%E9%99%A2_%E6%96%B0%E5%B9%B4.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2731" data-file-width="4096" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/201402_%E5%9C%8B%E7%AB%8B%E6%95%85%E5%AE%AE%E5%8D%9A%E7%89%A9%E9%99%A2_%E6%96%B0%E5%B9%B4.jpg/220px-201402_%E5%9C%8B%E7%AB%8B%E6%95%85%E5%AE%AE%E5%8D%9A%E7%89%A9%E9%99%A2_%E6%96%B0%E5%B9%B4.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/201402_%E5%9C%8B%E7%AB%8B%E6%95%85%E5%AE%AE%E5%8D%9A%E7%89%A9%E9%99%A2_%E6%96%B0%E5%B9%B4.jpg/330px-201402_%E5%9C%8B%E7%AB%8B%E6%95%85%E5%AE%AE%E5%8D%9A%E7%89%A9%E9%99%A2_%E6%96%B0%E5%B9%B4.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/201402_%E5%9C%8B%E7%AB%8B%E6%95%85%E5%AE%AE%E5%8D%9A%E7%89%A9%E9%99%A2_%E6%96%B0%E5%B9%B4.jpg/440px-201402_%E5%9C%8B%E7%AB%8B%E6%95%85%E5%AE%AE%E5%8D%9A%E7%89%A9%E9%99%A2_%E6%96%B0%E5%B9%B4.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:201402_%E5%9C%8B%E7%AB%8B%E6%95%85%E5%AE%AE%E5%8D%9A%E7%89%A9%E9%99%A2_%E6%96%B0%E5%B9%B4.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/National_Palace_Museum" title="National Palace Museum">National Palace Museum</a> is an institute dedicated to the organization, care, and display of ancient Chinese artifacts and works of art</div></div></div>
<p>The cultures of Taiwan are a hybrid blend from various sources, incorporating elements of the majority <a href="/wiki/Chinese_culture" title="Chinese culture">traditional Chinese culture</a>, aboriginal cultures, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Japan" title="Culture of Japan">Japanese cultural influence</a>, traditional Confucianist beliefs, and increasingly, <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">Western values</a>.
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/Martial_law_in_Taiwan" title="Martial law in Taiwan">martial law period</a> in which the Republic of China was officially <a href="/wiki/Anti-communism" title="Anti-communism">anti-communist</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang" title="Kuomintang">Kuomintang</a> promoted an official <a href="/wiki/Chinese_culture" title="Chinese culture">traditional Chinese culture</a> over Taiwan in order to emphasize that the Republic of China represents the true orthodoxy to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_Culture" title="Chinese Culture">Chinese Culture</a> (and therefore the "real and legitimate China") as opposed to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="People's Republic of China">Communist China</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469"><a href="#cite_note-469">[441]</a></sup> The government launched what's known as the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Cultural_Renaissance" title="Chinese Cultural Renaissance">Chinese Cultural Renaissance</a> movement in Taiwan in opposition to the cultural destructions caused by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_China" title="Communist Party of China">Chinese Communist Party</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution" title="Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a>. The General Assembly of Chinese Culture (中華文化總會) was established as a movement promotion council to help promote Chinese Culture in Taiwan and overseas. It was <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang" title="Kuomintang">Kuomintang</a>'s first structured plan for cultural development on Taiwan. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chiang_Kai_Shek" title="Chiang Kai Shek">Chiang</a> himself was the head of the General Assembly of Chinese Culture. Subsequent <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="President of the Republic of China">President of the Republic of China</a> also became the head of this General Assembly. The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Cultural_Renaissance" title="Chinese Cultural Renaissance">Chinese Cultural Renaissance</a> movement in Taiwan coupled with Chinese Cultural education in Taiwan had helped to elevate the cultural refinement, mannerism and politeness of many Taiwanese, in contrast to the cultural destruction (uncultured behaviour) of many mainland Chinese due to the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution" title="Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470"><a href="#cite_note-470">[442]</a></sup> This has also led to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_Culture" title="Chinese Culture">Chinese Culture</a> (especially its soft culture) being better preserved in Taiwan than in <a href="/wiki/Mainland_China" title="Mainland China">mainland China</a>. An example of this preservation is the continued use of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese" title="Traditional Chinese">Traditional Chinese</a>. The influence of <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a> can be found in the behaviour of <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_people" title="Taiwanese people">Taiwanese people</a>, known for their friendliness and politeness.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471"><a href="#cite_note-471">[443]</a></sup>
</p><p>The lifting of <a href="/wiki/Martial_law_in_Taiwan" title="Martial law in Taiwan">martial law</a> ushered a period of <a href="/wiki/Democratization" title="Democratization">democratization</a> whereby <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Freedom_of_Speech" title="Freedom of Speech">Freedom of Speech and Expression</a> led to a flourishing <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_literature" title="Taiwanese literature">Taiwanese literature</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mass_media_in_Taiwan" title="Mass media in Taiwan">Mass media in Taiwan</a>.   
</p><p>Reflecting the continuing controversy surrounding the political status of Taiwan, politics continues to play a role in the conception and development of a Taiwanese cultural identity, especially in its relationship to Chinese culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[444]</a></sup> In recent years, the concept of Taiwanese <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism" title="Multiculturalism">multiculturalism</a> has been proposed as a relatively apolitical alternative view, which has allowed for the inclusion of mainlanders and other minority groups into the continuing re-definition of Taiwanese culture as collectively held systems of meaning and customary patterns of thought and behaviour shared by the people of Taiwan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473"><a href="#cite_note-473">[445]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Identity_politics" title="Identity politics">Identity politics</a>, along with the over one hundred years of political separation from mainland China, has led to distinct traditions in many areas, including <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_cuisine" title="Taiwanese cuisine">cuisine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Taiwan" title="Music of Taiwan">music</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arts">Arts</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Taiwan" title="Music of Taiwan">Music of Taiwan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_art" title="Taiwanese art">Taiwanese art</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097763485">.mw-parser-output .ambox{border:1px solid #a2a9b1;border-left:10px solid #36c;background-color:#fbfbfb;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .mbox-text-span{margin-left:23px!important}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .ambox{margin:0 10%}}</style><table class="box-Recentism plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-style ambox-Recentism" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/40px-Edit-clear.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/60px-Edit-clear.svg.png 1.5x, href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a></small>)</i></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Acclaimed classical musicians include violinist <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cho-Liang_Lin" title="Cho-Liang Lin">Cho-Liang Lin</a>, pianist <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ching-Yun_Hu" title="Ching-Yun Hu">Ching-Yun Hu</a>, and the Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society artist director <a href="/wiki/Wu_Han_(pianist)" title="Wu Han (pianist)">Wu Han</a>. Other musicians include <a href="/wiki/Teresa_Teng" title="Teresa Teng">Teresa Teng</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jay_Chou" title="Jay Chou">Jay Chou</a> and groups such as <a href="/wiki/Mayday_(Taiwanese_band)" title="Mayday (Taiwanese band)">Mayday</a> and <a href="/wiki/Heavy_metal_music" title="Heavy metal music">heavy metal</a> band <a href="/wiki/Chthonic_(band)" title="Chthonic (band)">Chthonic</a>, led by singer <a href="/wiki/Freddy_Lim" title="Freddy Lim">Freddy Lim</a>, which has been referred to as the "<a href="/wiki/Black_Sabbath" title="Black Sabbath">Black Sabbath</a> of Asia".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-474"><a href="#cite_note-474">[446]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-475"><a href="#cite_note-475">[447]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Taiwan" title="Cinema of Taiwan">Taiwanese films</a> have won various international awards at film festivals around the world. <a href="/wiki/Ang_Lee" title="Ang Lee">Ang Lee</a>, a Taiwanese director, has directed critically acclaimed films such as: <i><a href="/wiki/Crouching_Tiger,_Hidden_Dragon" title="Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon">Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon</a></i>; <i><a href="/wiki/Eat_Drink_Man_Woman" title="Eat Drink Man Woman">Eat Drink Man Woman</a></i>; <i><a href="/wiki/Sense_and_Sensibility_(film)" title="Sense and Sensibility (film)">Sense and Sensibility</a></i>; <i><a href="/wiki/Brokeback_Mountain" title="Brokeback Mountain">Brokeback Mountain</a></i>; <i><a href="/wiki/Life_of_Pi_(film)" title="Life of Pi (film)">Life of Pi</a></i>; and <i><a href="/wiki/Lust,_Caution" title="Lust, Caution">Lust, Caution</a></i>. Other famous Taiwanese directors include <a href="/wiki/Tsai_Ming-liang" title="Tsai Ming-liang">Tsai Ming-liang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Edward_Yang" title="Edward Yang">Edward Yang</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hou_Hsiao-hsien" title="Hou Hsiao-hsien">Hou Hsiao-hsien</a>. Taiwan has hosted the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horse_Film_Festival_and_Awards" title="Golden Horse Film Festival and Awards">Golden Horse Film Festival and Awards</a> since 1962.
</p><p>Taiwan hosts the <a href="/wiki/National_Palace_Museum" title="National Palace Museum">National Palace Museum</a>, which houses more than 650,000 pieces of Chinese bronze, jade, calligraphy, painting, and porcelain and is considered one of the greatest collections of Chinese art and objects in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[448]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_cuisine" title="Taiwanese cuisine">Taiwanese cuisine</a></div>
<p>Taiwanese culinary history is murky and is intricately tied to patterns of migration and colonization. Local and international Taiwanese cuisine, including its history, is a politically contentious topic. Famous Taiwanese dishes include <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_beef_noodle_soup" title="Taiwanese beef noodle soup">Taiwanese beef noodle soup</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gua_bao" title="Gua bao">Gua bao</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zongzi" title="Zongzi">Zongzi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khong_bah_png" title="Khong bah png">Khong bah png</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_fried_chicken" title="Taiwanese fried chicken">Taiwanese fried chicken</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oyster_vermicelli" title="Oyster vermicelli">oyster vermicelli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sanbeiji" title="Sanbeiji">Sanbeiji</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Aiyu_jelly" title="Aiyu jelly">Aiyu jelly</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eater_2019_477-0"><a href="#cite_note-Eater_2019-477">[449]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Michelin_Guide" title="Michelin Guide">Michelin Guide</a> began reviewing restaurants in Taipei in 2018 and Taichung in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-478"><a href="#cite_note-478">[450]</a></sup> In 2014 <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i> called <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taiwanese_night_markets" title="Taiwanese night markets">Taiwanese night markets</a> the "best street food markets in the world".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Guardian_2014_479-0"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian_2014-479">[451]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Bubble_tea" title="Bubble tea">Bubble tea</a>, created in Taiwan in the 1980s, has now become a global phenomenon with its popularity spreading across the globe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480"><a href="#cite_note-480">[452]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Popular_culture">Popular culture</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Karaoke" title="Karaoke">Karaoke</a>, drawn from contemporary Japanese culture, is extremely popular in Taiwan, where it is known as KTV.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-481"><a href="#cite_note-481">[453]</a></sup> KTV businesses operate in a hotel-like style, renting out small rooms and ballrooms according to the number of guests in a group. Many KTV establishments partner with restaurants and buffets to form all-encompassing and elaborate evening affairs for families, friends, or businessmen. Tour busses that travel around Taiwan have several TVs, primarily for singing karaoke.
</p><p>Taiwan has a high density of 24-hour convenience stores, which, in addition to the usual services, provide services on behalf of financial institutions or government agencies, such as collection of parking fees, utility bills, traffic violation fines, and credit card payments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-482"><a href="#cite_note-482">[454]</a></sup> They also provide a service for mailing packages. Chains such as <a href="/wiki/FamilyMart" title="FamilyMart">FamilyMart</a> provide clothing laundry services,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-483"><a href="#cite_note-483">[455]</a></sup> and it is possible to purchase or receive tickets for <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Railways_Administration" title="Taiwan Railways Administration">TRA</a> and THSR tickets at convenience stores, specifically <a href="/wiki/7-Eleven" title="7-Eleven">7-Eleven</a>, FamilyMart, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Hi-Life_(convenience_store)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Hi-Life (convenience store) (page does not exist)">Hi-Life</a> and <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=OK_(convenience_store)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="OK (convenience store) (page does not exist)">OK</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-484"><a href="#cite_note-484">[456]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-485"><a href="#cite_note-485">[457]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Taiwan" title="Sport in Taiwan">Sport in Taiwan</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:11.27_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A7%80%E8%B3%9E%E3%80%8C2021%E4%B8%AD%E8%8F%AF%E8%81%B7%E6%A3%92%E7%B8%BD%E5%86%A0%E8%BB%8D%E8%B3%BD%E9%A6%96%E6%88%B0%E3%80%8D.jpg"><img alt="" 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:11.27_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A7%80%E8%B3%9E%E3%80%8C2021%E4%B8%AD%E8%8F%AF%E8%81%B7%E6%A3%92%E7%B8%BD%E5%86%A0%E8%BB%8D%E8%B3%BD%E9%A6%96%E6%88%B0%E3%80%8D.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Professional_Baseball_League" title="Chinese Professional Baseball League">Chinese Professional Baseball League</a> (CPBL) is the top-tier professional baseball league in Taiwan</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tai_Tzu-ying_at_2022_Taipei_Open.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1672" data-file-width="2508" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Tai_Tzu-ying_at_2022_Taipei_Open.jpg/220px-Tai_Tzu-ying_at_2022_Taipei_Open.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Tai_Tzu-ying_at_2022_Taipei_Open.jpg/330px-Tai_Tzu-ying_at_2022_Taipei_Open.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Tai_Tzu-ying_at_2022_Taipei_Open.jpg/440px-Tai_Tzu-ying_at_2022_Taipei_Open.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tai_Tzu-ying_at_2022_Taipei_Open.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Tai_Tzu-ying" title="Tai Tzu-ying">Tai Tzu-ying</a> spent most weeks as world No. 1 women's singles player in <a href="/wiki/BWF_World_Ranking" title="BWF World Ranking">BWF World Ranking</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Baseball" title="Baseball">Baseball</a> is commonly considered as Taiwan's <a href="/wiki/National_sport" title="National sport">national sport</a> and is a popular spectator sport.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486"><a href="#cite_note-486">[458]</a></sup> The Taiwanese <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Taipei_national_baseball_team" title="Chinese Taipei national baseball team">men's baseball team</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Taipei_women%27s_national_baseball_team" title="Chinese Taipei women's national baseball team">women's baseball team</a> are world No.2 in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/WBSC_Rankings" title="WBSC Rankings">WBSC Rankings</a> as of June 2021. The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Professional_Baseball_League" title="Chinese Professional Baseball League">Chinese Professional Baseball League</a> (CPBL) in Taiwan was established in 1989 and eventually absorbed the competing <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_Major_League" title="Taiwan Major League">Taiwan Major League</a> in 2003. As of 2021, the CPBL has five teams, with average attendance around 4,000 per game.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-487"><a href="#cite_note-487">[459]</a></sup> Some elite players signed with overseas professional teams in the <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> (MLB) or the <a href="/wiki/Nippon_Professional_Baseball" title="Nippon Professional Baseball">Nippon Professional Baseball</a> (NPB). There have been sixteen <a href="/wiki/List_of_Major_League_Baseball_players_from_Taiwan" title="List of Major League Baseball players from Taiwan">Taiwanese MLB players</a> in the United States as of the 2022 MLB Season, including former pitchers <a href="/wiki/Chien-Ming_Wang" title="Chien-Ming Wang">Chien-Ming Wang</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wei-Yin_Chen" title="Wei-Yin Chen">Wei-Yin Chen</a>.
</p><p>Besides baseball, <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">basketball</a> is Taiwan's other major sport.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-488"><a href="#cite_note-488">[460]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/P._League%2B" title="P. League+">P. League+</a> and <a href="/wiki/T1_League" title="T1 League">T1 League</a> are two Taiwan's professional basketball leagues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-489"><a href="#cite_note-489">[461]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-490"><a href="#cite_note-490">[462]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Semi-professional_sports" title="Semi-professional sports">semi-professional</a> <a href="/wiki/Super_Basketball_League" title="Super Basketball League">Super Basketball League</a> (SBL) has also been in play since 2003.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-491"><a href="#cite_note-491">[463]</a></sup> Two other teams from Taiwan compete in the <a href="/wiki/ASEAN_Basketball_League" title="ASEAN Basketball League">ASEAN Basketball League</a>, a professional men's basketball league in East and Southeast Asia. Other team sports including <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a> and <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">volleyball</a> are practiced and sports leagues are run by Taiwanese sports governing bodies. Taiwan is also a major competitor in <a href="/wiki/Korfball" title="Korfball">korfball</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-492"><a href="#cite_note-492">[464]</a></sup>
</p><p>Taiwan participates in international sporting organizations and events under the name of "Chinese Taipei" due to its political status. In 2009, Taiwan hosted two <a href="/wiki/Multi-sport_event" title="Multi-sport event">multi-sport events</a> on the island. The <a href="/wiki/2009_World_Games" title="2009 World Games">2009 World Games</a> were held in Kaohsiung and the <a href="/wiki/2009_Summer_Deaflympics" title="2009 Summer Deaflympics">Summer Deaflympics</a> were held in Taipei. Furthermore, Taipei hosted the Summer <a href="/wiki/Universiade" title="Universiade">Universiade</a> in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493"><a href="#cite_note-493">[465]</a></sup> In terms of annual international competitions held in Taiwan, the <a href="/wiki/William_Jones_Cup" title="William Jones Cup">William Jones Cup</a> for basketball and the <a href="/wiki/Taipei_Open_(badminton)" title="Taipei Open (badminton)">Taipei Open</a> for badminton are the events with more than forty years of history.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Taekwondo" title="Taekwondo">Taekwondo</a> was introduced to Taiwan in 1966 for military training and has become a mature and successful <a href="/wiki/Combat_sport" title="Combat sport">combat sport</a> in Taiwan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[466]</a></sup> The first two Olympic gold medals won by Taiwanese athletes belong to the sport. In the <a href="/wiki/Taekwondo_at_the_2004_Summer_Olympics" title="Taekwondo at the 2004 Summer Olympics">2004 Olympics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chen_Shih-hsin" title="Chen Shih-hsin">Chen Shih-hsin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chu_Mu-yen" title="Chu Mu-yen">Chu Mu-yen</a> won gold medals in the women's flyweight event and the men's flyweight event, respectively. Subsequent taekwondo competitors have strengthened Taiwan's taekwondo culture.
</p><p>In individual ball sports, Taiwanese athletes are often seen in international tournaments. <a href="/wiki/Yani_Tseng" title="Yani Tseng">Yani Tseng</a> is the youngest <a href="/wiki/Golf" title="Golf">golf</a> player ever, male or female, to win five <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_major_golf_championships" title="Women's major golf championships">major championships</a> and was ranked number 1 in the <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_World_Golf_Rankings" title="Women's World Golf Rankings">Women's World Golf Rankings</a> for 109 consecutive weeks from 2011 to 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[467]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-496"><a href="#cite_note-496">[468]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-497"><a href="#cite_note-497">[469]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hsieh_Su-wei" title="Hsieh Su-wei">Hsieh Su-wei</a> is the country's most successful player. She reached a career-high singles <a href="/wiki/WTA_rankings" title="WTA rankings">ranking</a> of world No. 23 in 2013 and world No. 1 in the doubles rankings in 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-498"><a href="#cite_note-498">[470]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-499"><a href="#cite_note-499">[471]</a></sup> Taiwan's strength in <a href="/wiki/Badminton" title="Badminton">badminton</a> is demonstrated by <a href="/wiki/Tai_Tzu-ying" title="Tai Tzu-ying">Tai Tzu-ying</a>, who spent most weeks as world No. 1 women's singles player in <a href="/wiki/BWF_World_Ranking" title="BWF World Ranking">BWF World Ranking</a>, and her compatriots in the <a href="/wiki/BWF_World_Tour" title="BWF World Tour">BWF World Tour</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-500"><a href="#cite_note-500">[472]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[473]</a></sup> Taiwan also has a long history of strong international presence in <a href="/wiki/Table_tennis" title="Table tennis">table tennis</a>. Five-time Olympian <a href="/wiki/Chuang_Chih-yuan" title="Chuang Chih-yuan">Chuang Chih-yuan</a> made the most appearances at the Olympic Games among Taiwanese athletes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-502"><a href="#cite_note-502">[474]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Calendar">Calendar</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_calendar" title="Republic of China calendar">Republic of China calendar</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Chinese_calendar" title="Chinese calendar">Chinese calendar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Taiwan" title="Public holidays in Taiwan">Public holidays in Taiwan</a></div>
<p>The standard <a href="/wiki/Gregorian_calendar" title="Gregorian calendar">Gregorian calendar</a> is used for most purposes in Taiwan. The year is often denoted by the Minguo <a href="/wiki/Calendar_era" title="Calendar era">era system</a> which starts in 1912, the year the ROC was founded. 2021 is year 110 Minguo (民國110年). The <a href="/wiki/Calendar_date#Gregorian,_year–month–day_(YMD)" title="Calendar date">East Asian date format</a> is used in Chinese.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-503"><a href="#cite_note-503">[475]</a></sup>
</p><p>Prior to standardisation in 1929, the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_calendar" title="Chinese calendar">Chinese calendar</a> was officially used. It is a <a href="/wiki/Lunisolar_calendar" title="Lunisolar calendar">Lunisolar calendar system</a> which remains in use today for traditional festivals such as the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_New_Year" title="Chinese New Year">Lunar New Year</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Lantern_Festival" title="Lantern Festival">Lantern Festival</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Dragon_Boat_Festival" title="Dragon Boat Festival">Dragon Boat Festival</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-504"><a href="#cite_note-504">[476]</a></sup>
</p>

<li><span><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ic%C3%B4ne_Ile.svg"><img alt="icon" class="noviewer" data-file-height="200" data-file-width="200" decoding="async" height="28" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Ic%C3%B4ne_Ile.svg/28px-Ic%C3%B4ne_Ile.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Ic%C3%B4ne_Ile.svg/42px-Ic%C3%B4ne_Ile.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Ic%C3%B4ne_Ile.svg/56px-Ic%C3%B4ne_Ile.svg.png 2x" width="28"/></a></span><span><a href="/wiki/Portal:Islands" title="Portal:Islands">Islands portal</a></span></li></ul></div>
